@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.documentation: Provides functionality for audio manipulation and playback, including volume and pitch adjustments, spatial considerations, and muting capabilities.

@highrise/global/AudioShader.documentation: Provides functionality for audio manipulation and playback, including volume and pitch adjustments, spatial considerations, and muting capabilities.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.Play.documentation: Begins playback of the audio with optional volume and pitch parameters.
@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.Play.code_sample:
-- Play the audio with custom volume and pitch
audioShaderInstance:Play(0.8, 1.1)

params.name: volume
params.documentation: The volume at which to play the audio. Overrides the instance's volume property for this playback.

params.name: pitch
params.documentation: The pitch at which to play the audio. Overrides the instance's pitch property for this playback.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.GetRand.documentation: Returns a randomly selected AudioClip from the available set.
@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.GetRand.code_sample:
-- Get a random AudioClip
local randomClip = audioShaderInstance:GetRandomClip()

returns.documentation: The randomly selected AudioClip object.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioShaderType.Cre.documentation: Creates a new instance of AudioShader with a specified AudioClip.
@highrise/globaltype/AudioShaderType.Cre.code_sample:
-- Create a new AudioShader instance with the specified AudioClip
local audioShaderInstance = AudioShader.Create(clip)

params.name: clip
params.documentation: The AudioClip to associate with the new AudioShader instance.

returns.documentation: A new instance of AudioShader configured with the provided AudioClip.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.isMuted.documentation: Indicates whether the audio is currently muted.
@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.isMuted.code_sample:
-- Check if the audio is muted
local isMuted = audioShaderInstance.isMuted

print(tostring(isMuted) -- true or false

@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.spatial.documentation: Defines the range in which the audio can be heard.
@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.spatial.code_sample:
-- Set the spatial range of the audio
audioShaderInstance.spatialRange = 10

@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.volume.documentation: Controls the playback volume of the audio.
@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.volume.code_sample:
-- Set the volume of the audio
audioShaderInstance.volume = 0.5

@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.randomV.documentation: Sets a range for random volume variation.
@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.randomV.code_sample:
-- Set the random volume range of the audio
audioShaderInstance.randomVolume = 0.1

@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.pitch.documentation: Adjusts the pitch of the audio playback.
@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.pitch.code_sample:
-- Set the pitch of the audio
audioShaderInstance.pitch = 1.2

@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.randomP.documentation: Sets a range for random pitch variation.
@highrise/globaltype/AudioShader.randomP.code_sample:
-- Set the random pitch range of the audio
audioShaderInstance.randomPitch = 0.2

@highrise/globaltype/Collider.documentation: Collider acts as an invisible force field around GameObjects, essential for interactions like collisions and input responses. Integrating with Rigidbody, Colliders allow objects to engage physically with the game world, simulating real-world physics. Various Collider types match different object shapes, enabling precise interaction management. Colliders can be set as triggers for event detection without physical response, offering versatility in gameplay mechanics. Refer to the official Unity Collider documentation for in-depth guidance.

@highrise/global/Collider.documentation: Collider acts as an invisible force field around GameObjects, essential for interactions like collisions and input responses. Integrating with Rigidbody, Colliders allow objects to engage physically with the game world, simulating real-world physics. Various Collider types match different object shapes, enabling precise interaction management. Colliders can be set as triggers for event detection without physical response, offering versatility in gameplay mechanics. Refer to the official Unity Collider documentation for in-depth guidance.

@highrise/globaltype/Collider.ClosestPoi.documentation: Determines the nearest point on the Collider to a specified location, useful for proximity-based interactions.

params.name: position
params.documentation: Target position for closest point calculation.

returns.documentation: The nearest point on the Collider.

@highrise/globaltype/Collider.ClosestPoi.documentation: Identifies the nearest point on the Collider's bounds to a given location, focusing solely on outer limits.

params.name: position
params.documentation: Target position relative to the Collider's bounds.

returns.documentation: The closest boundary point.

@highrise/globaltype/Collider.enabled.documentation: Toggles the Collider's interaction capabilities; disabling prevents collision detection.

@highrise/globaltype/Collider.attachedRi.documentation: Points to the Rigidbody component associated with the Collider, crucial for physics interactions.

@highrise/globaltype/Collider.isTrigger.documentation: Converts the Collider into a Trigger, which notifies of entering or exiting objects without physical collisions.

@highrise/globaltype/Collider.contactOff.documentation: Adjusts collision detection sensitivity, controlling the threshold for collision recognition.

@highrise/globaltype/Collider.bounds.documentation: Retrieves the Collider's world space bounds, outlining its physical extent.

@highrise/globaltype/Collider.hasModifia.documentation: Indicates the capability to modify collision contacts, useful for custom collision handling.

@highrise/globaltype/Collider.providesCo.documentation: Identifies if the Collider supplies collision contact data, facilitating detailed interaction analysis.

@highrise/globaltype/Collider.layerOverr.documentation: Determines override precedence in Layer Collision Matrix conflicts, guiding collision layer resolution.

@highrise/globaltype/Collider.excludeLay.documentation: Specifies layers to exclude from collision detection, enhancing control over interaction scope.

@highrise/globaltype/Collider.includeLay.documentation: Defines layers to include in collision detection, allowing targeted interaction setups.

@highrise/globaltype/FingerCountBegin.documentation: Event sent when the required finger count has been met

@highrise/global/FingerCountBegin.documentation: Event sent when the required finger count has been met

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.documentation: Camera in Unity acts as the player's viewpoint into the game world, capturing scenes much like a real camera. It defines the field of view, perspective, and what is visible on the screen. Cameras can transform between world and screen space, control projection settings for depth and perspective, specify rendering settings, and manage culling properties. For comprehensive functionalities, explore Unity's Camera documentation.

@highrise/global/Camera.documentation: Camera in Unity acts as the player's viewpoint into the game world, capturing scenes much like a real camera. It defines the field of view, perspective, and what is visible on the screen. Cameras can transform between world and screen space, control projection settings for depth and perspective, specify rendering settings, and manage culling properties. For comprehensive functionalities, explore Unity's Camera documentation.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.ScreenToWorl.documentation: Converts a point from screen space into world space for this Camera, useful for interaction with game objects.

params.name: position
params.documentation: The screen space position to convert.

returns.documentation: The converted world space position.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.WorldToScree.documentation: Transforms a world space point to screen space, allowing UI alignment or visibility checks.

params.name: position
params.documentation: The world space position to convert.

returns.documentation: The screen space representation of the point.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.ScreenPointT.documentation: Creates a ray from the Camera through a screen point, primarily for object selection via raycasting.

params.name: position
params.documentation: The screen point through which the ray passes.

returns.documentation: The ray from the camera through the screen point.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.Reset.documentation: Resets all Camera settings to their defaults, useful for reinitializing camera properties.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.ResetTranspa.documentation: Reverts the Camera's transparency sort settings to the default state.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.ResetAspect.documentation: Resets the Camera's aspect ratio to the screen's aspect ratio, undoing any custom aspect ratio settings.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.ResetCulling.documentation: Resets the Camera's culling matrix to the default, useful for undoing custom culling adjustments.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.ResetReplace.documentation: Removes any replacement shader from the Camera, returning to standard rendering.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.GetGateFitte.documentation: Calculates the field of view based on gate fitting, useful for matching physical camera settings.

returns.documentation: The calculated field of view.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.GetGateFitte.documentation: Determines the lens shift required based on gate fitting, aiding in accurate camera simulation.

returns.documentation: The required lens shift.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.ResetWorldTo.documentation: Resets the Camera's world-to-camera matrix to the identity matrix, clearing any transformations.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.ResetProject.documentation: Reverts the Camera's projection matrix to default, useful for standard perspective restoration.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.CalculateObl.documentation: Creates a custom projection matrix for oblique near-plane clipping, useful for mirror reflections or water surfaces.

params.name: clipPlane
params.documentation: The clipping plane to align with.

returns.documentation: The custom projection matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.ScreenToView.documentation: Transforms a point from screen space to normalized viewport space.

params.name: position
params.documentation: The screen space point to convert.

returns.documentation: The viewport space position.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.ViewportToSc.documentation: Converts a point from normalized viewport space to screen space.

params.name: position
params.documentation: The viewport space point to convert.

returns.documentation: The screen space position.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.ResetStereoP.documentation: Resets the stereo projection matrices for left and right eyes to the default values.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.ResetStereoV.documentation: Reverts the stereo view matrices for the left and right eyes to Unity's defaults.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.Render.documentation: Forces immediate rendering of the scene from this Camera's perspective.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.RenderDontRe.documentation: Renders the scene immediately without restoring the Camera's state afterwards.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.CopyFrom.documentation: Copies settings from another Camera, including all properties and transformation matrices.

params.name: other
params.documentation: The source Camera to copy from.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.RemoveAllCom.documentation: Deletes all command buffers attached to this Camera.

@highrise/globaltype/CameraType.FocalLen.documentation: Converts focal length to vertical field of view for the Camera's sensor size.

params.name: focalLength
params.documentation: The focal length to convert.

params.name: sensorSize
params.documentation: The vertical size of the sensor.

returns.documentation: The calculated vertical field of view.

@highrise/globaltype/CameraType.FieldOfV.documentation: Calculates the focal length from a given vertical field of view and sensor size.

params.name: fieldOfView
params.documentation: The vertical field of view to convert.

params.name: sensorSize
params.documentation: The vertical size of the sensor.

returns.documentation: The focal length corresponding to the given field of view.

@highrise/globaltype/CameraType.Horizont.documentation: Converts a horizontal field of view to a vertical field of view based on the aspect ratio.

params.name: horizontalFieldOfView
params.documentation: The horizontal field of view to convert.

params.name: aspectRatio
params.documentation: The aspect ratio of the camera.

returns.documentation: The vertical field of view.

@highrise/globaltype/CameraType.Vertical.documentation: Converts a vertical field of view to a horizontal field of view based on the aspect ratio.

params.name: verticalFieldOfView
params.documentation: The vertical field of view to convert.

params.name: aspectRatio
params.documentation: The aspect ratio of the camera.

returns.documentation: The horizontal field of view.

@highrise/globaltype/CameraType.SetupCur.documentation: Sets a specified Camera as the current active Camera, useful for dynamic camera switching.

params.name: cur
params.documentation: The Camera to set as current.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.nearClipPlan.documentation: Defines the closest distance at which the Camera starts rendering objects.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.farClipPlane.documentation: Sets the maximum distance up to which the Camera renders objects in the scene.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.fieldOfView.documentation: Manages the vertical extent of the scene visible at any moment, measured in degrees.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.allowHDR.documentation: Controls if the Camera uses High Dynamic Range rendering for enhanced visual details.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.allowMSAA.documentation: Enables or disables Multi-Sample Anti-Aliasing for smoother image edges.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.allowDynamic.documentation: Allows dynamic resolution adjustment for performance optimization.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.forceIntoRen.documentation: Forces Camera's view to always render to a texture for advanced image processing.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.orthographic.documentation: Defines the size of the view in world units for Orthographic Cameras.
Toggles between Perspective and Orthographic modes for the Camera.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.transparency.documentation: Custom axis for sorting transparent objects when using Custom Axis mode.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.depth.documentation: Specifies the Camera's depth in the rendering order.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.aspect.documentation: Sets the aspect ratio (width/height) for the Camera.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.velocity.documentation: Provides the Camera's velocity, useful for motion blur effects.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.cullingMask.documentation: Bit mask for rendering GameObjects on specific Layers.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.eventMask.documentation: Bit mask to selectively ignore GameObjects when sending events.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.layerCullSph.documentation: Uses spherical bounds for layer culling computation when enabled.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.overrideScen.documentation: Bit mask override for Scene culling on this Camera.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.useOcclusion.documentation: Determines if Unity performs occlusion culling for this Camera.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.cullingMatri.documentation: Custom projection matrix for the Camera to adjust rendering.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.backgroundCo.documentation: Sets the background color for the Camera's view.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.clearStencil.documentation: Clears the stencil buffer after lighting pass as an optimization.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.usePhysicalP.documentation: Enables physical camera settings to simulate real camera properties.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.iso.documentation: Simulates the ISO setting of a physical camera, affecting image brightness and noise.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.shutterSpeed.documentation: Mimics a camera's shutter speed, influencing exposure and motion blur.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.aperture.documentation: Emulates the aperture of a physical camera, impacting light intake and depth of field.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.focusDistanc.documentation: Adjusts the distance to the focus plane, useful for depth of field effects.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.focalLength.documentation: Represents the focal length of the camera lens, affecting the field of view.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.bladeCount.documentation: Sets the number of diaphragm blades, affecting the shape of out-of-focus areas.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.curvature.documentation: Simulates lens curvature, affecting perspective distortion in the rendered image.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.barrelClippi.documentation: Determines the clipping level for light entering the camera, affecting edge brightness.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.anamorphism.documentation: Creates anamorphic lens effects by compressing the image in one dimension.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.sensorSize.documentation: Imitates the physical dimensions of the camera sensor, affecting the angle of view.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.lensShift.documentation: Allows shifting the lens in relation to the sensor, correcting for keystone distortion.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.rect.documentation: Specifies the Camera's viewport rectangle, controlling which part of the screen it occupies.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.pixelRect.documentation: Defines the rectangle, in pixels, that the Camera renders to on the screen.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.pixelWidth.documentation: Gives the width in pixels of the Camera's rendering area.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.pixelHeight.documentation: Provides the height in pixels of the Camera's rendering area.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.scaledPixelW.documentation: Gets the width of the Camera's image after applying the scaling factor.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.scaledPixelH.documentation: Retrieves the height of the Camera's image with the scaling factor applied.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.targetDispla.documentation: Sets the display for the Camera's output, useful for multi-display setups.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.cameraToWorl.documentation: Provides a matrix transforming from camera space to world space.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.worldToCamer.documentation: Allows setting a custom transformation from world space to camera space.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.projectionMa.documentation: Offers a custom projection matrix for perspective transformations.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.nonJitteredP.documentation: Gives a projection matrix without jittering for anti-aliasing.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.useJitteredP.documentation: Decides whether to use a jittered projection matrix for rendering transparent objects.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.previousView.documentation: Holds the matrix from multiplying the previous frame's projection matrix by its world-to-camera matrix, useful for effects needing historical comparison.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.stereoEnable.documentation: Indicates if stereoscopic rendering is enabled for creating 3D effects.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.stereoSepara.documentation: Adjusts the distance between the stereo camera's views to alter the 3D effect's intensity.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.stereoConver.documentation: Sets the point where the left and right views converge, affecting the depth of the 3D scene.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.areVRStereoV.documentation: Checks if the view matrices for VR rendering fall within a tolerance for efficient culling.

@highrise/globaltype/Camera.commandBuffe.documentation: Returns the total number of command buffers attached to the Camera, for extending rendering.

@highrise/globaltype/CameraType.main.documentation: Accesses the main Camera in the scene, designated by the 'MainCamera' tag.

@highrise/globaltype/CameraType.current.documentation: Retrieves the currently rendering Camera, useful for effects and scripts during rendering.

@highrise/globaltype/CameraType.allCamer.documentation: Gives the count of all enabled Cameras within the Scene.

@highrise/globaltype/CameraType.kMinAper.documentation: Specifies the minimum logical aperture size for cameras, constraining physical camera simulations.

@highrise/globaltype/CameraType.kMaxAper.documentation: Defines the maximum logical aperture size for camera simulations, affecting depth of field and light intake.

@highrise/globaltype/CameraType.kMinBlad.documentation: Indicates the minimum number of aperture blades for simulating camera bokeh effects.

@highrise/globaltype/CameraType.kMaxBlad.documentation: Sets the maximum number of aperture blades for detailed bokeh simulation in camera effects.

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.documentation:
Have you ever wanted to draw lines in your Unity game? Maybe you're creating a laser beam, a route, or even a spider's web. If so, the LineRenderer class is just the tool you need! The LineRenderer class in Unity enables developers to draw a series of connected segments in your scene directly from your scripts.

LineRenderer is immensely versatile and can be used for almost anything that requires a dynamic line. You can customize the line's appearance using various properties like width, color, and texture. In addition, you can precisely control the line's shape by defining the points that the LineRenderer passes through.

Want to create a glowing neon trail in a dark room? Or the trajectory of a projectile? The LineRenderer has got you covered. Learn more by visiting [Unity's LineRenderer Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer.html).

@highrise/global/LineRenderer.documentation:
Have you ever wanted to draw lines in your Unity game? Maybe you're creating a laser beam, a route, or even a spider's web. If so, the LineRenderer class is just the tool you need! The LineRenderer class in Unity enables developers to draw a series of connected segments in your scene directly from your scripts.

LineRenderer is immensely versatile and can be used for almost anything that requires a dynamic line. You can customize the line's appearance using various properties like width, color, and texture. In addition, you can precisely control the line's shape by defining the points that the LineRenderer passes through.

Want to create a glowing neon trail in a dark room? Or the trajectory of a projectile? The LineRenderer has got you covered. Learn more by visiting [Unity's LineRenderer Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer.html).

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.SetPos.documentation: The 'SetPosition' method allows you to manually set the position of any point along the line. This is important for defining the line's shape. More information can be found on [Unity's LineRenderer.SetPosition Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer.SetPosition.html).

params.name: index
params.documentation: The index of the position to be modified.

params.name: position
params.documentation: The new position for the specified point along the line.

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.GetPos.documentation: The 'GetPosition' method retrieves the position of a particular point along the line, helping in understanding and debugging the line's shape. Visit [Unity's LineRenderer.GetPosition Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer.GetPosition.html) for further insight.

params.name: index
params.documentation: The index of the position to retrieve.

returns.documentation: Returns the current position of the specified point on the line.

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.Simpli.documentation: The 'Simplify' method simplifies the shape of the line using the Ramer-Douglas-Peucker algorithm, reducing the number of vertices on the line. This can help to decrease rendering cost. See [Unity's LineRenderer.Simplify Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer.Simplify.html) for more information.

params.name: tolerance
params.documentation: The maximum allowed error when simplifying the line.

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.BakeMe.documentation: The 'BakeMesh' method allows you to create a static Mesh from the line. This could be extremely useful for saving the state of a line, or for use in other Mesh-based systems. More details can be found on [Unity's LineRenderer.BakeMesh Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer.BakeMesh.html).

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.startW.documentation: The 'startWidth' property controls the width at the start of the line. Changing this value will make the beginning of the line wider or narrower. Check out [Unity's LineRenderer.startWidth Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer-startWidth.html).

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.endWid.documentation: The 'endWidth' property works similar to 'startWidth', but it controls the width at the end of the line, effectively determining the tapering of the line. More details at [Unity's LineRenderer.endWidth Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer-endWidth.html).

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.widthM.documentation: The 'widthMultiplier' property multiplies the width of the line by a certain factor, effectively scaling the whole line's width. Visit [Unity's LineRenderer.widthMultiplier Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer-widthMultiplier.html).

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.numCor.documentation: The 'numCornerVertices' property influences how many vertices are created when the line bends at a corner. It comes in handy when designing smoother or sharper corners. More information can be found in [Unity's LineRenderer.numCornerVertices Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer-numCornerVertices.html).

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.numCap.documentation: The 'numCapVertices' property dictates how many vertices are used to form the end cap of the line, controlling how rounded the end of a line appears. Check the [Unity's LineRenderer.numCapVertices Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer-numCapVertices.html).

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.useWor.documentation: The 'useWorldSpace' property allows the line to move along with the GameObject if set to false, else the line will be drawn in the global space. Visit [Unity's LineRenderer.useWorldSpace Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer-useWorldSpace.html).

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.loop.documentation: The 'loop' property, when set to true, connects the start and end of the line, forming a continuous loop. Check [Unity's LineRenderer.loop Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer-loop.html) for more details.

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.startC.documentation: The 'startColor' property defines the color at the start of the line. You can achieve cool gradient effects by having different start and end colors. See [Unity's LineRenderer.startColor Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer-startColor.html).

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.endCol.documentation: The 'endColor' property modifies the color at the end of the line. Like 'startColor', this can help to create colorful gradients on your line. Check [Unity's LineRenderer.endColor Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer-endColor.html).

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.positi.documentation: The 'positionCount' property is used to indicate how many vertices the line has, effectively defining the line's complexity. More in [Unity's LineRenderer.positionCount Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer-positionCount.html).

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.textur.documentation: The 'textureScale' property affects how often a texture is repeated along the line. Check [Unity's LineRenderer.textureScale Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer-textureScale.html) for more details.

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.shadow.documentation: The 'shadowBias' helps in eliminating undesired lines by tweaking the rendering of shadows. More details are available in [Unity's LineRenderer.shadowBias Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer-shadowBias.html).

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.genera.documentation: The 'generateLightingData' property decides whether or not to generate lighting data for the line. Check the [Unity's LineRenderer.generateLightingData Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer-generateLightingData.html) for more insights.

@highrise/globaltype/LineRenderer.widthC.documentation: With 'widthCurve', you can apply a complex pattern to the variation of width along the line. It essentially provides you a powerful tool to craft the line's width to your desire. You can find more details in [Unity's LineRenderer.widthCurve Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LineRenderer-widthCurve.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Screen.documentation: Provides functionalities to control and query properties of the game screen, such as dimensions, pixel density, fullscreen mode, safe areas, sleep timeout, and brightness adjustment.

@highrise/global/Screen.documentation: Provides functionalities to control and query properties of the game screen, such as dimensions, pixel density, fullscreen mode, safe areas, sleep timeout, and brightness adjustment.

@highrise/globaltype/ScreenType.width.documentation: Retrieves the current width of the game screen in pixels. Can be used to adjust the game's layout based on the screen's width.
@highrise/globaltype/ScreenType.width.code_sample:
local width = Screen.width
  print("Screen width: " .. width)

@highrise/globaltype/ScreenType.height.documentation: Retrieves the current height of the game screen in pixels. Can be used to adjust the game's layout based on the screen's height.
@highrise/globaltype/ScreenType.height.code_sample:
local height = Screen.height
  print("Screen height: " .. height)

@highrise/globaltype/ScreenType.dpi.documentation: Provides the current screen resolution in dots per inch. Can be used to adjust the game's layout based on the screen's pixel density.
@highrise/globaltype/ScreenType.dpi.code_sample:
local dpi = Screen.dpi
  print("Screen DPI: " .. dpi)

@highrise/globaltype/ScreenType.fullScre.documentation: Controls whether the game is displayed in fullscreen mode. When set to `true`, the game occupies the entire screen.

@highrise/globaltype/ScreenType.safeArea.documentation: Gives a rectangle excluding certain areas of the screen like notches or taskbars. Can be used to adjust the game's layout based on the safe area.
@highrise/globaltype/ScreenType.safeArea.code_sample:
local safeArea = Screen.safeArea
  print("Safe area: " .. safeArea)

@highrise/globaltype/ScreenType.sleepTim.documentation: Sets a timeout after which the device's screen will go to sleep.

@highrise/globaltype/ScreenType.brightne.documentation: Adjusts the brightness of the game screen. The value ranges from 0 to 1, where 0 is the darkest and 1 is the brightest.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.documentation:
In the realm of Unity 3D game development, the 'Mesh' class is a fundamentally important tool. It's like the nuts and bolts enabling the creation and modification of graphical meshes - the fundamental building blocks of 3D modeling. The Mesh class is what shapes the tangible elements of your game, giving form to everything from the detailed terrain of a sprawling landscape, to the intricate contours of characters and objects.

The distinguishing feature of the 'Mesh' class is its proficient control over vertex transformations, empowering developers to fine-tune the look and feel of their 3D models down to the minutest detail. Whether you're crafting the subtle curve of a racing car, the rough crags of a mountain range, or the smooth surface of a futuristic gadget, the Mesh class is the instrument of such creation.

For a comprehensive understanding of the 'Mesh' class, the [official Unity Mesh Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.html) expands on how this essential tool is crucial in creating immersive and visually rewarding 3D game environments.

@highrise/global/Mesh.documentation:
In the realm of Unity 3D game development, the 'Mesh' class is a fundamentally important tool. It's like the nuts and bolts enabling the creation and modification of graphical meshes - the fundamental building blocks of 3D modeling. The Mesh class is what shapes the tangible elements of your game, giving form to everything from the detailed terrain of a sprawling landscape, to the intricate contours of characters and objects.

The distinguishing feature of the 'Mesh' class is its proficient control over vertex transformations, empowering developers to fine-tune the look and feel of their 3D models down to the minutest detail. Whether you're crafting the subtle curve of a racing car, the rough crags of a mountain range, or the smooth surface of a futuristic gadget, the Mesh class is the instrument of such creation.

For a comprehensive understanding of the 'Mesh' class, the [official Unity Mesh Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.html) expands on how this essential tool is crucial in creating immersive and visually rewarding 3D game environments.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.GetVertexBuffe.documentation: The 'GetVertexBufferStride' method retrieves the byte size of one vertex in a vertex buffer. Information like this can be useful for advanced manipulation of Graphics APIs. Learn more in [Unity's Mesh.GetVertexBufferStride Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.GetVertexBufferStride.html).

params.name: stream
params.documentation: The index of the vertex buffer we are querying.

returns.documentation: The size of one vertex in bytes.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.ClearBlendShap.documentation: The 'ClearBlendShapes' method deletes all blend shapes from the Mesh object. This might be useful in cases where you need to redefine the blend shapes on an existing Mesh object. Visit [Unity's Mesh.ClearBlendShapes Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.ClearBlendShapes.html) to learn more.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.GetBlendShapeN.documentation: 'GetBlendShapeName' is a method that retrieves the name of a blend shape based on its index. This could be useful when rearranging or altering blend shapes programmatically. Refer to [Unity's Mesh.GetBlendShapeName Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.GetBlendShapeName.html) for more info.

params.name: shapeIndex
params.documentation: The index of the blend shape to get the name of.

returns.documentation: The name of the blend shape.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.GetBlendShapeI.documentation: 'GetBlendShapeIndex' method fetches the index of a blend shape given its name. This is useful when you need to manipulate blend shapes but only know their names. [Unity's Mesh.GetBlendShapeIndex Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.GetBlendShapeIndex.html) provides more details.

params.name: blendShapeName
params.documentation: The name of the blend shape to get the index of.

returns.documentation: The index of the blend shape.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.GetBlendShapeF.documentation: 'GetBlendShapeFrameCount' retrieves the number of frames in a blend shape of a given index. BlendShape frames are points of transition in blend shape animation sequences. Learn how to use this method in [Unity's Mesh.GetBlendShapeFrameCount Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.GetBlendShapeFrameCount.html).

params.name: shapeIndex
params.documentation: The index of the blend shape to retrieve the frame count from.

returns.documentation: The number of frames in the blend shape.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.GetBlendShapeF.documentation: 'GetBlendShapeFrameWeight' method returns the weight of a specific frame given the indices of blend shape and frame. BlendShape weights determine the influence of a BlendShape in the final outcome. Refer to [Unity's Mesh.GetBlendShapeFrameWeight Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.GetBlendShapeFrameWeight.html) for more details.

params.name: shapeIndex
params.documentation: The index of the blend shape to retrieve the weight from.

params.name: frameIndex
params.documentation: The index of the frame to retrieve the weight from.

returns.documentation: The weight of the frame in the blend shape.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.MarkModified.documentation: The 'MarkModified' method explicitly marks the Mesh as modified, which can be used to trigger certain updates. This is used mainly to optimize drawing by helping Unity understand what needs to be redrawn. Learn more about it in [Unity's Mesh.MarkModified Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.MarkModified.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.GetUVDistribut.documentation: 'GetUVDistributionMetric' is a method that provides a UV metric for the Mesh, which is a key consideration for texture mapping and related operations. [Find out more in this Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.GetUVDistributionMetric.html).

params.name: uvSetIndex
params.documentation: The index of the UV set whose distribution metric should be retrieved.

returns.documentation: The UV distribution metric for the specified UV set.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.GetIndexStart.documentation: 'GetIndexStart' is a method that returns the start index of a specific submesh. This is useful when looping through individual submeshes in a Mesh object. More information is available in [Unity's Mesh.GetIndexStart Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.GetIndexStart.html).

params.name: submesh
params.documentation: The index of the submesh to get the start index of.

returns.documentation: The start index for the specified submesh.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.GetIndexCount.documentation: 'GetIndexCount' gets the total number of indices in a specific submesh. This information can be helpful when altering the geometry of submeshes. See [Unity's Mesh.GetIndexCount Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.GetIndexCount.html) for additional insights.

params.name: submesh
params.documentation: The index of the submesh to get the index count of.

returns.documentation: The number of indices in the given submesh.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.GetBaseVertex.documentation: 'GetBaseVertex' is a method that retrieves the base vertex of a specific submesh. This can be useful when you're manipulating vertices at a low level, for example, in some procedural generation algorithms. [Unity's Mesh.GetBaseVertex Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.GetBaseVertex.html) provides more details.

params.name: submesh
params.documentation: The index of the submesh to get the base vertex of.

returns.documentation: The base vertex of the specified submesh.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.Clear.documentation: 'Clear' method removes all vertex and index data from the Mesh. It's useful for cleaning up Meshes or if you need to rebuild a Mesh from scratch. Learn how to use the Clear(keepVertexLayout) method effectively in [Unity's Mesh.Clear Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.Clear.html).

params.name: keepVertexLayout
params.documentation: Specifies whether to keep original layout of the vertex buffer.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.RecalculateBou.documentation: The 'RecalculateBounds' method recalculates the bounding volume of the Mesh from the vertices. This is useful when modifications have been made to the vertex positions and the bounding volume needs to be updated. More can be found out in [Unity's Mesh.RecalculateBounds Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.RecalculateBounds.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.RecalculateNor.documentation: The 'RecalculateNormals' method recomputes the normals of the Mesh from the vertices and triangles. This is useful when changes are made to vertex positions and the normals need to correspond to the new shape. Find more details in [Unity's Mesh.RecalculateNormals Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.RecalculateNormals.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.RecalculateTan.documentation: 'RecalculateTangents' is a method that recalculates the tangents of the Mesh, which are used in normal mapping and other techniques. It's most useful when changes have been made to the vertex positions or texture coordinates and the tangents need to be updated. More can be learned from [Unity's Mesh.RecalculateTangents Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.RecalculateTangents.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.RecalculateUVD.documentation: The 'RecalculateUVDistributionMetric' method recalculates the UV distribution metric for a specified UV set. This helps bring uniformity to the UV mapping which prevents texture distortion. Learn more in [Unity's Mesh.RecalculateUVDistributionMetric Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.RecalculateUVDistributionMetric.html).

params.name: uvSetIndex
params.documentation: The index of the UV set to recalculate the distribution metric for.

params.name: uvAreaThreshold
params.documentation: The area threshold to consider in the UV recalculations.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.RecalculateUVD.documentation: The 'RecalculateUVDistributionMetrics' method recalculates UV distribution metrics. It improves texture quality by reducing distortions in the mapping from texture space to 3D. Learn about its usage in [Unity's Mesh.RecalculateUVDistributionMetrics Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.RecalculateUVDistributionMetrics.html).

params.name: uvAreaThreshold
params.documentation: A threshold that defines what should be considered in the UV recalculations.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.MarkDynamic.documentation: The 'MarkDynamic' method marks the Mesh as dynamic, hinting the engine that this Mesh will be updated frequently. This speeds up certain operations but uses slightly more memory. To learn more, refer to [Unity's Mesh.MarkDynamic Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.MarkDynamic.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.UploadMeshData.documentation: 'UploadMeshData' uploads Mesh data to the GPU, making it available for rendering. It's crucial when creating procedural Meshes that need to be drawn in the scene. To know more, see [Unity's Mesh.UploadMeshData Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.UploadMeshData.html).

params.name: markNoLongerReadable
params.documentation: Whether to mark the data as not readable by scripts after the upload.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.Optimize.documentation: The 'Optimize' method optimizes the Mesh for rendering according to its usage patterns. This includes operations like reordering vertices and triangles for better vertex cache utilization. Learn more from [Unity's Mesh.Optimize Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.Optimize.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.OptimizeIndexB.documentation: 'OptimizeIndexBuffers' optimizes the index buffers of the Mesh. This reduces the size of the index buffer and speeds up rendering. Visit [Unity's Mesh.OptimizeIndexBuffers Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.OptimizeIndexBuffers.html) to learn more about this method.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.OptimizeReorde.documentation: The 'OptimizeReorderVertexBuffer' method optimizes the vertex buffer of the Mesh. This improves memory usage and rendering performance. More information on how this method operates can be found in [Unity's Mesh.OptimizeReorderVertexBuffer Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh.OptimizeReorderVertexBuffer.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.new.documentation: The 'new' method is invoked to create a new instance of the Mesh class. Its main use is to generate a Mesh object which can then be filled with custom data and applied to a GameObject. More details in [Unity's Mesh.new Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh-ctor.html).

returns.documentation: Returns a new instance of the Mesh class.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.vertexBufferCo.documentation: The 'vertexBufferCount' property holds the count of vertex buffers, which are containers for all vertex related data like positions, normals, UVs etc, in a Mesh object. More details about it are in [Unity's Mesh.vertexBufferCount Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh-vertexBufferCount.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.blendShapeCoun.documentation: The 'blendShapeCount' property keeps track of the number of blend shapes found within a Mesh object. Blend shapes allow for smooth transitions between different facial expressions or body positions. Refer to [Unity's Mesh.blendShapeCount Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh-blendShapeCount.html) for more details.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.bindposeCount.documentation: The 'bindposeCount' property gives the count of bind poses, which are transformations determining how Meshes move with joints, in a Mesh object. To learn more about this property, check [Unity's Mesh.bindposeCount Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh-bindposeCount.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.isReadable.documentation: The 'isReadable' property informs whether the Mesh data is available for reading by scripting. For instance, you may want this to be true if you're creating procedural Meshes. Learn how to use this property effectively in [Unity's Mesh.isReadable Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh-isReadable.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.vertexCount.documentation: The 'vertexCount' property allows you to retrieve the amount of vertices present in the Mesh object. It's helpful for debugging or when performing operations on every vertex. More info can be found in [Unity's Mesh.vertexCount Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh-vertexCount.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.subMeshCount.documentation: The 'subMeshCount' property provides the number of submeshes in a Mesh object. Submeshes can be useful when you want to apply different materials to different parts of a Mesh. Visit [Unity's Mesh.subMeshCount Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh-subMeshCount.html) for more about this property.

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.bounds.documentation: The 'bounds' property represents the axis-aligned bounding box of the Mesh in its local space (i.e., not affected by the transform). This can be useful for things like collision detection and visibility testing. Learn more from [Unity's Mesh.bounds Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh-bounds.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Mesh.vertexAttribut.documentation: The 'vertexAttributeCount' property gives the count of vertex attributes like positions, normals, tangents, colors, and texture coordinates in the Mesh. To know more about these, see [Unity's Mesh.vertexAttributeCount Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Mesh-vertexAttributeCount.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Value.documentation: In games, we often want clients to inform servers that the state of certain data has changed and have every other client be informed of that state change. Maybe a door has been opened or a score has increased. This base class is the common ancestor of all other Values like Class.Vector3Value and Class.NumberValue that allow you to specifically track a single variable as one that all clients should be synchronized on.

@highrise/global/Value.documentation: In games, we often want clients to inform servers that the state of certain data has changed and have every other client be informed of that state change. Maybe a door has been opened or a score has increased. This base class is the common ancestor of all other Values like Class.Vector3Value and Class.NumberValue that allow you to specifically track a single variable as one that all clients should be synchronized on.

@highrise/globaltype/Value.parent.documentation: The 'parent' property is used to access the parent of the object. This is always the owning script of the object as a LuaBehaviour.

@highrise/globaltype/Value.Changed.documentation:
An event that is triggered when the value of the object changes. This is useful for when you want to trigger an action that should be performed when the value of the object changes.

NOTE: Changed will occur the moment a client joins the server, that way they can be synchronized with the current state of the variable from the server.

@highrise/globaltype/PressEvent.documentation: Event sent when a press gesture has been recognized by a GestureRecognizer

@highrise/global/PressEvent.documentation: Event sent when a press gesture has been recognized by a GestureRecognizer

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.documentation:
The ParticleSystem class in Unity allows you to create visually complex and dynamic simulations like fire, smoke, or a flock of birds. From sparks flying in a firefight to the delicate dust particles in a sunbeam, particle systems bring a game to life.

At its core, a ParticleSystem shoots out particles in a certain direction and for a certain duration, but there's much more to it than that. You can control over a wide range of properties like the color, size, and shape of the particles, the speed and direction of their emission, and their behavior over their lifetime.

Want to have physics applied to your particles or intricate collisions? That's possible too. Given its scalability and rich feature set, ParticleSystem is a powerful tool for adding atmospheric and stylistic flair to your game.

To understand how to use ParticleSystem to its full potential, refer to [Unity's ParticleSystem Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem.html).

@highrise/global/ParticleSystem.documentation:
The ParticleSystem class in Unity allows you to create visually complex and dynamic simulations like fire, smoke, or a flock of birds. From sparks flying in a firefight to the delicate dust particles in a sunbeam, particle systems bring a game to life.

At its core, a ParticleSystem shoots out particles in a certain direction and for a certain duration, but there's much more to it than that. You can control over a wide range of properties like the color, size, and shape of the particles, the speed and direction of their emission, and their behavior over their lifetime.

Want to have physics applied to your particles or intricate collisions? That's possible too. Given its scalability and rich feature set, ParticleSystem is a powerful tool for adding atmospheric and stylistic flair to your game.

To understand how to use ParticleSystem to its full potential, refer to [Unity's ParticleSystem Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem.html).

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.Stop.documentation: The 'Stop' method halts the emission of particles, providing the option to stop instantaneously or let live particles die out naturally. Extremely helpful in controlling the lifecycle of particle emissions. See [Unity's ParticleSystem.Stop Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem.Stop.html) for finer details.

params.name: includeChildren
params.documentation: Should the method affect all children of this Particle System?

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.Simu.documentation: The 'Simulate' method advances the simulation of the ParticleSystem by the given number of seconds. It's particularly useful when creating effects that happen instantly, rather than over time. Visit [Unity's ParticleSystem.Simulate Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem.Simulate.html).

params.name: t
params.documentation: The number of seconds to advance the Particle System simulation by.

params.name: withChildren
params.documentation: Should the simulation include all children of this Particle System?

params.name: restart
params.documentation: Should the Particle System be restarted before the simulation is run?

params.name: fixedTimeStep
params.documentation: Should Unity simulate each individual time step for the full duration of 't'?

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.Play.documentation: To restart the Particle System or resume it after a pause, use the 'Play' method. It includes an optional parameter to include all child systems. Read more at [Unity's ParticleSystem.Play Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem.Play.html).

params.name: withChildren
params.documentation: Should the play request be propagated to all child systems?

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.Paus.documentation: The 'Pause' method halts the simulation of the Particle System in its current state. It can be resumed later using the Play method. More details in [Unity's ParticleSystem.Pause Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem.Pause.html).

params.name: withChildren
params.documentation: Should the pause request apply to all child systems?

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.Clea.documentation: The 'Clear' method removes all particles in the Particle System. It's a handy way to reset the Particle System to an empty state. Check [Unity's ParticleSystem.Clear Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem.Clear.html) for more details.

params.name: withChildren
params.documentation: Should the clear request include all child systems?

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.IsAl.documentation: The 'IsAlive' method lets you know if the ParticleSystem is still alive, meaning if it is still emitting particles or any of its particles are still alive. Allows for decision-making based on Particle System's state of activity. More info at [Unity's ParticleSystem.IsAlive Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem.IsAlive.html).

params.name: withChildren
params.documentation: Should the check include all child systems?

returns.documentation: Returns true if the ParticleSystem is still alive.

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.Emit.documentation: The 'Emit' method allows you to create new particles, emits the specified amount instantly. Useful to create a burst of particles at a particular time. [Unity's ParticleSystem.Emit Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem.Emit.html) provides more details.

params.name: count
params.documentation: The number of particles to emit.

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.Trig.documentation: The 'TriggerSubEmitter' method triggers all sub-emitters on this Particle System, which means it starts their emission. Sub-Emitter allows to spawn new particles based on the state or behaviour of a particle in the parent system. More details are available in [Unity's ParticleSystem.TriggerSubEmitter Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem.TriggerSubEmitter.html).

params.name: subEmitterIndex
params.documentation: The index of the sub-emitter in the ParticleSystem's sub-emitters list.

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.Allo.documentation: The 'AllocateAxisOfRotationAttribute' method allocates particle attribute data for storing a separate axis of rotation per particle. Check the [Unity's ParticleSystem.AllocateAxisOfRotationAttribute Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem.AllocateAxisOfRotationAttribute.html) for further information.

The 'AllocateMeshIndexAttribute' method allows for particle attribute data allocation to store a separate mesh index per particle. Visit [Unity's ParticleSystem.AllocateMeshIndexAttribute Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem.AllocateMeshIndexAttribute.html).

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystemType..documentation: The 'ResetPreMappedBufferMemory' method resets the pre-allocated memory used to store particle data for external read/write access. More information is available at [Unity's ParticleSystem.ResetPreMappedBufferMemory Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem.ResetPreMappedBufferMemory.html).

The 'SetMaximumPreMappedBufferCounts' method allows you to set the maximum buffer sizes for pre-mapped fixed buffers. Useful for optimizing memory usage. You can refer to [Unity's ParticleSystem.SetMaximumPreMappedBufferCounts Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem.SetMaximumPreMappedBufferCounts.html) for more details.

params.name: vertexBuffersCount
params.documentation: The maximum number of vertex buffers.

params.name: indexBuffersCount
params.documentation: The maximum number of index buffers.

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.isPl.documentation: The 'isPlaying' property tells you if the ParticleSystem is currently playing. It's helpful to alter behavior based on the state of the ParticleSystem. Check out [Unity's ParticleSystem.isPlaying Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem-isPlaying.html).

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.isEm.documentation: The 'isEmitting' property helps you to determine if the ParticleSystem is currently emitting particles. This can be particularly useful for performance optimization. See [Unity's ParticleSystem.isEmitting Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem-isEmitting.html).

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.isSt.documentation: The 'isStopped' property indicates whether the ParticleSystem has been stopped, thereby not emitting particles. It's ideal for enabling/disabling other game features based on Particle System's activity. More information in [Unity's ParticleSystem.isStopped Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem-isStopped.html).

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.isPa.documentation: The 'isPaused' property signifies whether the ParticleSystem is currently paused or not. This can give you finer control over the game flow based on the ParticleSystem's state. Consult [Unity's ParticleSystem.isPaused Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem-isPaused.html) for details.

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.part.documentation: The 'particleCount' property provides the current number of particles in the ParticleSystem, which is useful for performance tuning and diagnostics. Refer to [Unity's ParticleSystem.particleCount Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem-particleCount.html).

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.time.documentation: The 'time' property returns how long the Particle System has been playing. It's particularly useful when you need to trigger events based on the playback time of your Particle System. More details at [Unity's ParticleSystem.time Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem-time.html).

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.tota.documentation: The 'totalTime' property reflects the total lifetime of the Particle System in seconds. It's beneficial for initiating actions once the Particle System has ended. Check [Unity's ParticleSystem.totalTime Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem-totalTime.html).

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.rand.documentation: The 'randomSeed' property allows you to seed the random number generator for reproducible effects. This can be beneficial for creating predictable visual effects. More at [Unity's ParticleSystem.randomSeed Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem-randomSeed.html).

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.useA.documentation: The 'useAutoRandomSeed' property, when set to true, lets Unity automatically generate a random seed allowing different effect each time. For more insights, check [Unity's ParticleSystem.useAutoRandomSeed Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem-useAutoRandomSeed.html).

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.proc.documentation: The 'proceduralSimulationSupported' property indicates whether procedural simulation is supported on the Particle System. If supported, you can manipulate the Particle System without the overhead of enabling it. For further details, visit [Unity's ParticleSystem.proceduralSimulationSupported Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem-proceduralSimulationSupported.html).

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.has3.documentation: The 'has3DParticleRotations' property tells you if any particles in the Particle System have 3D rotations. Useful for optimizing processing when 3D rotations are not needed. Detailed info at [Unity's ParticleSystem.has3DParticleRotations Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem-has3DParticleRotations.html).

@highrise/globaltype/ParticleSystem.hasN.documentation: The 'hasNonUniformParticleSizes' property indicates whether the Particle System contains particles of non-uniform sizes. When true, this could influence specific rendering techniques. Check [Unity's ParticleSystem.hasNonUniformParticleSizes Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/ParticleSystem-hasNonUniformParticleSizes.html) for more information.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.documentation: The Animator class is a core component in Unity for managing animations. It works with the Animator Controller to manage states and transitions in a state machine, enabling complex animation setups. This class provides a variety of methods and properties to control animations on GameObjects, essential for dynamic and interactive game environments.

@highrise/global/Animator.documentation: The Animator class is a core component in Unity for managing animations. It works with the Animator Controller to manage states and transitions in a state machine, enabling complex animation setups. This class provides a variety of methods and properties to control animations on GameObjects, essential for dynamic and interactive game environments.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.GetFloat.documentation: Retrieves a float parameter from the Animator.

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the parameter to retrieve.

returns.documentation: The float value of the specified parameter.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.SetFloat.documentation: Sets the value of a float parameter.

params.name: name
params.documentation: Name of the parameter.

params.name: value
params.documentation: The value to be set.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.GetBool.documentation: Retrieves the value of a boolean parameter in the Animator.

params.name: name
params.documentation: Name of the parameter.

returns.documentation: The current state (true or false) of the specified parameter.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.SetBool.documentation: Sets the value of a boolean parameter in the Animator.

params.name: name
params.documentation: Name of the parameter.

params.name: value
params.documentation: The value to be set.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.GetInteger.documentation: Fetches the value of an integer parameter in the Animator.

params.name: name
params.documentation: Name of the parameter.

returns.documentation: The current state of the specified parameter.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.SetInteger.documentation: Assigns an integer value to an integer parameter in the Animator.

params.name: name
params.documentation: Name of the parameter.

params.name: value
params.documentation: The value to be set.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.SetTrigger.documentation: Activates a trigger parameter to change the animator's state.

params.name: name
params.documentation: Name of the trigger parameter.

params.name: name
params.documentation: Name of the trigger parameter to reset.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.IsParamete.documentation: Checks if a parameter is controlled by a curve.

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the parameter to check.

returns.documentation: True if the parameter is controlled by a curve, false otherwise.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.SetLookAtP.documentation: Sets a target position for the character's head to look at.

params.name: lookAtPosition
params.documentation: Position for the character to look at.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.SetLookAtW.documentation: Sets the weights for the head and body parts to look at a position.

params.name: weight
params.documentation: The weight by which the body parts follow the lookAtPosition.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.GetLayerNa.documentation: Retrieves the name of a layer by its index.

params.name: layerIndex
params.documentation: The index of the layer.

returns.documentation: The name of the layer.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.GetLayerIn.documentation: Finds the index of a layer by its name.

params.name: layerName
params.documentation: The name of the layer.

returns.documentation: The index of the layer.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.GetLayerWe.documentation: Gets the weight of a layer, defining its influence on the final animation.

params.name: layerIndex
params.documentation: The index of the layer.

returns.documentation: The weight of the layer.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.SetLayerWe.documentation: Sets the weight of a layer, adjusting its influence on the final animation outcome.

params.name: layerIndex
params.documentation: The index of the layer.

params.name: weight
params.documentation: The weight to set for the layer.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.GetCurrent.documentation: Returns the count of AnimatorClipInfo instances for the current layer.

params.name: layerIndex
params.documentation: The index of the layer.

returns.documentation: The count of AnimatorClipInfo instances.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.GetNextAni.documentation: Gets the count of AnimatorClipInfo for the next layer the animator will transition to.

params.name: layerIndex
params.documentation: The index of the layer.

returns.documentation: The count of AnimatorClipInfo instances for the next layer.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.IsInTransi.documentation: Checks if the animator is in a transition between animations in the state machine.

params.name: layerIndex
params.documentation: The index of the layer.

returns.documentation: True if the animator is in transition, false otherwise.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.InterruptM.documentation: Interrupts automatic target matching, allowing manual control.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.CrossFadeI.documentation: Gradually blends from the current animation to another over a fixed time.

params.name: stateName
params.documentation: The name of the state to transition to.

params.name: fixedTransitionDuration
params.documentation: The duration of the transition.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.WriteDefau.documentation: Writes default values to the Animator, resetting runtime modifications.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.CrossFade.documentation: Transitions from the current state to another over a relative duration.

params.name: stateName
params.documentation: The name of the state.

params.name: normalizedTransitionDuration
params.documentation: Duration of the transition relative to animation length.

params.name: layer
params.documentation: Index of the layer.

params.name: normalizedTimeOffset
params.documentation: Adjusts the starting point of the transition.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.PlayInFixe.documentation: Plays an animation state at a specified time scale, unaffected by Animator speed.

params.name: stateName
params.documentation: The name of the state to play.

params.name: layer
params.documentation: The layer index.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.Play.documentation: Plays an animation state, allowing direct control over animation playback.

params.name: stateName
params.documentation: The name of the state.

params.name: layer
params.documentation: The layer index.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.StartPlayb.documentation: Begins animator playback mode, useful for testing Animator functionality.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.StopPlayba.documentation: Stops animator playback mode initiated by StartPlayback.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.StartRecor.documentation: Starts recording the Animator in play mode for analysis or replaying sequences.

params.name: frameCount
params.documentation: Number of frames to record.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.StopRecord.documentation: Stops recording started by StartRecording, controlling recording duration.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.HasState.documentation: Checks if a specific state exists within a layer of the Animator.

params.name: layerIndex
params.documentation: The index of the layer.

params.name: stateID
params.documentation: The ID of the state to check for existence.

returns.documentation: True if the state exists in the specified layer, false otherwise.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.Update.documentation: Manually advances the Animator state machine by a specified amount of time.

params.name: deltaTime
params.documentation: The amount of time to advance the state machine.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.Rebind.documentation: Resets the Animator to its default state, removing all runtime modifications.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.ApplyBuilt.documentation: Applies built-in root motion from animation clips, if present.

@highrise/globaltype/AnimatorType.String.documentation: Converts a string into a hash ID for efficient parameter identification.

params.name: name
params.documentation: The string to convert into a hash ID.

returns.documentation: The hash ID of the string.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.isOptimiza.documentation: Indicates if the Animator can be optimized for performance.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.isHuman.documentation: Checks if the Animator controls a humanoid model.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.hasRootMot.documentation: Determines if the Animator's animation data contains root motion.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.humanScale.documentation: Provides the scale of the humanoid Avatar in meters.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.isInitiali.documentation: Checks if the Animator is initialized and ready to control animations.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.deltaPosit.documentation: Returns the GameObject's position change during the last frame.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.deltaRotat.documentation: Provides the rotation difference of the GameObject during the last frame.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.velocity.documentation: Gives the velocity vector of the GameObject controlled by the Animator.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.angularVel.documentation: Returns the angular velocity vector of the GameObject.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.rootPositi.documentation: Provides the position of the root of the GameObject controlled by the Animator.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.rootRotati.documentation: Offers the rotation of the root of the GameObject controlled by the Animator.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.applyRootM.documentation: Controls whether root motion in animations should be applied to the GameObject.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.hasTransfo.documentation: Indicates if the Animator has a transform hierarchy.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.gravityWei.documentation: Represents the gravity weight based on current animations being played.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.bodyPositi.documentation: Allows getting or setting the position of the body mass.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.bodyRotati.documentation: Lets you get or set the rotation of the body mass.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.stabilizeF.documentation: Controls feet stabilization for plant and IK feet.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.layerCount.documentation: Represents the total number of layers within the Animator.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.parameterC.documentation: Pertains to the count of parameters in the Animator Controller.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.feetPivotA.documentation: A blend variable for calculating the position of each foot during a transition.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.pivotWeigh.documentation: Indicates the current weight of the pivot, as determined by foot animations.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.pivotPosit.documentation: Offers the current position of the pivot in the avatar root, relative to world space.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.isMatching.documentation: Indicates whether the character is currently matching a target via script.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.speed.documentation: Allows manipulation of the Animator's playback speed.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.targetPosi.documentation: Gets the target position for the MatchTarget function.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.targetRota.documentation: Fetches the target rotation for the MatchTarget function.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.avatarRoot.documentation: Refers to the root Transform of the humanoid Avatar in the animator.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.playbackTi.documentation: Gets the current playback time of the Animator recorder.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.recorderSt.documentation: Represents the start time of the first frame of the Animator recorder.
Provides the stop time of the last frame of the Animator recorder.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.hasBoundPl.documentation: Indicates whether any playable graphs are attached to the Animator.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.layersAffe.documentation: Controls whether the mass center is affected by all layers or only the base layer.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.leftFeetBo.documentation: Provides the position of the bottom of the left foot relative to the root.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.rightFeetB.documentation: Represents the position of the bottom of the right foot relative to the root.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.logWarning.documentation: Controls whether warnings are logged for issues with AnimatorController setup.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.fireEvents.documentation: Dictates whether the Animator is allowed to emit events.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.keepAnimat.documentation: Keeps the current Animator state and its time when the GameObject is disabled.

@highrise/globaltype/Animator.writeDefau.documentation: Writes default values into the GameObject when the animator component is disabled.

@highrise/globaltype/GameClient.documentation:
In Highrise's scripting environment, the GameClient class acts as the high-level game context the script is running in. Any client-level interaction or manipulation will be found in this class. Specifically, scripts marked 'Client' or 'Client and Server' can access client - with 'Client and Server' requiring you to check if `client` is not nil (or `server` is nil).

The GameClient is essential for managing critical client-specific activities, such as identifying the local player or the main camera. It also enables responding to events like the connection and disconnection of players during gameplay.

It stands as the bridge between local operations and the expansive game environment, providing a hassle-free way to tap into and manage client-side functionalities.

@highrise/global/GameClient.documentation:
In Highrise's scripting environment, the GameClient class acts as the high-level game context the script is running in. Any client-level interaction or manipulation will be found in this class. Specifically, scripts marked 'Client' or 'Client and Server' can access client - with 'Client and Server' requiring you to check if `client` is not nil (or `server` is nil).

The GameClient is essential for managing critical client-specific activities, such as identifying the local player or the main camera. It also enables responding to events like the connection and disconnection of players during gameplay.

It stands as the bridge between local operations and the expansive game environment, providing a hassle-free way to tap into and manage client-side functionalities.

@highrise/globaltype/GameClient.localPla.documentation: This property provides a direct handle to the game's local player from the client's perspective, facilitating easy interaction and local player management.

@highrise/globaltype/GameClient.mainCame.documentation: This property helps you obtain the main camera for the game client. It fetches the first active, enabled camera tagged as "MainCamera" in the scene. If no such camera is found, it returns nil.

@highrise/globaltype/GameClient.PlayerCo.documentation: An event that is triggered when a new player gets connected to the game. This mechanism allows developers to trigger specific actions in response to a player's connection. Note that this is not when the player's Class.Avatar is spawned. For avatar spawn, see Class.Player .

@highrise/globaltype/GameClient.PlayerDi.documentation: An event that is set off when a player disconnects from the game. This feature is crucial in managing actions that follow a player's disconnection.

@highrise/globaltype/CharacterAnimation.documentation: Represents a character animation that includes animations for each side of the character.

@highrise/global/CharacterAnimation.documentation: Represents a character animation that includes animations for each side of the character.

@highrise/globaltype/UITextFieldBase.Sel.documentation: Move the cursor to the end of the text with no selection

@highrise/globaltype/UITextFieldBase.inp.documentation:
A regular expression to match valid values that can be inserted into the textfield by the user.
Invalid values will be rejected.

@highrise/globaltype/UITextFieldBase.isS.documentation:
Enables a mode in which Return key sends a ReturnEvent
and Shift+Return sends ShiftReturnEvent.

@highrise/globaltype/UITextFieldBase.mul.documentation: True if multiline editing is enabled
