@highrise/globaltype/UITextFieldBase.val.documentation: Current text value of the field

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryError.documentation: Contains possible error codes that can be returned from Inventory functions.

@highrise/global/InventoryError.documentation: Contains possible error codes that can be returned from Inventory functions.

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryErrorType..documentation: Your world is sending requests too frequently.  The limit for GetItem is 60 + (active players * 10) requests per minute.  The limit for GetItems is 10 + (active players * 5) requests per minute.  The limit for CommitTransaction and RollbackTransaction together is 10 + (active players * 2) requests per minute.
The item ID must be 128 characters or less.
The holder ID must be 128 characters or less.
The limit passed to GetItems must be 100 or less.
The cursor ID passed to GetItems was not valid.
The InventoryTransaction passed to CommitTransaction contained actions that could not be performed, such as using Take to remove more items than a player owns.
The InventoryTransaction passed to CommitTransaction must contain 32 or fewer actions.
The InventoryTransaction passed to CommitTransaction did not contain any actions.  You must call at least one of the functions of InventoryTransaction before calling CommitTransaction.
A response from the server was not received within the time limit.

@highrise/globaltype/CharacterAnimationE.documentation: We used to call it FunctionName so we are keeping this around until we can get rid of it

Override to return a view for the given index within the cells array

@highrise/globaltype/UICollectionProvide.documentation: Override to return estimated size of cell for the given index within the cells array
Override to return type of cell for the given index within the cells array

@highrise/globaltype/Anchor.documentation: Anchors enable specific actions for players upon reaching designated points in the environment, such as sitting down, standing up, or other actions.

@highrise/global/Anchor.documentation: Anchors enable specific actions for players upon reaching designated points in the environment, such as sitting down, standing up, or other actions.

@highrise/globaltype/Anchor.Entered.documentation: Called when a player enters the anchor.

@highrise/globaltype/Anchor.Exited.documentation: Called when a player exits the anchor.

@highrise/globaltype/Anchor.enterFromPos.documentation: Enters the anchor from a specific position.

@highrise/globaltype/Anchor.exitToPositi.documentation: Exits the anchor to a specific position.

@highrise/globaltype/Anchor.enterFrom.documentation: Enters the anchor from a specific transform.

@highrise/globaltype/Anchor.exitTo.documentation: Exits the anchor to a specific transform.

@highrise/globaltype/Anchor.isTappable.documentation: Returns whether the anchor is tappable.

returns.documentation: Whether the anchor is tappable.

@highrise/globaltype/PageReset.documentation: Event sent when the page is reset

@highrise/global/PageReset.documentation: Event sent when the page is reset

@highrise/globaltype/Chat.documentation: The Chat service provides functionality for creating and managing chat channels to dictate how players communicate with each other, as well as how receiving messages work in the game.

@highrise/global/Chat.documentation: The Chat service provides functionality for creating and managing chat channels to dictate how players communicate with each other, as well as how receiving messages work in the game.

@highrise/globaltype/Chat.CreateChannel.documentation: Creates a new channel. If the channel already exists, it will return the existing channel.
@highrise/globaltype/Chat.CreateChannel.code_sample:
local isGameRunning = true

local ghostChannel = Chat:CreateChannel("Ghost", true, false)
local generalChannel = Chat:CreateChannel("General", true, true)

server.PlayerConnected:Connect(function(player)
  if isGameRunning then
    Chat:AddPlayerToChannel(generalChannel, player) -- General channel is for players who are in the game
  else
    Chat:AddPlayerToChannel(ghostChannel, player) -- Ghost channel is for players who are not in the game
  end
end)

@highrise/globaltype/Chat.DestroyChannel.documentation: Destroys the given channel, removing all players from it.

@highrise/globaltype/Chat.AddPlayerToCha.documentation: Adds the given player to the given channel.
@highrise/globaltype/Chat.AddPlayerToCha.code_sample:
local channel = Chat:CreateChannel("General", true, true)

server.PlayerConnected:Connect(function(player)
  Chat:AddPlayerToChannel(channel, player)
end)

@highrise/globaltype/Chat.RemovePlayerFr.documentation: Removes the given player from the given channel.
@highrise/globaltype/Chat.RemovePlayerFr.code_sample:
local isGameRunning = true

local function ResetGame(players)
  for k, v in pairs(players) do
    Chat:RemovePlayerFromChannel(generalChannel, v)
    Chat:AddPlayerToChannel(ghostChannel, v)
  end
end

@highrise/globaltype/Chat.SetDefaultChan.documentation: Sets the default channel for the player. This will be the default channel text messages are sent to.
@highrise/globaltype/Chat.SetDefaultChan.code_sample:
local generalChannel = Chat:CreateChannel("General", true, true)

server.PlayerConnected:Connect(function(player)
  Chat:SetDefaultChannel(player, generalChannel)
end)

@highrise/globaltype/Chat.DisplayTextMes.documentation: Displays the given text message to the channel's chat log with a speech bubble over the given player's head.
@highrise/globaltype/Chat.DisplayTextMes.code_sample:
local generalChannel = Chat:CreateChannel("General", true, true)

server.PlayerConnected:Connect(function(player)
  Chat:AddPlayerToChannel(generalChannel, player)
end)

Chat.TextMessageReceivedHandler:Connect(function(channel, player, message)
  Chat:DisplayTextMessage(channel, player, message)
end)

@highrise/globaltype/Chat.allChannels.documentation: All chat channels that exist in the game.

@highrise/globaltype/Chat.allJoinedChann.documentation: All chat channels that the player has joined.

@highrise/globaltype/Chat.TextMessageRec.documentation:
An event that is fired when a client receives a text message. If this event has no connected listeners, the text message will display normally.

If you connect to this event to do custom messaging logic, use the `DisplayTextMessage` method to send the final results.

Class.ChannelInfo, Class.Player (the sender), and string are passed as the parameters.

@highrise/globaltype/Chat.WhisperReceive.documentation:
An event that is fired when a client receives a whisper. If this event has no connected listeners, the whisper will display normally.

If your game does not allow whispering at certain times or only with certain people, this event should be connected to and use the `DisplayTextMessage` method only when whispering is allowed.

Class.ChannelInfo, Class.Player (the sender), and string are passed as the parameters.
@highrise/globaltype/Chat.WhisperReceive.code_sample:
local canWhisper = false
Chat.WhisperReceivedHandler:Connect(function(channel, player, message)
  if canWhisper then
    Chat:DisplayTextMessage(channel, player, message)
  end
end)

@highrise/globaltype/Chat.PlayerJoinedCh.documentation: An event that is fired by the server to all clients in the same channel as the player that joined. Class.ChannelInfo and Class.Player are passed as the parameters.
@highrise/globaltype/Chat.PlayerJoinedCh.code_sample:
Chat.PlayerJoinedChannel:Connect(function(channel, player)
  Chat.TextMessageReceivedHandler:Connect(function(channel, player, message)
    if message == "Hello" then
      Chat:DisplayTextMessage(channel, player, "Hello, " .. player.name .. "!")
    end
  end)
end)

@highrise/globaltype/Chat.PlayerLeftChan.documentation: An event that is fired by the server to all clients in the same channel as the player that left. Class.ChannelInfo and Class.Player are passed as the parameters.

@highrise/globaltype/Chat.ChannelDestroy.documentation: An event that is fired by the server to all clients when a channel is destroyed. Class.ChannelInfo is passed as the parameter.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.documentation:
The Rigidbody component adds physical properties to an object, allowing it to react to forces and torques, making it controlled by the unity physics engine. If you want an object to be affected by gravity, for instance, or if you want to be able to apply forces to it, you would attach a Rigidbody component to it. Rigidbody also keeps track of the object's position and orientation.

One common application of Rigidbodies is for creating objects that move and interact under physics control. On the other hand, you could also use Rigidbody for objects which move kinematically or which you want to move around the world but want to avoid intersection with other Rigidbodies. For a more detailed understanding, refer to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.html).

@highrise/global/Rigidbody.documentation:
The Rigidbody component adds physical properties to an object, allowing it to react to forces and torques, making it controlled by the unity physics engine. If you want an object to be affected by gravity, for instance, or if you want to be able to apply forces to it, you would attach a Rigidbody component to it. Rigidbody also keeps track of the object's position and orientation.

One common application of Rigidbodies is for creating objects that move and interact under physics control. On the other hand, you could also use Rigidbody for objects which move kinematically or which you want to move around the world but want to avoid intersection with other Rigidbodies. For a more detailed understanding, refer to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.AddExplos.documentation: The 'AddExplosionForce' method applies a force to the Rigidbody that simulates the effect of an explosion at a given location. The force diminishes with increasing distance from the explosion source. This method can be used to create dynamic force effects in gameplay, like grenade explosions. Refer to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.AddExplosionForce.html) for more details.

params.name: explosionForce
params.documentation: The magnitude of the force of the explosion.

params.name: explosionPosition
params.documentation: The position of the explosion origin.

params.name: explosionRadius
params.documentation: The maximum distance from the explosion origin at which the explosion force is considered.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.AddForceA.documentation: The 'AddForceAtPosition' method applies a force to the Rigidbody at a specific position. Instead of applying the force through the center of mass, the force is applied at the specified position, creating a torque and causing the Rigidbody to rotate. This method is useful for creating precise scripted physics effects. For more information, refer to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.AddForceAtPosition.html).

params.name: force
params.documentation: The vector to apply as a force.

params.name: position
params.documentation: The position in world coordinates where the force is applied.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.AddRelati.documentation: The 'AddRelativeForce' method applies a force to the Rigidbody relative to its coordinate system, as opposed to world coordinates. This is useful in situations where you want an object to push forward on its local axis, or similar operation relative to the object rather than the world. The [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.AddRelativeForce.html) provides more details about force application in the local space of the Rigidbody.

params.name: force
params.documentation: The vector to apply as a force in the local space of the Rigidbody.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.AddForce.documentation: The 'AddForce' method applies a force to the Rigidbody in world coordinates. You can use this method to give an initial speed to a Rigidbody, or to simulate actions like a gust of wind or torrent pushing an object. You manipulate the speed and direction of Rigidbody through this method. For more context and examples, check the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.AddForce.html).

params.name: force
params.documentation: The vector to apply as a force in the global space.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.SweepTest.documentation: The 'SweepTest' method checks if a Rigidbody would collide with anything, if it was moved through the Scene. This can be used to predict collisions before moving an object or to find out if an area is clear from obstacles. The method provides information about what the Rigidbody would hit if it was moved through its environment. You can understand more about sweep testing from the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.SweepTest.html).

params.name: direction
params.documentation: The direction in which to sweep the Rigidbody.

params.name: maxDistance
params.documentation: The maximum distance over which to sweep the Rigidbody.

returns.documentation: Returns true if a Rigidbody collider is hit, and includes information about the object hit in a RaycastHit object.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.SetDensit.documentation: The 'SetDensity' method forces the mass of the Rigidbody to adjust to the given density. This method is useful for recalculating mass after changing the mass of the object, especially when dealing with variable density fluids or building a physics puzzle. Read more about this in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.SetDensity.html).

params.name: density
params.documentation: The density to be set on the Rigidbody.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.MovePosit.documentation: The 'MovePosition' method moves the Rigidbody to the specified position by calculating the appropriate linear velocity required to move the Rigidbody to that position during the next physics update. This method is particularly useful when you want to instantly move a Rigidbody in response to player input or AI calculations. For further details, refer to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.MovePosition.html).

params.name: position
params.documentation: The target position for the Rigidbody in world space.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.MoveRotat.documentation: The 'MoveRotation' method rotates the Rigidbody to the specified rotation by calculating the appropriate angular velocity required to rotate the Rigidbody to that rotation during the next physics update. It is commonly used for rotating Rigidbodies that are under the influence of physics. For more details, check out the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.MoveRotation.html).

params.name: rot
params.documentation: The new rotation for the Rigidbody.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.Move.documentation: The 'Move' method simultaneously changes the position and rotation of the Rigidbody to match the specified position and rotation. This method affects the Rigidbody's position and rotation using physics and is therefore useful for moving objects under the control of physics. To understand more about it, take a look at the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.Move.html).

params.name: position
params.documentation: The new position for the Rigidbody in world space.

params.name: rotation
params.documentation: The new rotation for the Rigidbody.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.Sleep.documentation: The 'Sleep' method is used to put the Rigidbody to sleep. When a Rigidbody is asleep, it won't register any physics updates until it's woken up, saving processing power. In most cases, you won't need to manually put a Rigidbody to sleep, as Unity does it automatically when objects come to rest. However, there may be times when you need to put a Rigidbody to sleep instantly, for example, when a game object should freeze in place. The [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.Sleep.html) provides more insight into this topic.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.IsSleepin.documentation: The 'IsSleeping' method checks whether the Rigidbody is sleeping or not. It can be used to confirm that a Rigidbody is asleep, for instance, before applying a force to it, since such changes would wake up the Rigidbody. If you want to know more, check the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.IsSleeping.html).

returns.documentation: Returns true if the Rigidbody is asleep, false otherwise.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.WakeUp.documentation: The 'WakeUp' method is used to wake up a sleeping Rigidbody. Once woken, it will start receiving physics updates again. This is often useful when you want to instantly wake up a Rigidbody to reapply physics to it. For more on this, refer to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.WakeUp.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.ResetCent.documentation: The 'ResetCenterOfMass' method resets the center of mass of the Rigidbody by calculating it based on the attached colliders. This can be useful if the Rigidbody's mass or shape has changed, and you need to recalibrate the center of mass. You can learn more in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.ResetCenterOfMass.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.ResetIner.documentation: The 'ResetInertiaTensor' method resets the inertia tensor of the Rigidbody by calculating it based on the shape of the attached colliders. This is similar to ResetCenterOfMass and is useful when the Rigidbody's mass or shape has changed. The inertia tensor influences how the Rigidbody's shape behaves when it rotates. Check out the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.ResetInertiaTensor.html) for more in-depth information.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.GetRelati.documentation: The 'GetRelativePointVelocity' function retrieves the velocity at which a point on the Rigidbody moves, relative to the Rigidbody, including any rotational velocity. This can be handy for numerous physical simulations or visual effects, such as calculating the directions of sparks when a rotating wheel hits an obstacle. More information can be found at the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.GetRelativePointVelocity.html).

params.name: relativePoint
params.documentation: The point on the Rigidbody in local space for which to retrieve the relative velocity.

returns.documentation: Returns the relative velocity of the specified point.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.GetPointV.documentation: The 'GetPointVelocity' method provides the velocity at which a point on the object is moving, including rotational velocity. This method is commonly used for visual effects or physics computations. For example, you might want to release a particle system at the position where a rotating wheel makes contact with the ground, and you want the particles to inherit the wheel's velocity at the contact point. You can explore more on this topic in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.GetPointVelocity.html).

params.name: worldPoint
params.documentation: The point in world space to calculate the velocity for.

returns.documentation: Returns the velocity of the specified point.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.GetAccumu.documentation: The 'GetAccumulatedForce' method obtains the force accumulated on the Rigidbody over one physics simulation step. This is useful in certain effects or physics-based calculators that need to understand the amount of force being put on an object. For more details, refer to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.GetAccumulatedForce.html).

params.name: step
params.documentation: The step index to retrieve accumulated forces for.

returns.documentation: Returns the accumulated force for the given step.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.GetAccumu.documentation: The 'GetAccumulatedTorque' method retrieves the torque accumulated on the Rigidbody over one physics simulation step. Just like 'GetAccumulatedForce', this method is useful where you need to calculate the rotation effects based on the amount of torque applied on an object. The [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.GetAccumulatedTorque.html) provides additional context for this.

params.name: step
params.documentation: The step index to retrieve accumulated torques for.

returns.documentation: Returns the accumulated torque for the given step.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.ClosestPo.documentation: The 'ClosestPointOnBounds' method finds the closest point to the provided position on the collider's boundary of the attached Rigidbody. This method can be advantageous in numerous scenarios such as checking how close an object is to touching or hitting something. You can delve deeper into this topic in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody.ClosestPointOnBounds.html).

params.name: position
params.documentation: The world space point to find the closest point on the object to.

returns.documentation: Returns the point on the bounding box of the collider attached to the Rigidbody that is closest to the specified location.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.velocity.documentation: The 'velocity' property accesses the velocity of the Rigidbody. It is essentially the speed at which the Rigidbody is moving through 3D space in your game, as measured in units per second, giving you control over the speed at which an object moves. For more about velocity, check out the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-velocity.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.angularVe.documentation: The 'angularVelocity' property describes the angular velocity vector of the Rigidbody in degrees per second. Angular velocity essentially measures the rate and direction of rotation. When working on rotating objects or adjusting spin on Rigidbodies this becomes very handy. Refer to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-angularVelocity.html) for more.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.drag.documentation: The 'drag' property gives you control over the drag acting on the Rigidbody. Drag is a force that reduces the velocity of the Rigidbody making it decelerate over time as the force increases with speed. The ability to manipulate drag could help in emulating real-world physics like airflow resistance, slowing down your Rigidbody's linear movement over time. To learn more about this, visit the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-drag.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.angularDr.documentation: The 'angularDrag' property controls the angular drag applied to the Rigidbody. Angular drag could be interpreted as your Rigidbody's rotational inertia or in simpler terms, resistance to changes in rotating speed. Modifying this could help in creating more realistic movements and spins. You can explore more in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-angularDrag.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.mass.documentation: The 'mass' property allows you to alter the mass of the Rigidbody. The mass of an object is an important aspect in physics-based interactions and plays a crucial role when calculating how forces affect it. For example, giving an object a larger mass in the game would make it harder to push around. The [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-mass.html) provides more insights about this.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.useGravit.documentation: The 'useGravity' property enables or disables the application of gravity on the Rigidbody. Disabling gravity might be useful for certain objects, like in a zero-gravity setting or while programming specific behaviors for an object, like a hover effect. To find out more, you can check the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-useGravity.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.maxDepene.documentation: The 'maxDepenetrationVelocity' property sets the maximum velocity the Rigidbody can have when resolving penetration. It's useful primarily for sleeping bodies that are directly moved or affected by other bodies that initiate overlaps. For details, see the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-maxDepenetrationVelocity.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.isKinemat.documentation: The 'isKinematic' property, when enabled, makes the Rigidbody stop responding to forces, effectively turning off its built-in physics engine. The Rigidbody continues to interact with other non-kinematic bodies and collide with them but will move only when directly controlled by its Transform. This is useful when moving objects under direct player or script control. Please consult the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-isKinematic.html) for more information.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.freezeRot.documentation: The 'freezeRotation' property, when enabled, causes the Rigidbody to stop rotating under the influence of external forces or impacts - its rotation only changes if directly manipulated. This property can be useful when you want to control Rigidbody rotation directly, or when simulating items that resist rotation such as wheels or gyros. Further details are in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-freezeRotation.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.automatic.documentation: The 'automaticCenterOfMass' property determines whether the system should automatically compute the Rigidbody's center of mass. When this property is set to true, Unity calculates the center of mass based on the attached colliders. The [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-automaticCenterOfMass.html) provides an in-depth understanding of this.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.centerOfM.documentation: The 'centerOfMass' property helps manage Rigidbody's center of mass, a crucial factor in simulating physical behaviors. You can manually specify the local space position of the center of mass or let Unity automatically compute it. See the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-centerOfMass.html) for more on this.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.worldCent.documentation: The 'worldCenterOfMass' property accesses the global space position of the center of mass of the Rigidbody. This property is particularly handy when relying on the center of mass to calculate forces or torques that should affect the Rigidbody. The [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-worldCenterOfMass.html) provides a deeper understanding of this.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.automatic.documentation: The 'automaticInertiaTensor' property enables or disables automatic calculations of the Rigidbody's inertia tensor based on its attached colliders. Disabling this allows setting custom inertia tensors, which can be beneficial for fine-tuning the rotational behavior of complex Rigidbody setups. For additional information, refer to [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-automaticInertiaTensor.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.inertiaTe.documentation: The 'inertiaTensorRotation' property specifies the rotation of the local space in which the inertia tensor is defined. This allows you to adjust the "shape" of the Rigidbody's mass. This property, in combination with inertiaTensor, can be used to fine-tune the rotational behavior of the Rigidbody. Detailed explanations are provided in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-inertiaTensorRotation.html).

The 'inertiaTensor' property determines the Rigidbody's inertia tensor, a measure of an object's resistance to changes in its rotational motion. Defining a custom inertia tensor can help simulate more complex rotational behavior. For more details, see the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-inertiaTensor.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.detectCol.documentation: The 'detectCollisions' property gives you control over whether the Rigidbody will detect collisions or not. In some cases, you may want to move a Rigidbody through a scene without triggering hooks like OnCollisionEnter. In such situations, disabling detectCollisions can be helpful. You can learn more from the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-detectCollisions.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.position.documentation: The 'position' property gives you access to the position of the Rigidbody. It can be used to directly set the position of the Rigidbody in world space, and can be of significance while operating in kinematic mode or when you want to bypass physics simulation. For more context, visit the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-position.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.rotation.documentation: The 'rotation' property provides you with access to the rotation of the Rigidbody. It can be used to directly set the rotation of the Rigidbody in world space. It can be crucial while operating in kinematic mode or when you want to bypass physics simulation to manually rotate the Rigidbody. For an in-depth understanding, check the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-rotation.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.solverIte.documentation: The 'solverIterations' property allows you to adjust the number of solver iterations Unity performs for the Rigidbody. More iterations typically lead to more stable physics, but at the cost of extra computational overhead. Find more details in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-solverIterations.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.sleepThre.documentation: The 'sleepThreshold' property defines the minimum energy a Rigidbody must have before it can be put to sleep. When a Rigidbody is asleep, it won't register any physics updates until it's woken up, saving processing power. Visit the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-sleepThreshold.html) to learn more.

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.maxAngula.documentation: The 'maxAngularVelocity' property sets the maximum angular velocity of the Rigidbody. It can prevent fast rotating objects from moving too quickly, which could lead to instability in the physics simulation. To know more about maximum angular velocity, check the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-maxAngularVelocity.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.maxLinear.documentation: The 'maxLinearVelocity' property sets the maximum linear velocity of the Rigidbody. It is an effective way to cap the speed of fast-moving objects for stability or gameplay reasons. For more details, you can check the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-maxLinearVelocity.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Rigidbody.solverVel.documentation: The 'solverVelocityIterations' property sets the number of solver iterations used to solve velocity constraints. More iterations can improve stability but have performance implications. Additional information on this topic can be found at the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Rigidbody-solverVelocityIterations.html).

@highrise/globaltype/CapsuleCollider.documentation: CapsuleCollider is a collider component in Unity shaped like a capsule, suitable for elongated spherical objects where SphereCollider and BoxCollider aren't ideal fits. It detects collisions between GameObjects, allowing scripted reactions to these events. CapsuleColliders can be resized and repositioned to match GameObject shapes accurately.

@highrise/global/CapsuleCollider.documentation: CapsuleCollider is a collider component in Unity shaped like a capsule, suitable for elongated spherical objects where SphereCollider and BoxCollider aren't ideal fits. It detects collisions between GameObjects, allowing scripted reactions to these events. CapsuleColliders can be resized and repositioned to match GameObject shapes accurately.

@highrise/globaltype/CapsuleCollider.cen.documentation: Defines the center position of the CapsuleCollider relative to the GameObject, adjustable to move the Collider from the GameObject's center.

@highrise/globaltype/CapsuleCollider.rad.documentation: Controls the size of the CapsuleCollider by adjusting its radius, allowing expansion or contraction.

@highrise/globaltype/CapsuleCollider.hei.documentation: Adjusts the vertical dimension of the CapsuleCollider, affecting its height.

@highrise/globaltype/CapsuleCollider.dir.documentation: Sets the orientation axis of the Collider's height, with values "0" for X-axis, "1" for Y-axis, and "2" for Z-axis.

@highrise/globaltype/CharacterClothing.documentation: A single item of clothing in a character's outfit.

@highrise/global/CharacterClothing.documentation: A single item of clothing in a character's outfit.

@highrise/globaltype/RemoteFunction.Invo.documentation: Invokes the remote function on the client side.

params.name: player
params.documentation: The player to invoke the function for.
Add any number of other additional parameters to your invoked function, just remember to handle them in `OnInvokeClient`.

@highrise/globaltype/RemoteFunction.Invo.documentation: Invokes the remote function on the server side.

params.documentation: Add any number of other additional parameters to your invoked function, just remember to handle them in `OnInvokeServer`.

@highrise/globaltype/RemoteFunction.name.documentation: The name of the remote function.

@highrise/globaltype/RemoteFunction.OnIn.documentation: Callback function for the client that is triggered by the server. Parameters are determined by what was passed into `InvokeClient`.
Callback function for the server that is triggered by the client. Parameters are determined by what was passed into `InvokeServer`.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Value.documentation: The Vector3Value class is used to store a single Datatype.Vector3 value. It is a subclass of the Class.Value and it is recommended to check out that documentation before continuing on. This class is useful for tracking a single integer value that all clients should be synchronized on.

@highrise/global/Vector3Value.documentation: The Vector3Value class is used to store a single Datatype.Vector3 value. It is a subclass of the Class.Value and it is recommended to check out that documentation before continuing on. This class is useful for tracking a single integer value that all clients should be synchronized on.

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the Vector3Value. This must be unique as it is used as the key to synchronize the value across all clients.

params.name: initialValue
params.documentation: The initial value of the Vector3Value.

returns.documentation: An Vector3Value instance with the specified value.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Value.value.documentation: The currently synchronized Vector3 value of the Vector3Value. This is the value that all clients will be synchronized on and if changed, notified that the value is now different from the Value.Changed event.

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryItem.documentation: InventoryItem contains the data for an item retrieved through either Inventory.GetItem or Inventory.GetItems.

@highrise/global/InventoryItem.documentation: InventoryItem contains the data for an item retrieved through either Inventory.GetItem or Inventory.GetItems.

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryItem.holde.documentation: The id of the holder which owns this item

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryItem.amoun.documentation: How many of this item the owner owns.  Includes items that have been reserved.

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryItem.avail.documentation: How many of this item the owner owns that are not reserved.

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryItem.creat.documentation: The time the holder first gained this item.  The time is in the UTC time zone expressed in unix epoch seconds.  You can use os.date to format this time into a human-readable format.

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryItem.updat.documentation: The last time the state of this item changed.  The time is in the UTC time zone expressed in unix epoch seconds.  You can use os.date to format this time into a human-readable format.

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryItem.reser.documentation: Returns an array of InventoryReservations which contain how many items are reserved and the purpose.

@highrise/globaltype/IntValue.documentation: The IntValue class is used to store a single integer value, which is a number without decimals. It is a subclass of the Class.Value and it is recommended to check out that documentation before continuing on. This class is useful for tracking a single integer value that all clients should be synchronized on.

@highrise/global/IntValue.documentation: The IntValue class is used to store a single integer value, which is a number without decimals. It is a subclass of the Class.Value and it is recommended to check out that documentation before continuing on. This class is useful for tracking a single integer value that all clients should be synchronized on.

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the IntValue. This must be unique as it is used as the key to synchronize the value across all clients.

params.name: initialValue
params.documentation: The initial value of the IntValue.

returns.documentation: An IntValue instance with the specified value.

@highrise/globaltype/IntValue.value.documentation: The currently synchronized integer value of the IntValue. This is the value that all clients will be synchronized on and if changed, notified that the value is now different from the Value.Changed event.

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.documentation:
The Texture2D class in Unity is like your canvas for drawing in the digital realm. A powerhouse for handling 2D textures and images, it is used for constructing and customizing visual elements in your game world, one pixel at a time. From generating a fresh texture dynamically, tailoring pre-existing textures, to applying those as the backdrop or developing intricate sprite animations, the Texture2D class gives you the reins.

Beyond its basic form, the Texture2D class dives deeper into the realm of advanced graphical rendering. Paired with Shader programming, it allows you to create diverse visual effects, playing with lighting and transforming visuals in complex ways.

To unravel the vast applications and techniques you can achieve with the Texture2D class and carve detailed, interactive, and visually appealing experiences in your games, head over to the in-depth guide in the [official Unity Texture2D Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D.html).

@highrise/global/Texture2D.documentation:
The Texture2D class in Unity is like your canvas for drawing in the digital realm. A powerhouse for handling 2D textures and images, it is used for constructing and customizing visual elements in your game world, one pixel at a time. From generating a fresh texture dynamically, tailoring pre-existing textures, to applying those as the backdrop or developing intricate sprite animations, the Texture2D class gives you the reins.

Beyond its basic form, the Texture2D class dives deeper into the realm of advanced graphical rendering. Paired with Shader programming, it allows you to create diverse visual effects, playing with lighting and transforming visuals in complex ways.

To unravel the vast applications and techniques you can achieve with the Texture2D class and carve detailed, interactive, and visually appealing experiences in your games, head over to the in-depth guide in the [official Unity Texture2D Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.Compress.documentation: The Compress method compresses texture data in memory, decreasing the memory footprint at the expense of image quality. This can be significant to optimize game performance, especially on mobile platforms or devices with lower specs. Detailed info at [Unity's Texture2D.Compress Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D.Compress.html)

params.name: highQuality
params.documentation: Determines whether the compression process strives for higher quality or smaller footprint.

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.ClearRequ.documentation: The ClearRequestedMipmapLevel method discards all pending mipmap level requests for the texture. This may be important in dynamic scenes where mipmap level requirements can change rapidly. For more, visit [Unity's Texture2D.ClearRequestedMipmapLevel Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D.ClearRequestedMipmapLevel.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.IsRequest.documentation: The IsRequestedMipmapLevelLoaded method checks if the requested mipmap level has been loaded into memory. This is useful to ensure desired level of detail is ready before being applied. Detailed info at [Unity's Texture2D.IsRequestedMipmapLevelLoaded Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D.IsRequestedMipmapLevelLoaded.html)

returns.documentation: Returns true if the requested mipmap level has been loaded, false otherwise.

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.ClearMini.documentation: The ClearMinimumMipmapLevel method clears the minimum level of mipmaps that need to be loaded for the texture. This can be used along with related mipmap methods to fine-tune the balance between texture quality and memory usage. For more, see [Unity's Texture2D.ClearMinimumMipmapLevel Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D.ClearMinimumMipmapLevel.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.SetPixel.documentation: The SetPixel method lets you change a pixel's color at a specific position on the texture. This is a critical tool for runtime texture manipulation or applying custom drawn effects on textures. To understand more about it, see [Unity's Texture2D.SetPixel Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D.SetPixel.html)

params.name: x
params.documentation: The x-coordinate of the pixel.

params.name: y
params.documentation: The y-coordinate of the pixel.

params.name: color
params.documentation: The desired color for the pixel.

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.GetPixel.documentation: The GetPixel method fetches the color of a pixel at a given position on the texture. This can be useful to create color-based logic or to read color information from textures. To learn more, refer to [Unity's Texture2D.GetPixel Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D.GetPixel.html)

params.name: x
params.documentation: The x-coordinate of the pixel.

params.name: y
params.documentation: The y-coordinate of the pixel.

returns.documentation: Returns the color of the specified pixel.

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.GetPixelB.documentation: The GetPixelBilinear method retrieves the color of a pixel using bilinear filtering. Bilinear filtering considers the four pixels surrounding specific coordinates and returns a blended color, producing a smoother result. More about this at [Unity's Texture2D.GetPixelBilinear Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D.GetPixelBilinear.html)

params.name: u
params.documentation: The u-coordinate (horizontal) of the pixel.

params.name: v
params.documentation: The v-coordinate (vertical) of the pixel.

returns.documentation: Returns the color of the pixel at the specified coordinates, blended using bilinear filtering.

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.Apply.documentation: The Apply method updates the texture with any changes made since the last time Apply was called. If the texture is used in a material, it is necessary to call this method for the changes to be rendered on screen. For more details, visit [Unity's Texture2D.Apply Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D.Apply.html)

params.name: updateMipmaps
params.documentation: If true, the mipmap levels are regenerated automatically.

params.name: makeNoLongerReadable
params.documentation: If true, system memory copy of the texture is released after uploading it to the GPU.

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.Reinitial.documentation: The Reinitialize method recreates the texture with a new size, preserving existing texture content. It is designed for dynamic operations like texture size changes in response to screen resizing. Learn more at [Unity's Texture2D.Reinitialize Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D.Reinitialize.html)

params.name: width
params.documentation: The new width for the texture.

params.name: height
params.documentation: The new height for the texture.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the re-initialization is successful.

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.ReadPixel.documentation: The ReadPixels method reads pixel data from the framebuffer and stores it into a region of the Texture2D. This operation can be particularly helpful when implementing features like screenshots. Detailed info can be found at [Unity's Texture2D.ReadPixels Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D.ReadPixels.html)

params.name: source
params.documentation: The region of the screen from which pixels are read.

params.name: destX
params.documentation: The x-coordinate of the lower left corner of the region where pixels are written in the Texture2D.

params.name: destY
params.documentation: The y-coordinate of the lower left corner of the region where pixels are written in the Texture2D.

params.name: recalculateMipMaps
params.documentation: If true, mipmaps are automatically recalculated for this texture after reading pixels.

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.new.documentation: The constructor for creating a new Texture2D instance with predefined width and height. A Texture2D object could be then utilized for displaying images, applying as textures, or even for complex graphical computations. To learn more about its versatile usage, refer to [Unity's Texture2D.new Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-ctor.html)

params.name: width
params.documentation: The desired width for the new Texture2D.

params.name: height
params.documentation: The desired height for the new Texture2D.

returns.documentation: Returns the newly created Texture2D object.

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.ignoreMip.documentation: The ignoreMipmapLimit property is a Boolean that allows you to bypass mipmap limits when generating mipmaps. This is helpful when you are looking for a higher level of detail in your textures. For more info: [Unity's Texture2D.ignoreMipmapLimit Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-ignoreMipmapLimit.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.mipmapLim.documentation: The mipmapLimitGroup property is a string that is differential in controlling the mipmap display details, by categorizing the different mipmaps of a single texture into various groups. Each mipmap group can then be rendered separately, facilitating various visualization techniques. More details at [Unity's Texture2D.mipmapLimitGroup Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-mipmapLimitGroup.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.activeMip.documentation: The activeMipmapLimit property allows you to determine the highest level of mipmaps that should be rendered for the texture. This is especially useful to optimize performance by controlling the level of texture detail, and balancing it against the processing power. For more about this, check [Unity's Texture2D.activeMipmapLimit Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-activeMipmapLimit.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.isReadabl.documentation: The isReadable property is an indication of whether the pixel data of the texture can be read or written via script. This gives developers control over direct pixel manipulation which can be useful for custom graphics effects. Learn more from [Unity's Texture2D.isReadable Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-isReadable.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.vtOnly.documentation: The vtOnly property, when set to true, facilitates Virtual Texturing behavior for the Texture2D object. Virtual Texturing improves rendering performance by only loading visible textures, helpful for devices with limited graphic memory. Find out more in [Unity's Texture2D.vtOnly Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-vtOnly.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.streaming.documentation: The streamingMipmaps property, when enabled, allows relative mipmap levels to be loaded asynchronously, optimizing the resources used for texture details. For more on this, see [Unity's Texture2D.streamingMipmaps Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-streamingMipmaps.html)

The streamingMipmapsPriority property assigns a priority level to the Texture2D for mipmap streaming. Textures with higher priority will be streamed first. Read more at [Unity's Texture2D.streamingMipmapsPriority Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-streamingMipmapsPriority.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.requested.documentation: The requestedMipmapLevel property lets you request a specific level of detail for mipmaps to be loaded. This gives you control over the texture quality and performance trade-off. More can be found at [Unity's Texture2D.requestedMipmapLevel Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-requestedMipmapLevel.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.minimumMi.documentation: The minimumMipmapLevel property sets the lowest mipmap level that can be used. By controlling the mipmap levels, you can ensure the right balance between texture detail and memory usage. For more details, check out [Unity's Texture2D.minimumMipmapLevel Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-minimumMipmapLevel.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.calculate.documentation: The calculatedMipmapLevel property retrieves the currently calculated most suitable mipmap level based on texture usage. This can be convenient for optimizing texture detail in dynamic situations. Read more at [Unity's Texture2D.calculatedMipmapLevel Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-calculatedMipmapLevel.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.desiredMi.documentation: The desiredMipmapLevel property returns the desired mipmap level calculated by Unity. This is determined based on texture usage and the system's conditions. More about this at [Unity's Texture2D.desiredMipmapLevel Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-desiredMipmapLevel.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.loadingMi.documentation: The loadingMipmapLevel property indicates the highest mipmap level currently being loaded. This can be useful for monitoring and managing texture detail level during runtime. Read more at [Unity's Texture2D.loadingMipmapLevel Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-loadingMipmapLevel.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2D.loadedMip.documentation: The loadedMipmapLevel property returns the highest fully loaded mipmap level. This can be leveraged to guarantee a certain level of texture quality by ensuring that high enough mipmap levels are fully loaded. Detailed info at [Unity's Texture2D.loadedMipmapLevel Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-loadedMipmapLevel.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2DType.white.documentation: The whiteTexture property is a convenient way of getting a 2x2 white texture. This is commonly used for single color texturing or debugging. Official details at [Unity's Texture2D.whiteTexture Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-whiteTexture.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2DType.black.documentation: The blackTexture property is a readily available 2x2 black texture. Similar to whiteTexture, this can be useful for single color texturing or debugging. Learn more at [Unity's Texture2D.blackTexture Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-blackTexture.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2DType.redTe.documentation: The redTexture property gives you a 2x2 red texture. This can be used for simple color assignments in texturing tasks or debugging. More at [Unity's Texture2D.redTexture Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-redTexture.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2DType.grayT.documentation: The grayTexture property returns a 2x2 gray texture. This can come in handy for simple color texturing or debugging. Detailed information at [Unity's Texture2D.grayTexture Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-grayTexture.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2DType.linea.documentation: The linearGrayTexture property provides a 2x2 gray texture with no gamma correction applied. This can be important for tasks requiring linear color space textures. To know more about this, refer to [Unity's Texture2D.linearGrayTexture Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-linearGrayTexture.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Texture2DType.norma.documentation: The normalTexture property allows quick access to a 2x2 pixel texture where all pixels are set to 'RGB(0, 0.5, 0.5)', commonly used as a default for normal maps. To understand more about its use, check [Unity's Texture2D.normalTexture Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture2D-normalTexture.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Collision.documentation: Collision encapsulates details about interactions between moving objects, including the collision's impact, the objects involved, and the exact collision points. It offers a suite of properties that provide insights into the physical dynamics of a collision, aiding in the application of game logic and physics manipulations during collision events. The Collision class is pivotal for handling "OnCollision" events, offering a detailed framework for understanding and reacting to in-game physical interactions. Refer to Unity's official Collision documentation for a deeper exploration.

@highrise/global/Collision.documentation: Collision encapsulates details about interactions between moving objects, including the collision's impact, the objects involved, and the exact collision points. It offers a suite of properties that provide insights into the physical dynamics of a collision, aiding in the application of game logic and physics manipulations during collision events. The Collision class is pivotal for handling "OnCollision" events, offering a detailed framework for understanding and reacting to in-game physical interactions. Refer to Unity's official Collision documentation for a deeper exploration.

@highrise/globaltype/Collision.impulse.documentation: Indicates the total impulse applied to simulate the collision, useful for measuring collision impact.

@highrise/globaltype/Collision.relativeV.documentation: Provides the speed difference at the moment of collision, aiding in speed-based logic.

@highrise/globaltype/Collision.rigidbody.documentation: References the Rigidbody of the collided object, enabling direct manipulation post-collision.

@highrise/globaltype/Collision.body.documentation: Similar to 'rigidbody', it references the body involved in the collision for adjustments or analysis.

@highrise/globaltype/Collision.collider.documentation: Points to the Collider component of the object hit, crucial for accessing collision properties.

@highrise/globaltype/Collision.transform.documentation: Accesses the Transform of the collided object, offering positional and rotational control.

@highrise/globaltype/Collision.gameObjec.documentation: Grants access to the GameObject that was part of the collision, enabling game logic application.

@highrise/globaltype/Collision.contactCo.documentation: Reveals the number of contact points in the collision, informative for collision scope assessment.

@highrise/globaltype/WorldProduct.documentation: Represents a product that can be purchased by players in the game.

@highrise/global/WorldProduct.documentation: Represents a product that can be purchased by players in the game.

returns.documentation: The new WorldProduct object.

@highrise/globaltype/WorldProduct.produc.documentation: The product ID of the product.

@highrise/globaltype/WorldProduct.price.documentation: The price of the product in Gold.

@highrise/globaltype/DoubleClickEvent.documentation: Event sent when a double click occurs on an element

@highrise/global/DoubleClickEvent.documentation: Event sent when a double click occurs on an element

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryReservatio.documentation: InventoryReservation is returned from InventoryItem.reservations and contains how many items have been reserved and their purpose.

@highrise/global/InventoryReservation.documentation: InventoryReservation is returned from InventoryItem.reservations and contains how many items have been reserved and their purpose.

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryReservatio.documentation: The amount of items that have been reserved.
The purpose the items were reserved for.  This corresponds to the reservedFor parameter passed into InventoryTransaction.Reserve and InventoryTransaction.Release

@highrise/globaltype/LongPressGesture.documentation: Listens for a long press gestures on a VisualElement and sends a LongPressEvent when recognized.

@highrise/global/LongPressGesture.documentation: Listens for a long press gestures on a VisualElement and sends a LongPressEvent when recognized.

@highrise/globaltype/NumberValue.documentation: The NumberValue class is used to store a single number value, which unlike Class.IntValue supports decimal points. It is a subclass of the Class.Value and it is recommended to check out that documentation before continuing on. This class is useful for tracking a single number value that all clients should be synchronized on.

@highrise/global/NumberValue.documentation: The NumberValue class is used to store a single number value, which unlike Class.IntValue supports decimal points. It is a subclass of the Class.Value and it is recommended to check out that documentation before continuing on. This class is useful for tracking a single number value that all clients should be synchronized on.

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the NumberValue. This must be unique as it is used as the key to synchronize the value across all clients.

params.name: initialValue
params.documentation: The initial value of the NumberValue.

returns.documentation: An NumberValue instance with the specified value.

@highrise/globaltype/NumberValue.value.documentation: The currently synchronized number value of the NumberValue. This is the value that all clients will be synchronized on and if changed, notified that the value is now different from the Value.Changed event.

@highrise/globaltype/Scene.documentation: The 'Scene' class in the scene or 'game area'. It manages events related to player interactions with the scene and allows you to section and differentiate portions of your world into smaller chunks.

@highrise/global/Scene.documentation: The 'Scene' class in the scene or 'game area'. It manages events related to player interactions with the scene and allows you to section and differentiate portions of your world into smaller chunks.

@highrise/globaltype/Scene.PlayerJoined.documentation: An event triggered when a player joins the scene.

@highrise/globaltype/Scene.PlayerLeft.documentation: An event triggered when a player leaves the scene.

@highrise/globaltype/Scene.id.documentation: The unique identifier of the scene.

@highrise/globaltype/Scene.mainCamera.documentation: The main camera associated with the scene.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.documentation: Represents an in-game character, providing properties and methods to control its movement, appearance, and interaction within the game environment.

@highrise/global/Character.documentation: Represents an in-game character, providing properties and methods to control its movement, appearance, and interaction within the game environment.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.Teleport.documentation: Teleports the character to a specified position.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.SetIdle.documentation: Sets the character to an idle state.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.PlayEmote.documentation: Plays a specified emote animation on the character.

params.name: emoteName
params.documentation: The name of the emote to play.

params.name: loop
params.documentation: Whether the emote should loop.

params.name: callback
params.documentation: A callback function to execute when the emote playback is complete.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.MoveTo.documentation: Moves the character to a specified position.

params.name: position
params.documentation: The target position for the character to move to.

params.name: areaMask
params.documentation: An optional mask to specify allowed movement areas.

params.name: callback
params.documentation: A callback function to execute when movement is complete.

returns.documentation: Returns true if movement is successfully initiated.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.MoveWithi.documentation: Moves the character within a specified range of a position.

params.name: position
params.documentation: The target position for the character to approach.

params.name: distance
params.documentation: The desired distance from the target position.

params.name: areaMask
params.documentation: An optional mask to specify allowed movement areas.

params.name: callback
params.documentation: A callback function to execute when movement is complete.

returns.documentation: Returns true if movement is successfully initiated.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.TweenRend.documentation: Smoothly transitions the character's render position from one point to another.

params.name: from
params.documentation: The starting position for the tween.

params.name: to
params.documentation: The ending position for the tween.

returns.documentation: A Tween object representing the transition.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.TweenRend.documentation: Initiates a smooth transition for the character's render position to a specified destination.

params.name: to
params.documentation: The target position for the character's render position.

returns.documentation: A Tween object representing the transition.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.SetOutfit.documentation: Sets the character's outfit to a specified asset.

params.name: outfit
params.documentation: The outfit asset to apply to the character.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.ResetOutf.documentation: Resets the character's outfit to its default appearance.

params.name: outfit
params.documentation: The outfit asset to remove from the character.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.AddOutfit.documentation: Adds an outfit to the character's current appearance.

params.name: outfit
params.documentation: The outfit asset to add to the character.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.destinati.documentation: The target destination of the character in the game world.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.isMoving.documentation: Indicates whether the character is currently moving.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.distanceT.documentation: Returns the distance from the character to its destination.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.usePathfi.documentation: When set to true, the character uses pathfinding to navigate to its destination.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.renderLay.documentation: Specifies the rendering layer of the character for drawing order.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.renderPos.documentation: The position of the character in the game world for rendering purposes.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.renderRot.documentation: The rotation of the character in the game world for rendering purposes.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.renderSca.documentation: The scale of the character in the game world for rendering purposes.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.player.documentation: Reference to the player object that controls or owns the character.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.StateChan.documentation: An event that is triggered when the character's state changes.
@highrise/globaltype/Character.StateChan.code_sample:
local player = client.localPlayer

player.character.StateChanged:Connect(function(state)
  print("Character state changed to " .. state)
end)

@highrise/globaltype/Character.MoveFinis.documentation: An event that is triggered when the character finishes moving to a destination.
@highrise/globaltype/Character.MoveFinis.code_sample:
local player = client.localPlayer

player.character.MoveFinished:Connect(function()
  print("Character has finished moving.")
end)

@highrise/globaltype/Character.Animation.documentation: An event that is triggered when an animation event occurs on the character.
@highrise/globaltype/Character.Animation.code_sample:
local player = client.localPlayer

player.character.AnimationEvent:Connect(function(event)
  print("Animation event: " .. event)
end)

@highrise/globaltype/Character.state.documentation: The current state of the character.

@highrise/globaltype/Character.speed.documentation: The movement speed of the character. You must wait for the player to connect before setting this property.

@highrise/globaltype/Timer.Restart.documentation: Starts the timer and resets its elapsed time

@highrise/globaltype/AnimationEventHandl.documentation:
Attach this script to a GameObject with an Animator to receive events when the animation graph
  state changes.
  
  self:GetComponent(AnimationEventHandler).StateExit:Connect(function(clip)
      print("AnimationClip " .. clip.name .. " finished playing")
  end)

@highrise/global/AnimationEventHandler.documentation:
Attach this script to a GameObject with an Animator to receive events when the animation graph
  state changes.
  
  self:GetComponent(AnimationEventHandler).StateExit:Connect(function(clip)
      print("AnimationClip " .. clip.name .. " finished playing")
  end)

@highrise/globaltype/AnimationEventHandl.documentation: OnStateEnter is called when a transition starts and the state machine starts to evaluate this state.
OnStateExit is called when a transition ends and the state machine finishes evaluating this state.
OnStateIK is called right after Animator.OnAnimatorIK().
OnStateMove is called right after Animator.OnAnimatorMove().
OnStateUpdate is called on each Update frame between OnStateEnter and OnStateExit callbacks.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioListener.documentation: AudioListener functions as the game's auditory receiver, essential for creating immersive audio experiences. It works in tandem with AudioSource objects, replicating the real-world effect of sound proximity and volume. Typically attached to the camera or player, it facilitates global audio control, including volume adjustment and scene-wide pausing. For in-depth insights, consult Unity's official AudioListener documentation.

@highrise/global/AudioListener.documentation: AudioListener functions as the game's auditory receiver, essential for creating immersive audio experiences. It works in tandem with AudioSource objects, replicating the real-world effect of sound proximity and volume. Typically attached to the camera or player, it facilitates global audio control, including volume adjustment and scene-wide pausing. For in-depth insights, consult Unity's official AudioListener documentation.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioListenerType.v.documentation: Acts as a master volume control, affecting all AudioSource objects heard by the AudioListener.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioListenerType.p.documentation: Allows pausing or resuming all audio in the scene, useful for game events requiring silence.

@highrise/globaltype/Event.documentation: Event in Highrise signifies key moments or changes in the game environment, facilitating dynamic and responsive gameplay. It provides a structured way to define, trigger, and respond to in-game occurrences, such as a player joining or leaving. Events can be triggered on specific clients, all clients, or on the server, with corresponding actions attached through connections to functions. This mechanism is pivotal for creating interactive and adaptive game experiences.

@highrise/global/Event.documentation: Event in Highrise signifies key moments or changes in the game environment, facilitating dynamic and responsive gameplay. It provides a structured way to define, trigger, and respond to in-game occurrences, such as a player joining or leaving. Events can be triggered on specific clients, all clients, or on the server, with corresponding actions attached through connections to functions. This mechanism is pivotal for creating interactive and adaptive game experiences.

@highrise/globaltype/Event.FireClient.documentation: Activates the event for a particular client, enabling targeted notifications or actions.

@highrise/globaltype/Event.FireAllClient.documentation: Broadcasts the event to all connected clients, useful for global notifications or updates.

@highrise/globaltype/Event.FireServer.documentation: Triggers the event on the server side, often leading to updates in game state or other server-managed data.

@highrise/globaltype/Event.Connect.documentation: Establishes a linkage between the event and a specific response function, ensuring automatic execution upon event triggering.

returns.documentation: An EventConnection instance denoting the connection between the event and its response function.

@highrise/globaltype/EventType.new.documentation: Initializes a new event, marking a specific occurrence within the game that warrants reaction or handling.

returns.documentation: An instance of the Event class, representing the defined event.

@highrise/globaltype/Event.name.documentation: Identifies the event, aiding in differentiation and specific event handling.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioClip.documentation: AudioClip serves as a container for audio data, including music, voiceovers, and sound effects. It offers properties and methods to access playback details like length, samples, channels, and frequency. AudioClip supports preloading, 3D audio, and background loading. Custom AudioClip instances can be created programmatically. Fundamental for auditory experiences in Unity projects, AudioClip documentation provides further details.

@highrise/global/AudioClip.documentation: AudioClip serves as a container for audio data, including music, voiceovers, and sound effects. It offers properties and methods to access playback details like length, samples, channels, and frequency. AudioClip supports preloading, 3D audio, and background loading. Custom AudioClip instances can be created programmatically. Fundamental for auditory experiences in Unity projects, AudioClip documentation provides further details.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioClip.LoadAudio.documentation: Initiates loading of the clip's audio data, particularly when 'preloadAudioData' is false.

returns.documentation: True if data loading starts successfully.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioClip.UnloadAud.documentation: Unloads the clip's audio data from memory, aiding in efficient memory usage.

returns.documentation: True if data unloading begins successfully.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioClipType.Creat.documentation: Generates a new AudioClip with specified parameters, optionally streaming from disk.

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name for the new AudioClip.

params.name: lengthSamples
params.documentation: The total length of the clip in samples.

params.name: channels
params.documentation: The number of audio channels.

params.name: frequency
params.documentation: The sample rate of the clip.

params.name: stream
params.documentation: Whether the audio data is streamed from disk.

returns.documentation: A new AudioClip instance.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioClip.length.documentation: Returns the clip's duration in seconds, akin to a song's length.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioClip.samples.documentation: Refers to the total number of audio samples within the clip.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioClip.channels.documentation: Represents the number of audio channels, such as 1 for mono or 2 for stereo.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioClip.frequency.documentation: Denotes the sample rate of the clip in kHz, indicating the samples per second.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioClip.preloadAu.documentation: Controls whether the audio data should be preloaded upon clip asset loading.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioClip.ambisonic.documentation: Indicates if the clip is ambisonic, providing 3D audio capabilities.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioClip.loadInBac.documentation: Specifies if the clip should load in the background, allowing gameplay to continue.

@highrise/globaltype/UICollectionDelegat.documentation: Provides data to a collection using a delegate

@highrise/global/UICollectionDelegatePro.documentation: Provides data to a collection using a delegate

@highrise/globaltype/StringValue.documentation: The StringValue class is used to store a single string value. It is a subclass of the Class.Value and it is recommended to check out that documentation before continuing on. This class is useful for tracking a single string value that all clients should be synchronized on.

@highrise/global/StringValue.documentation: The StringValue class is used to store a single string value. It is a subclass of the Class.Value and it is recommended to check out that documentation before continuing on. This class is useful for tracking a single string value that all clients should be synchronized on.

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the StringValue. This must be unique as it is used as the key to synchronize the value across all clients.

params.name: initialValue
params.documentation: The initial value of the StringValue.

returns.documentation: A StringValue instance with the specified value.

@highrise/globaltype/StringValue.value.documentation: The currently synchronized string value of the StringValue. This is the value that all clients will be synchronized on and if changed, notified that the value is now different from the Value.Changed event.

@highrise/globaltype/Input.documentation:
The 'Input' class provides an interface to gather information from various external inputs. 'Input' works like a monitoring station, keeping track of user actions and triggering responses within the game.

Each of these properties contain events that are fired when the corresponding action is performed, and game developers can add listeners to these events to trigger custom game logic.

@highrise/global/Input.documentation:
The 'Input' class provides an interface to gather information from various external inputs. 'Input' works like a monitoring station, keeping track of user actions and triggering responses within the game.

Each of these properties contain events that are fired when the corresponding action is performed, and game developers can add listeners to these events to trigger custom game logic.

@highrise/globaltype/Input.isAltPressed.documentation: The 'IsAltPressed' property indicates if the Alt key is currently being pressed on the keyboard. This can be useful for creating keyboard shortcuts or alternate modes within the game.
@highrise/globaltype/Input.isAltPressed.code_sample:
if Input.IsAltPressed then
  -- Perform an action when the Alt key is pressed
end

@highrise/globaltype/Input.isMouseInput.documentation: The 'IsMouseInput' property helps to detect whether a mouse device is providing input. false == touch input
@highrise/globaltype/Input.isMouseInput.code_sample:
if Input.IsMouseInput then
  -- Perform an action when the mouse is providing input
end

@highrise/globaltype/Input.PinchOrDragBe.documentation: The 'PinchOrDragBegan' property listens for the beginning of pinch or drag gestures on a touch screen. Such gestures are common in mobile UI for operations like zooming or moving objects and can be leveraged effectively in game controls. See Class.PinchGestureBegan for more details on the parameter of the event.

@highrise/globaltype/Input.PinchOrDragCh.documentation: The 'PinchOrDragChanged' property fires an event whenever there is a change in an ongoing pinch or drag gesture on the touch screen. This allows the game to continuously track such gestures and make corresponding adjustments in its state. See Class.PinchGestureChanged for more details on the parameter of the event.

@highrise/globaltype/Input.PinchOrDragEn.documentation: The 'PinchOrDragEnded' property listens for the end of a pinch or drag gesture on a touch screen. This allows the game to know precisely when such a gesture ends and probably trigger appropriate actions thereafter. See Class.PinchGestureEnded for more details on the parameter of the event.

@highrise/globaltype/Input.MouseWheel.documentation: The 'MouseWheel' property listens for movements of the mouse wheel.
