local collider = GameObject.Find("Collider"):GetComponent(Collider)
local position = Vector3.new(0, 0, 0)
local rotation = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 0, 1)

local closestPoint = Physics.ClosestPoint(point, collider, position, rotation)
print("Closest point: " .. tostring(closestPoint))

params.name: point
params.documentation: Position to check against.

params.name: collider
params.documentation: Collider to check.

params.name: position
params.documentation: Collider's position.

params.name: rotation
params.documentation: Collider's rotation.

returns.documentation: Closest point on the collider.

@highrise/globaltype/Component.documentation: Component acts as the core of GameObject customization, enabling GameObjects to exhibit specific characteristics and behaviors. It's the foundation for a wide range of functionalities, from physics interactions with Collider to visual presentations via MeshRenderer and Camera components. Components transform GameObjects from static entities to dynamic actors within the game world. Scripting through LuaBehaviour further expands potential behaviors, allowing for unique game mechanics and interactions. Components are pivotal for developing immersive, interactive game environments. Explore Unity's Component documentation for detailed insights.

@highrise/global/Component.documentation: Component acts as the core of GameObject customization, enabling GameObjects to exhibit specific characteristics and behaviors. It's the foundation for a wide range of functionalities, from physics interactions with Collider to visual presentations via MeshRenderer and Camera components. Components transform GameObjects from static entities to dynamic actors within the game world. Scripting through LuaBehaviour further expands potential behaviors, allowing for unique game mechanics and interactions. Components are pivotal for developing immersive, interactive game environments. Explore Unity's Component documentation for detailed insights.

returns.documentation: True if tags match, otherwise false.

@highrise/globaltype/Component.transform.documentation: Provides access to the GameObject's Transform, facilitating position, rotation, and scale adjustments.

@highrise/globaltype/Component.gameObjec.documentation: Allows access to the GameObject this component is attached to, central to numerous Unity operations.

@highrise/globaltype/Component.tag.documentation: Accesses the GameObject's tag for identification and selection purposes within Unity's environment.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioService.documentation: Manages and controls all aspects of audio playback, including music, sound effects, and voice within the game environment. Offers functionalities like playing, stopping, and adjusting audio properties.

@highrise/global/AudioService.documentation: Manages and controls all aspects of audio playback, including music, sound effects, and voice within the game environment. Offers functionalities like playing, stopping, and adjusting audio properties.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioService.IsPlay.documentation: Checks if any audio is currently playing.

returns.documentation: Returns true if audio is playing; otherwise, false.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioService.MusicI.documentation: Retrieves the current music intensity level.

returns.documentation: Current intensity of the playing music.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioService.MusicD.documentation: Gets the volume level music is ducked to during audio ducking.

returns.documentation: The volume level music is ducked to.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioService.DuckMu.documentation: Temporarily lowers the music volume for a specified duration.

params.name: duration
params.documentation: How long the music volume is lowered.

params.name: duckOutDuration
params.documentation: Time to transition music volume to the ducked level.

params.name: duckInDuration
params.documentation: Time to restore music volume back to normal after ducking.

params.name: shader
params.documentation: The AudioShader used to play music.

params.name: volume
params.documentation: The volume at which the music should be played.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioService.PlayMu.documentation: Plays music from a specified URL.

params.name: url
params.documentation: The URL of the music to be played.

params.name: volume
params.documentation: The volume at which the music should be played.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioService.StopMu.documentation: Stops currently playing music, with an option to fade out.

params.name: fadeOut
params.documentation: Whether the music should fade out instead of stopping abruptly.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioService.PlaySh.documentation: Plays an audio effect using an AudioShader.

params.name: shader
params.documentation: The AudioShader used to play the audio effect.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioService.PlaySo.documentation: Plays a sound effect globally, without spatialization.

params.name: shader
params.documentation: The AudioShader representing the sound to be played.

params.name: volume
params.documentation: Volume of the sound.

params.name: pitch
params.documentation: Pitch adjustment of the sound.

params.name: spatialize
params.documentation: Whether the sound should be spatialized.

params.name: loop
params.documentation: Whether the sound should loop.

returns.documentation: The AudioSource through which the sound is played.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioService.PlaySo.documentation: Plays a sound effect attached to a specific GameObject, allowing for spatial audio effects.

params.name: shader
params.documentation: The AudioShader used to play the sound.

params.name: gameObject
params.documentation: The GameObject to which the sound is attached, allowing it to emit sound from its location in the game world.

params.name: volume
params.documentation: Volume at which the sound should be played.

params.name: pitch
params.documentation: Pitch adjustment for the sound, allowing for higher or lower playback tones.

params.name: spatialize
params.documentation: Whether the sound should be spatialized, giving it a position in the 3D space of the game.

returns.documentation: The AudioSource instance through which the sound is played, allowing for further manipulation.

@highrise/globaltype/AudioService.StopAu.documentation: Stops playback of an audio source.

params.name: source
params.documentation: The AudioSource instance that should be stopped.

@highrise/globaltype/PageDidChange.documentation: Event sent when page view stopped animating page change

@highrise/global/PageDidChange.documentation: Event sent when page view stopped animating page change

@highrise/globaltype/Object.documentation:
The 'Object' class serves as the foundational layer for all elements in Unity scenes. Whether building intricate environments with GameObjects, infusing functionality through Components, or enhancing realism with Unity's pre-built assets such as textures and meshes, everything stems from the root 'Object' class.

Moreover, the 'Object' class provides an interactive gateway to Unity's lifecycle events. This includes initialization of objects upon creation, updates occurring in tandem with the game's frame rate, and the clean-up processes when objects are destroyed. This understanding of the object lifecycle is pivotal in managing memory usage, performance optimisation, and orchestrating smooth gameplay sequences.

To grasp the full extent of how the 'Object' class shapes the world of Unity, head over to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Object.html) for detailed insights.

@highrise/global/Object.documentation:
The 'Object' class serves as the foundational layer for all elements in Unity scenes. Whether building intricate environments with GameObjects, infusing functionality through Components, or enhancing realism with Unity's pre-built assets such as textures and meshes, everything stems from the root 'Object' class.

Moreover, the 'Object' class provides an interactive gateway to Unity's lifecycle events. This includes initialization of objects upon creation, updates occurring in tandem with the game's frame rate, and the clean-up processes when objects are destroyed. This understanding of the object lifecycle is pivotal in managing memory usage, performance optimisation, and orchestrating smooth gameplay sequences.

To grasp the full extent of how the 'Object' class shapes the world of Unity, head over to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Object.html) for detailed insights.

@highrise/globaltype/ObjectType.DestroyI.documentation: Immediately destroys the specified Object. You are strongly recommended to use Destroy instead. This function should only be used when writing editor code because it completely bypasses Unity's normal life-cycle events. More [details here](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Object.DestroyImmediate.html).

params.name: obj
params.documentation: The Object to destroy.

@highrise/globaltype/ObjectType.Destroy.documentation: Destroys the specified Object after all frame updates have finished processing. [Learn more](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Object.Destroy.html).

params.name: obj
params.documentation: The Object to destroy.

@highrise/globaltype/ObjectType.Instanti.documentation: The 'Instantiate' method clones the object original and returns the clone. This can be immensely useful in various gameplay mechanics like respawning, shooting projectiles, etc. Learn more about Instantiate [here](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Object.Instantiate.html).

params.name: obj
params.documentation: A reference to the object to be cloned.

returns.documentation: The newly cloned object.

@highrise/globaltype/Object.GetInstanceI.documentation: The 'GetInstanceID' method provides a unique identifer for the object instance. More details about Instance IDs can be found [here.](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Object.GetInstanceID.html)

returns.documentation: The unique identifier for the object instance.

@highrise/globaltype/ObjectType.DontDest.documentation: Makes the object target not be destroyed automatically when loading a new scene, which is the default behavior. [Learn more here.](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Object.DontDestroyOnLoad.html)

params.name: target
params.documentation: The Object that should not be destroyed.

@highrise/globaltype/ObjectType.FindObje.documentation: This method returns the first active loaded object of the given type. It is a generic method with return type of the generic parameter. It returns null if no GameObject is active in the hierarchy. More details can be obtained [here](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Object.FindObjectOfType.html).

params.name: type
params.documentation: The type of the Object to find.

returns.documentation: The object found or null.

@highrise/globaltype/ObjectType.FindFirs.documentation: This method returns the first object to match the specified type, including inactive objects. It is slower than FindObjectByType, as it searches all objects in the scene, not just the active ones. [Learn more here](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Object.FindFirstObjectByType.html).

params.name: type
params.documentation: The type of Object to find.

returns.documentation: The discovered object.

@highrise/globaltype/ObjectType.FindAnyO.documentation: The 'FindAnyObjectByType' method finds all objects in the scene of the specified type, including active and inactive ones. As the method must search every single object in the scene, this operation can be performance-intensive. [Details here](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Object.FindAnyObjectByType.html).

params.name: type
params.documentation: Type of Object to find.

returns.documentation: All objects found.

@highrise/globaltype/Object.name.documentation: The name property represents the name of the Object. This could be the name you gave an asset in Unity, or the default name of a created GameObject, like 'GameObject1'. [Find out more](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Object-name.html).

@highrise/globaltype/StorageError.documentation: Contains possible error codes that can be returned from Storage functions.

@highrise/global/StorageError.documentation: Contains possible error codes that can be returned from Storage functions.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageErrorType.Re.documentation: Your world is sending requests too frequently.  The limit for GetValue is 60 + (active players * 10) requests per minute.  The limit for SetValue, IncrementValue and DeleteValue together is 60 + (active players * 10) requests per minute.  The limit for SearchValue is 10 + (active players * 5) requests per minute.  UpdateValue counts against both the GetValue and SetValue limits.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageErrorType.In.documentation: The key must be 128 characters or less.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageErrorType.Va.documentation: The maximum size for value for a value is 4mb.  The value is converted before being saved, so it will not match the value parameter's size exactly.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageErrorType.Co.documentation: The data was modified by another world instance.  If UpdateValue or UpdatePlayerValue will automatically retry when this error code is returned, if the callback receives this error code then the retry limit was exceeded.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageErrorType.Cu.documentation: The limit passed to SearchValue and SearchPlayerValue must be 100 or less.
The cursor ID passed to SearchValue or SearchPlayerValue was not valid.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageErrorType.Ti.documentation: A response from the server was not received within the time limit.

@highrise/globaltype/Behaviour.documentation: Behaviour serves as the foundational class for enabling or disabling functionality on GameObjects, acting as a base for various active components such as scripts (MonoBehaviour), physics components (Rigidbody), and renderers (MeshRenderer). It facilitates dynamic control over the active states of attached functionalities. For comprehensive information, the official Unity documentation on Behaviour is recommended.

@highrise/global/Behaviour.documentation: Behaviour serves as the foundational class for enabling or disabling functionality on GameObjects, acting as a base for various active components such as scripts (MonoBehaviour), physics components (Rigidbody), and renderers (MeshRenderer). It facilitates dynamic control over the active states of attached functionalities. For comprehensive information, the official Unity documentation on Behaviour is recommended.

@highrise/globaltype/Behaviour.enabled.documentation: Permits runtime toggling of a Behaviour's active state, affecting scripts, physics, renderers, etc.

@highrise/globaltype/Behaviour.isActiveA.documentation: Indicates whether the Behaviour is active, considering both its own state and the GameObject's activity.

@highrise/globaltype/TerrainCollider.documentation:
Walking on flat plains is easy, but what if your game's character needs to climb a hill or traverse a valley? That's where Unity's TerrainCollider comes in. Every terrain needs a Terrain Collider to interact appropriately with the game objects.

A Terrain Collider is essentially a component that gets automatically added alongside the Terrain component in Unity. It's what allows characters and objects to move on, collide, or bounce off the terrain according to the laws of physics.

Essentially, it adds a physical presence to the terrain in your Unity scenes, blocking GameObjects from passing through and enabling interactions. Without this, your terrain would just be an immaterial piece of scenery.

To understand more about how to use TerrainColliders, check the [Unity's TerrainCollider Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/TerrainCollider.html).

@highrise/global/TerrainCollider.documentation:
Walking on flat plains is easy, but what if your game's character needs to climb a hill or traverse a valley? That's where Unity's TerrainCollider comes in. Every terrain needs a Terrain Collider to interact appropriately with the game objects.

A Terrain Collider is essentially a component that gets automatically added alongside the Terrain component in Unity. It's what allows characters and objects to move on, collide, or bounce off the terrain according to the laws of physics.

Essentially, it adds a physical presence to the terrain in your Unity scenes, blocking GameObjects from passing through and enabling interactions. Without this, your terrain would just be an immaterial piece of scenery.

To understand more about how to use TerrainColliders, check the [Unity's TerrainCollider Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/TerrainCollider.html).

@highrise/globaltype/PinchGestureEnded.documentation:
When the fingers finally let go after a pinch gesture, PinchGestureEnded is what is sent through the PinchOrDragEnded event from Service.Input class. This data container class is dedicated to tracking the details of a pinch gesture at the moment it concludes.

PinchGestureEnded keeps the historical details such as the position where the pinch began, the final position, the total distance the pinch covered, and how fast the pinch was. It also computes the scale factor, depending on the distance covered by the pinch. These properties can be very useful in determining the final adjustments based on the pinch gesture in your touch-based interactions.

While important for doing post-input reactions and FX, this is less commonly used for input interactions as its counterparts Class.PinchGestureBegan and Class.PinchGestureChanged .

@highrise/global/PinchGestureEnded.documentation:
When the fingers finally let go after a pinch gesture, PinchGestureEnded is what is sent through the PinchOrDragEnded event from Service.Input class. This data container class is dedicated to tracking the details of a pinch gesture at the moment it concludes.

PinchGestureEnded keeps the historical details such as the position where the pinch began, the final position, the total distance the pinch covered, and how fast the pinch was. It also computes the scale factor, depending on the distance covered by the pinch. These properties can be very useful in determining the final adjustments based on the pinch gesture in your touch-based interactions.

While important for doing post-input reactions and FX, this is less commonly used for input interactions as its counterparts Class.PinchGestureBegan and Class.PinchGestureChanged .

@highrise/globaltype/PinchGestureEnded.d.documentation: The 'DeltaPosition' property captures the change in position of the pinch gesture from the previous frame to the end frame. This gives the final motion vector of the pinch gesture.

@highrise/globaltype/PinchGestureEnded.s.documentation: The 'StartPosition' property stores the initial position where the pinch gesture started, providing a reference point to calculate the total movement when the pinch ends.

@highrise/globaltype/PinchGestureEnded.p.documentation: The 'Position' property holds the final position of the pinch gesture right before it concluded. It's the last recorded position of the pinch.

@highrise/globaltype/PinchGestureEnded.v.documentation: The 'Velocity' property calculates the speed of the pinch gesture based on its distance and time. This is beneficial when the effect of the pinch gesture is influenced by its speed.

@highrise/globaltype/PinchGestureEnded.d.documentation: The 'Distance' property represents the total gap between the two touch points in the pinch, from the start till the end. This measures the full spread of a pinch gesture.

@highrise/globaltype/PinchGestureEnded.s.documentation: The 'Scale' property computes the final scaling factor considering the overall distance the pinch gesture covered. It comes in handy when applying the final touches in zoom or scale interaction based on pinch gesture.

@highrise/globaltype/TapHandler.documentation:
A TapHandler is a class that can be used to detect when a GameObject has been tapped.
For a GameObject to be tapped, it must have a Collider component attached to it.

@highrise/global/TapHandler.documentation:
A TapHandler is a class that can be used to detect when a GameObject has been tapped.
For a GameObject to be tapped, it must have a Collider component attached to it.

@highrise/globaltype/TapHandler.Perform.documentation:
Performs the tap action on the GameObject.
This method is called when the GameObject is tapped.
@highrise/globaltype/TapHandler.Perform.code_sample:
-- Perform the tap action on the GameObject
self.gameObject:GetComponent(TapHandler):Perform()

@highrise/globaltype/TapHandler.Tapped.documentation: Called when the GameObject is tapped.
@highrise/globaltype/TapHandler.Tapped.code_sample:
-- Connect to the Tapped event
self.gameObject:GetComponent(TapHandler).Tapped:Connect(function()
    print("Tapped")
end)

@highrise/globaltype/TapHandler.moveTo.documentation: Moves the GameObject to the specified position when it is tapped.
@highrise/globaltype/TapHandler.moveTo.code_sample:
-- Move the GameObject to the specified position when it is tapped
self.gameObject:GetComponent(TapHandler).moveTo = Vector3.New(0, 0, 0)

@highrise/globaltype/TapHandler.distance.documentation: The distance the GameObject will move when it is tapped.
@highrise/globaltype/TapHandler.distance.code_sample:
-- Set the distance the GameObject will move when it is tapped
self.gameObject:GetComponent(TapHandler).distance = 1

@highrise/globaltype/Texture.documentation:
In the realm of Unity, the Texture class serves as the cornerstone for all texture-based entities. Think of textures as the digital equivalent of wallpaper, bringing color and detail to an otherwise uniform 3D model. It's the artist's palette in the 3D modeling process that breathes visual vibrancy into your game world.

The Texture class encapsulates common properties and methods shared by all 2D textures and is the base class for more specific texture types, like Class.Texture2D, Class.Texture3D, and Cubemap textures. This unifying class offers a standardized way to modify and interact with textures, regardless of their specific type.

No matter if you're tweaking the glossiness of an alien skin, projecting a starry night on a skybox using a Cubemap, or generating a procedural labyrinth with a Texture3D, the Texture class is the common thread binding these diverse operations.

For a deeper dive into the Texture class and how this versatile tool helps paint elaborate graphics onto your Unity projects, the [official Unity Texture documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture.html) is a comprehensive resource.

@highrise/global/Texture.documentation:
In the realm of Unity, the Texture class serves as the cornerstone for all texture-based entities. Think of textures as the digital equivalent of wallpaper, bringing color and detail to an otherwise uniform 3D model. It's the artist's palette in the 3D modeling process that breathes visual vibrancy into your game world.

The Texture class encapsulates common properties and methods shared by all 2D textures and is the base class for more specific texture types, like Class.Texture2D, Class.Texture3D, and Cubemap textures. This unifying class offers a standardized way to modify and interact with textures, regardless of their specific type.

No matter if you're tweaking the glossiness of an alien skin, projecting a starry night on a skybox using a Cubemap, or generating a procedural labyrinth with a Texture3D, the Texture class is the common thread binding these diverse operations.

For a deeper dive into the Texture class and how this versatile tool helps paint elaborate graphics onto your Unity projects, the [official Unity Texture documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture.html) is a comprehensive resource.

@highrise/globaltype/Texture.IncrementUp.documentation: The 'IncrementUpdateCount' method increments the number of times the texture has been updated. Although this method is rarely used for scripting in Unity, it can be useful for advanced texture manipulation such as writing plugins or extensions. Check the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture.IncrementUpdateCount.html) for additional details.

@highrise/globaltype/TextureType.SetGlob.documentation: The 'SetGlobalAnisotropicFilteringLimits' method sets the limits for Anisotropic filtering which is a method enhancing the image quality of textures on surfaces that are far away and steeply angled with respect to the camera. The [Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture.SetGlobalAnisotropicFilteringLimits.html) provides more information.

params.name: forcedMin
params.documentation: The minimum limit for Anisotropic filtering.

params.name: globalMax
params.documentation: The maximum limit for Anisotropic filtering.

@highrise/globaltype/TextureType.SetStre.documentation: The 'SetStreamingTextureMaterialDebugProperties' method sets debug properties for streaming texture materials. More detailed information can be found in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture.SetStreamingTextureMaterialDebugProperties.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Texture.mipmapCount.documentation: The 'mipmapCount' property returns the total number of mipmap levels present in the Texture. Mipmaps are a sequence of textures, each of which is a progressively lower resolution representation of the same image. They are used to increase rendering speed and reduce aliasing effects. You can learn more from the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture-mipmapCount.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Texture.width.documentation: The 'width' property represents the width of the texture in pixels. Knowing the dimensions of your textures can be crucial when working with UV mapping and texture application. The [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture-width.html) provides additional insights into texture manipulation.

@highrise/globaltype/Texture.height.documentation: The 'height' property specifies the height of the texture in pixels. Knowing the texture dimensions can be crucial when working with texture manipulation such as UV mapping. More information can be found in the [Unity's Texture documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture-height.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Texture.isReadable.documentation: The 'isReadable' property is a boolean flag that states if the texture data can be read or not. If set to true, scripts can read the pixel data of the texture. This is important while doing any kind of processing on the texture's pixel data. You can learn more about it from the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture-isReadable.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Texture.anisoLevel.documentation: The 'anisoLevel' property sets the Anisotropic filtering level of the texture. This filtering enhances the image quality of textures on surfaces that are at oblique viewing angles. A higher anisotropic level means better texture quality at such angles. For more information, refer to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture-anisoLevel.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Texture.mipMapBias.documentation: The 'mipMapBias' property is used to adjust the mipmap level. Mipmaps are used to enhance the visual quality and rendering speed of scaled textures. This property allows for fine control over the use of mipmaps in your textures. The [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture-mipMapBias.html) provides further information.

@highrise/globaltype/Texture.texelSize.documentation: The 'texelSize' property gives the size of a single texel (texture element). It represents the world space size of a single pixel of the texture. The [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture-texelSize.html) has more detailed information.

@highrise/globaltype/Texture.updateCount.documentation: The 'updateCount' property shows how many times the texture has been updated since the scene was loaded. This can be used for debugging or profiling, to monitor how often a texture is updated. Refer to [Unity's official documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture-updateCount.html) for more details.

@highrise/globaltype/Texture.isDataSRGB.documentation: The 'isDataSRGB' property determines whether the texture data is in gamma space (sRGB) or not. Gamma space is used to correct lighting calculations in computer graphics. True if the data is sRGB, false if linear. Learn more from the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Texture-isDataSRGB.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Storage.documentation:
The Storage API provides functionality for saving and loading persistent data.  This can be used for player-specific data such as storing player progress or a high score.  This can also be used for global data for tracking the progress of all players or a global leaderboard.  The Storage API is only available on the server.  For saving a player's obtained items or currency, use the Inventory API.  See StorageError for a list of errors that can be returned from Storage functions.  There is a limit of how often Storage functions can be called before functions will start returning StorageError.RequestThrottled.  See the documentation for StorageError.RequestThrottled for details.
In Unity, the Storage file is located at `Library/localStorage`. You can open this file with a text editor to see the data stored in it.

@highrise/global/Storage.documentation:
The Storage API provides functionality for saving and loading persistent data.  This can be used for player-specific data such as storing player progress or a high score.  This can also be used for global data for tracking the progress of all players or a global leaderboard.  The Storage API is only available on the server.  For saving a player's obtained items or currency, use the Inventory API.  See StorageError for a list of errors that can be returned from Storage functions.  There is a limit of how often Storage functions can be called before functions will start returning StorageError.RequestThrottled.  See the documentation for StorageError.RequestThrottled for details.
In Unity, the Storage file is located at `Library/localStorage`. You can open this file with a text editor to see the data stored in it.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageType.GetValu.documentation: Retrieves a value from storage with the given key.  The callback parameters are the value and error code.  Value will be nil and the error code will be StorageError.None if the value does not exist.  Value will be nil and the error code will be a value other than StorageError.None if an error occurred.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageType.GetPlay.documentation: This is the equivalent of calling GetValue(player.user.id .. "/" .. key, callback).  This retrieves a value that is specific to the player.  If you want to get a global value or use a different format for the key, use GetValue instead.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageType.SetValu.documentation: Sets a value in storage with the given key.  Currently supported types are string, number, boolean, table and Vector3.  If you have a global value whose value depends on the previous value, for example a leaderboard table where new high scores are inserted between existing ones, use UpdateValue instead or else data could be lost when multiple world instances set the value at the same time.  If your value is a number that needs to be increased or decreased, use IncrementValue instead.  The callback parameter is the error code.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageType.SetPlay.documentation: This is the equivalent of calling SetValue(player.user.id .. "|" .. key, value, callback).  This sets a value that is specific to the player.  If you want to set a global value or use a different format for the key, use SetValue instead.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageType.UpdateV.documentation: UpdateValue will use GetValue to retrieve the current value, then call the modifier function with the value as a parameter.  If the value does not exist, nil will be passed to the modifier function.  UpdateValue will then use SetValue to set the value to what is returned from the modifier function.  If the modifier function returns nil, the value will not be set and the callback will be immediately called.  The modifier function may be called multiple times if other world instances have made changes to the value.  Currently supported types are string, number, boolean, table and Vector3.  The callback parameter is the error code.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageType.UpdateP.documentation: This is the equivalent of calling UpdateValue(player.user.id .. "/" .. key, modifier, callback).  This updates a value that is specific to the player.  If you want to update a global value or use a different format for the key, use UpdateValue instead.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageType.Increme.documentation: If the value for the given key is a number, it will be increased by the amount.  If the value does not exist, it will be set to the amount.  This is safe to use for global values.  The callback parameter is the error code.

This is the equivalent of calling IncrementValue(player.user.id .. "/" .. key, amount, callback).  This increments a value that is specific to the player.  If you want to increment a global value or use a different format for the key, use IncrementValue instead.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageType.DeleteV.documentation: Deletes the value with the given key from storage.  The callback parameter is the error code.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageType.DeleteP.documentation: This is the equivalent of calling DeleteValue(player.user.id .. "/" .. key, callback).  This deletes a value that is specific to the player.  If you want to delete a global value or use a different format for the key, use DeleteValue instead.

@highrise/globaltype/StorageType.SearchV.documentation: Returns up to the given limit number of the most recent values that start with the given key.  To get the first group of results, pass in nil for the cursorId.  The callback includes a cursor ID that can be passed to SearchValue to retrieve the next group of results.  If the cursor ID is nil, then there are no more results.  The callback parameters are an array of values, where each is a table with the value's name as the key and its value as the value, the cursor ID, and the error code.  The array will be empty and the error code will be StorageError.None if no values are found.  The array will be nil and the error code will be a value other than StorageError.None if an error occurred.
@highrise/globaltype/StorageType.SearchV.code_sample:
function Search(key: string, limit: number, cursorId: string)
    Storage.SearchValue(key, limit, cursorId, function(data, newCursorId, errorCode)
      if(data == nil) then
        print(`Got error {StorageError[errorCode]} while searching`)
        return
      end
      
      for index, entry in data do
        for key, value in entry do
          print(`{key} : {tostring(value)}`)
        end
      end
      
      if(newCursorId ~= nil) then
        Search(key, limit, newCursorId)
      else
        print("done")
      end
    end)
  end
  Search("scores/", 10)

@highrise/globaltype/StorageType.SearchP.documentation: This is the equivalent of calling SearchValue(player.user.id .. "/" .. key, callback).  This searches for values that are specific to the player.  If you want to search for global values or use a different format for the key, use SearchValue instead.
@highrise/globaltype/StorageType.SearchP.code_sample:
function self:ServerStart()
    scene.PlayerJoined:Connect(function(scene, player)
      Storage.SearchPlayerValue(player, "scores/", 10, nil, function(data, newCursorId, errorCode)
        if(data == nil) then
          print(`Got error {StorageError[errorCode]} while searching`)
          return
        end
        
        for index, entry in data do
          for key, value in entry do
            print(`{key} : {tostring(value)}`)
          end
        end
        
        if(newCursorId ~= nil) then
          Storage.SearchPlayerValue(player, "scores/", 10, newCursorId)
        else
          print("done")
        end
      end)
    end)
  end

@highrise/globaltype/GameServer.documentation:
In Highrise's scripting environment, the GameServer class acts as the high-level game context the script is running remotely. Any server-level interaction or manipulation will be found in this class. Specifically, scripts marked 'Server' or 'Client and Server' can access server - with 'Client and Server' scripts requiring you to check if `server` is not nil (or `client` is nil).

Any high-level server events and interactions will be found in this type.

@highrise/global/GameServer.documentation:
In Highrise's scripting environment, the GameServer class acts as the high-level game context the script is running remotely. Any server-level interaction or manipulation will be found in this class. Specifically, scripts marked 'Server' or 'Client and Server' can access server - with 'Client and Server' scripts requiring you to check if `server` is not nil (or `client` is nil).

Any high-level server events and interactions will be found in this type.

This mechanism allows developers to trigger specific actions in response to a player's connection. Note that this is not when the player's Class.Avatar is spawned. For avatar spawn, see Class.Player when in a Class.GameClient side script.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.documentation: TrailRenderer is a Unity component that creates visually appealing trails behind moving objects, like the tail of a comet streaking through the sky. These trails can enhance the realism of fast-paced games or add visual flair to various effects. Dive into the [Unity's TrailRenderer Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/TrailRenderer.html) to explore its capabilities in more detail.

@highrise/global/TrailRenderer.documentation: TrailRenderer is a Unity component that creates visually appealing trails behind moving objects, like the tail of a comet streaking through the sky. These trails can enhance the realism of fast-paced games or add visual flair to various effects. Dive into the [Unity's TrailRenderer Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/TrailRenderer.html) to explore its capabilities in more detail.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.time.documentation: Retrieves or sets the duration in seconds that the trail takes to fade away completely.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.start.documentation: Determines the starting width of the trail at its base.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.endWi.documentation: Specifies the ending width of the trail at its tip.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.width.documentation: Scales the width of the trail uniformly.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.autod.documentation: Enables or disables automatic destruction of the trail renderer when it finishes emitting particles.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.emitt.documentation: Indicates whether the trail renderer is currently emitting particles.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.numCo.documentation: Sets the number of vertices to use for each corner of the trail.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.numCa.documentation: Specifies the number of vertices for each cap of the trail.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.minVe.documentation: Defines the minimum distance between consecutive vertices in the trail.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.start.documentation: Determines the color of the trail at its start.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.endCo.documentation: Specifies the color of the trail at its end.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.posit.documentation: Provides the number of positions in the trail's vertex array.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.textu.documentation: Sets the tiling of the trail's texture along its length.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.shado.documentation: Adjusts the distance of the shadow cast by the trail from the visible geometry.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.gener.documentation: Enables or disables the generation of lighting data for the trail.

@highrise/globaltype/TrailRenderer.width.documentation: Defines a curve that modifies the width of the trail along its length.
