@highrise/globaltype/Material.documentation:
Imagine your game's 3D models as a stage, the Material class in Unity is the set designer, impacting the look and feel of the stage by determining how light interacts with the models. It influences their appearance, creating the essential visual ambiance of your game world.

This class enables you to manipulate properties of materials used in rendering both 2D and 3D graphics. Whether it's to give a shiny metallic texture to a robot, a semi-transparent glaze to a ghostly apparition, or make a surface react to light in a specific way, the Material class aids in achieving these visual effects.

Being a fundamental part of shader programming - the magic behind the colors, lighting effects, and textures in your game, the Material class is an indispensable tool in Unity. To have a comprehensive understanding of how to leverage it to enrich the aesthetics of your game environment, the [official Unity Material Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.html) is your go-to guide.

@highrise/global/Material.documentation:
Imagine your game's 3D models as a stage, the Material class in Unity is the set designer, impacting the look and feel of the stage by determining how light interacts with the models. It influences their appearance, creating the essential visual ambiance of your game world.

This class enables you to manipulate properties of materials used in rendering both 2D and 3D graphics. Whether it's to give a shiny metallic texture to a robot, a semi-transparent glaze to a ghostly apparition, or make a surface react to light in a specific way, the Material class aids in achieving these visual effects.

Being a fundamental part of shader programming - the magic behind the colors, lighting effects, and textures in your game, the Material class is an indispensable tool in Unity. To have a comprehensive understanding of how to leverage it to enrich the aesthetics of your game environment, the [official Unity Material Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.html) is your go-to guide.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.HasPropert.documentation: The 'HasProperty' method checks whether the material has a property with a given name. This can be useful to prevent errors before trying to set or get a property. Learn more by checking [Unity's Material.HasProperty Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.HasProperty.html).

params.name: nameID
params.documentation: The identifier for the property you are checking for.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the property exists; otherwise, false.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.HasFloat.documentation: The 'HasFloat' method checks if the material has a specific float property. This is useful to prevent errors before attempting to access a float property. More details can be obtained from [Unity's Material.HasFloat Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.HasFloat.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the float property to check.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the float property exists; otherwise, false.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.HasInt.documentation: 'HasInt' method checks whether the material has a specific integer property. This is useful when working with a custom shader that may or may not have specific properties. For more extensive information, visit [Unity's Material.HasInt Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.HasInt.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the integer property to check.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the integer property exists; otherwise, false.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.HasInteger.documentation: The 'HasInteger' method checks if the material has a specific integer property. This is useful when dealing with custom shaders that may or may not have specific properties. To learn more about this method, check [Unity's Material.HasInteger Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.HasInteger.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name for the integer property to check.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the integer property exists; otherwise, false.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.HasTexture.documentation: 'HasTexture' is a method that checks if the material has a specific texture property. This is handy to avoid errors when trying to access a texture property. More information can be found in [Unity's Material.HasTexture Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.HasTexture.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the texture property to check.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the texture property exists; otherwise, false.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.HasMatrix.documentation: The 'HasMatrix' method checks if the material has a specific matrix property. It's useful in preventing errors when trying to access a matrix property. To learn more, refer to [Unity's Material.HasMatrix Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.HasMatrix.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the matrix property to check.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the matrix property exists; otherwise, false.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.HasVector.documentation: 'HasVector' method checks if a specific vector property exists in the material. This can help in preventing errors when trying to access this property. More information can be found in [Unity's Material.HasVector Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.HasVector.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the vector property to check.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the vector property exists; otherwise, false.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.HasColor.documentation: The 'HasColor' method is used to check if the material has a certain color property. This is done before getting or setting a color property to avoid errors. Find out more about color properties in [Unity's Material.HasColor Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.HasColor.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the color property to check.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the color property exists; false otherwise.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.HasBuffer.documentation: The 'HasBuffer' method verifies if the material has a particular buffer property. This is useful when dealing with advanced rendering techniques that involve ComputeBuffers or GraphicsBuffers. Learn more from [Unity's Material.HasBuffer Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.HasBuffer.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the buffer property to check.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the buffer property exists; false otherwise.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.HasConstan.documentation: The 'HasConstantBuffer' method checks if the material has a specific constant buffer property. This can be important in high-end graphics where constant buffers are used to hold resources for shaders. More info can be obtained from [Unity's Material.HasConstantBuffer Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.HasConstantBuffer.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the constant buffer property to check.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the constant buffer property exists; false otherwise.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.EnableKeyw.documentation: The 'EnableKeyword' method allows you to enable a specific shader keyword for this material. This can be used for activating certain behavior of a multi-feature shader. You can find more information in [Unity's Material.EnableKeyword Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.EnableKeyword.html).

params.name: keyword
params.documentation: The keyword to enable for this material.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.DisableKey.documentation: 'DisableKeyword' is a method that allows you to disable certain shader keywords on this material. This can be used to switch off specific features of a multi-purpose shader. To learn more, refer to [Unity's Material.DisableKeyword Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.DisableKeyword.html).

params.name: keyword
params.documentation: The keyword to disable for this material.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.IsKeywordE.documentation: The 'IsKeywordEnabled' method checks if a specific shader keyword is enabled for this material. This can be used to verify the state of a feature of a multi-function shader. Learn more by checking the [Unity's Material.IsKeywordEnabled Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.IsKeywordEnabled.html).

params.name: keyword
params.documentation: The keyword to check for this material.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the keyword is enabled; false otherwise.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.SetShaderP.documentation: The 'SetShaderPassEnabled' method enables or disables a specific Shader pass on the material. This offers more control over the rendering process, which can be useful for complex materials or advanced rendering techniques. For more information, see the [Unity's Material.SetShaderPassEnabled Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.SetShaderPassEnabled.html).

params.name: passName
params.documentation: The name of the Shader pass to enable or disable.

params.name: enabled
params.documentation: Whether the Shader pass should be enabled.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.GetShaderP.documentation: The 'GetShaderPassEnabled' method gets the status (enabled/disabled) of a specific Shader pass on the material. This can be used to check how the material is being drawn, which is helpful when understanding complex materials or rendering techniques. Instructions for how to use the method can be found in [Unity's Material.GetShaderPassEnabled Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.GetShaderPassEnabled.html).

params.name: passName
params.documentation: The name of the Shader pass whose status will be returned.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the Shader pass is enabled, false if it's not.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.GetPassNam.documentation: The 'GetPassName' method fetches the name of a particular pass from a material. A pass in Unity represents a single rendering step, and knowing their names can be useful when dealing with complex rendering logic. Find out more from [Unity's Material.GetPassName Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.GetPassName.html).

params.name: pass
params.documentation: The index of the pass to fetch the name from.

returns.documentation: The name of the pass.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.FindPass.documentation: The 'FindPass' method retrieves the index of a pass by its name. This can be helpful when dealing with complex rendering pipelines where specific passes need to be identified and modified. More details can be found in [Unity's Material.FindPass Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.FindPass.html).

params.name: passName
params.documentation: The name of the pass to find the index of.

returns.documentation: The index of the pass, or -1 if the pass doesn't exist.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.SetOverrid.documentation: The 'SetOverrideTag' method overrides or sets a shader tag for this material. Shader tags in Unity are used to determine how to render an object, and overriding them can help achieve unique rendering effects for particular materials. You can learn more in [Unity's Material.SetOverrideTag Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.SetOverrideTag.html).

params.name: tag
params.documentation: The tag to be overridden in this material.

params.name: val
params.documentation: The value to set for the overridden tag.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.GetTag.documentation: The 'GetTag' method retrieves the value of a shader tag from this material, providing more control over the rendering process. If the specified tag does not exist, a fallback value can be provided. For more information, check [Unity's Material.GetTag Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.GetTag.html).

params.name: tag
params.documentation: The name of the shader tag to retrieve.

params.name: searchFallbacks
params.documentation: Whether to look in the shader's fallbacks if the tag isn't found.

params.name: defaultValue
params.documentation: The value to return if the specified tag isn't found.

returns.documentation: The value of the shader tag if it exists; otherwise, the defaultValue.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.Lerp.documentation: The 'Lerp' method linearly interpolates between two Materials based on t parameter and applies the result to this Material. It's useful to blend between different materials dynamically, creating a transition effect. More details are in [Unity's Material.Lerp Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.Lerp.html).

params.name: start
params.documentation: The start Material for the Lerp operation.

params.name: end
params.documentation: The end Material for the Lerp operation.

params.name: t
params.documentation: The Lerp weighting factor.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.SetPass.documentation: 'SetPass' activates a given Shader Pass for rendering current object. It's used to set a particular pass in the material’s shader to the rendering hardware. More information can be found in [Unity's Material.SetPass Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.SetPass.html).

params.name: pass
params.documentation: The index of the pass to set.

returns.documentation: If the shader or pass is not valid, this function will return false; otherwise, it returns true.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.CopyProper.documentation: The 'CopyPropertiesFromMaterial' method copies properties from specified material to current material. This is helpful when you need to create a new material with the same properties as an existing one. Find more details in [Unity's Material.CopyPropertiesFromMaterial Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.CopyPropertiesFromMaterial.html).

params.name: mat
params.documentation: The source material to copy properties from.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.CopyMatchi.documentation: 'CopyMatchingPropertiesFromMaterial' copies properties from another material that match with properties of the current material. This can be useful for duplicating only the relevant properties from another material. [Unity's Material.CopyMatchingPropertiesFromMaterial Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.CopyMatchingPropertiesFromMaterial.html) provides more information.

params.name: mat
params.documentation: The source material to copy matching properties from.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.ComputeCRC.documentation: The 'ComputeCRC' method computes a cyclic redundancy check value for the material. This can be useful for comparing materials or for caching materials without storing them entirely. More details can be found in [Unity's Material.ComputeCRC Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.ComputeCRC.html).

returns.documentation: Returns the calculated CRC value.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.SetInt.documentation: 'SetInt' method sets an integer property in the material. This can be used to interact with integer properties defined in the shader used by the material. More information can be found in [Unity's Material.SetInt Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.SetInt.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the property to set.

params.name: value
params.documentation: The integer value to set the property to.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.SetFloat.documentation: 'SetFloat' is a method used to set a float property in the material. It is typically used to interact with float properties defined in the shader used by the material. Learn more about this method in [Unity's Material.SetFloat Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.SetFloat.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the property to set.

params.name: value
params.documentation: The float value to set the property to.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.SetInteger.documentation: The 'SetInteger' method is used to set an integer property in the material. It can be used to interact with integer properties defined in the shader used by the material. Detailed information can be found in [Unity's Material.SetInteger Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.SetInteger.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the property to set.

params.name: value
params.documentation: The integer value to set the property to.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.SetColor.documentation: The 'SetColor' method sets a color property in the material. This can be used to change the color of the material at runtime, allowing for dynamic visual effects. Refer to [Unity's Material.SetColor Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.SetColor.html) for more details.

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name for the color property to set.

params.name: value
params.documentation: The color value to set the property to.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.SetVector.documentation: The 'SetVector' method sets a Vector4 property in the material. This can be very useful when applying transformations or other operations that can be done through vector properties of a shader. Find more details in [Unity's Material.SetVector Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.SetVector.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the Vector4 property to set.

params.name: value
params.documentation: The Vector4 value to set the property to.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.SetMatrix.documentation: 'SetMatrix' is a method that sets a Matrix4x4 property in the material. This can be used to affect transformations or other matrix operations within the shader used by the material. For a better understanding, refer to [Unity's Material.SetMatrix Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.SetMatrix.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the Matrix4x4 property to set.

params.name: value
params.documentation: The Matrix4x4 value to set the property to.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.SetTexture.documentation: The 'SetTexture' method assigns a texture to a named property within a shader. It can be used to dynamically change the textures used by a material at runtime. The details can be found in [Unity's Material.SetTexture Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.SetTexture.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the texture property to set.

params.name: value
params.documentation: The Texture object to use.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.GetInt.documentation: The 'GetInt' method retrieves the integer value of a named property in a material. It is mainly used when we need a specific integer property for calculations or conditions. Refer to [Unity's Material.GetInt Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.GetInt.html) for more information.

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the integer property to retrieve.

returns.documentation: The integer value of the specified property.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.GetFloat.documentation: The 'GetFloat' method fetches the float value of a named property within a material. This method is often used when working with float properties of a shader that are needed for mathematical operations. You can find more details in [Unity's Material.GetFloat Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.GetFloat.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the float property to retrieve.

returns.documentation: The float value of the given property.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.GetInteger.documentation: The 'GetInteger' method gets the integer value of a named property in a material. This can be useful when working with shader properties that represent quantifiable data or entries in an array. See [Unity's Material.GetInteger Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.GetInteger.html) for more information.

params.name: name
params.documentation: The property name to retrieve the integer value from.

returns.documentation: The integer value of the specified property.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.GetColor.documentation: The 'GetColor' method fetches the color value of a named property from a material. The retrieved color can be used in various ways such as coloring other elements or calculations affecting color data. More details are in [Unity's Material.GetColor Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.GetColor.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the property to retrieve the color from.

returns.documentation: The Color value of the specified property.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.GetVector.documentation: The 'GetVector' method retrieves the Vector4 value of a named property in a material. This can be useful when dealing with vector properties of a shader. You can learn more about it from [Unity's Material.GetVector Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.GetVector.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The property name to retrieve the Vector4 value from.

returns.documentation: The Vector4 value of the specified property.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.GetMatrix.documentation: The 'GetMatrix' method fetches the Matrix4x4 value of a named property in a material. This can be useful when manipulating transformations or other matrix operations within the shader used by the material. For an expanded explanation, see [Unity's Material.GetMatrix Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.GetMatrix.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the Matrix4x4 property to retrieve.

returns.documentation: The Matrix4x4 value of the specified property.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.GetTexture.documentation: 'GetTexture' is a method that retrieves the texture mapped to a named property within a material. This allows you to access and potentially change the texture used by a material at runtime. More information is available in [Unity's Material.GetTexture Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.GetTexture.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the property to retrieve the texture from.

returns.documentation: The Texture object currently in use by the material.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.SetTexture.documentation: The 'SetTextureOffset' method adjusts the texture coordinates of a material, effectively shifting the texture. This can be useful for creating effects like scrolling textures. More information can be found in [Unity's Material.SetTextureOffset Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.SetTextureOffset.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The property name to which Texture offset will be applied.

params.name: value
params.documentation: The amount of texture offset to apply.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.SetTexture.documentation: 'SetTextureScale' adjusts the scaling of the texture coordinates of a material, effectively altering the tiling of the texture. This feature can be used for various visual effects, like magnifying or shrinking the appearance of a texture. Refer to [Unity's Material.SetTextureScale Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.SetTextureScale.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The property name to which Texture scaling will be applied.

params.name: value
params.documentation: The amount of texture scaling to apply.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.GetTexture.documentation: The 'GetTextureOffset' method retrieves the current texture offset of a property. This can be used to ascertain the current texture offset applied to a material. More info can be found in [Unity's Material.GetTextureOffset Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.GetTextureOffset.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the property to get the texture offset from.

returns.documentation: The current texture offset of the material's property.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.GetTexture.documentation: The 'GetTextureScale' method gets the current texture tiling of a property. This can be used in your project to determine the scaling factor applied to the texture of a material. See more in [Unity's Material.GetTextureScale Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material.GetTextureScale.html).

params.name: name
params.documentation: The name of the property to get the texture scale from.

returns.documentation: The current texture tiling of the material's property.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.new.documentation: The constructor 'new' produces a new instance of the Material class, typically for the purpose of creating custom materials. Detailed description can be found in [Unity's Material.new Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material-ctor.html).

params.name: source
params.documentation: This parameter represents a Material object to copy properties from.

returns.documentation: Returns a new instance of the Material class.

@highrise/globaltype/Material.color.documentation: The 'color' property allows to set or retrieve the main color of the material. Changing this property can drastically affect the look of the rendered object. Further information can be found in [Unity's Material.color Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material-color.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Material.mainTextur.documentation: 'mainTexture' property is used to apply or get the primary texture of the material. It allows to give detail to a GameObject by applying images to it. Explore more about this property in [Unity's Material.mainTexture Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material-mainTexture.html).

The 'mainTextureOffset' attribute allows to adjust the placement of the primary texture on the rendered object. It can be used to create various visual effects. More information can be found in [Unity's Material.mainTextureOffset Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material-mainTextureOffset.html).

The 'mainTextureScale' property adjusts the size of the primary texture on the object, allowing for shrinking or stretching of the texture. More details in [Unity's Material.mainTextureScale Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material-mainTextureScale.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Material.renderQueu.documentation: The 'renderQueue' property allows adjusting the place of the material in the renderer's queue. Manipulating this property can result in some objects rendering in front of or behind others. Learn more by consulting [Unity's Material.renderQueue Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material-renderQueue.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Material.doubleSide.documentation: The 'doubleSidedGI' property enables or disables the illumination of the back-faces of the Game object, impacting how light is reflected in the scene. You can learn more Indirect lighting details in [Unity's Material.doubleSidedGI Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material-doubleSidedGI.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Material.enableInst.documentation: The 'enableInstancing' property when set to true, instructs Unity to use GPU instancing. This can provide a performance boost when drawing many identical geometries that share the same material. More information in [Unity's Material.enableInstancing Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material-enableInstancing.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Material.passCount.documentation: The 'passCount' property gives the number of SubShader rendering passes in this material. Useful for fine grained control over complex shaders and rendering techniques. More info in [Unity's Material.passCount Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Material-passCount.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.documentation:
The 'Transform' class in Unity is the invisible puppet master that dictates where and how GameObjects exist within the game's spatial dimension. It's a control hub for manipulating the position, rotation, and scale of GameObjects, and where they fit into the game scene's hierarchy.

Think of GameObjects as characters on a theatre stage - While components like Mesh and Material determine what the characters look like, 'Transform' is the stage director, instructing them where to be, which way to face, and how large their presence is. The position of a GameObject sets its location in 3D space, the rotation controls the direction the object is facing, and the scale dictates the size of the GameObject. Including local and global space settings, 'Transform' caters for both simple and complex movements, rotations, and scaling.

Not just limited to single GameObjects, 'Transform' also enables hierarchy settings for GameObject relationships, like setting one GameObject as the child of another. These relationships form a tree-like hierarchy, useful for establishing parent-child associations, managing grouped objects, or creating complex GameObject structures.

The positioning and movement of game elements are core to creating an interactive and engaging gaming experience. The 'Transform' class is therefore the lynchpin to most scripting operations in Unity. To explore more about 'Transform' and its effective use in Unity, the [official Unity Transform documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.html) is a great learning material.

@highrise/global/Transform.documentation:
The 'Transform' class in Unity is the invisible puppet master that dictates where and how GameObjects exist within the game's spatial dimension. It's a control hub for manipulating the position, rotation, and scale of GameObjects, and where they fit into the game scene's hierarchy.

Think of GameObjects as characters on a theatre stage - While components like Mesh and Material determine what the characters look like, 'Transform' is the stage director, instructing them where to be, which way to face, and how large their presence is. The position of a GameObject sets its location in 3D space, the rotation controls the direction the object is facing, and the scale dictates the size of the GameObject. Including local and global space settings, 'Transform' caters for both simple and complex movements, rotations, and scaling.

Not just limited to single GameObjects, 'Transform' also enables hierarchy settings for GameObject relationships, like setting one GameObject as the child of another. These relationships form a tree-like hierarchy, useful for establishing parent-child associations, managing grouped objects, or creating complex GameObject structures.

The positioning and movement of game elements are core to creating an interactive and engaging gaming experience. The 'Transform' class is therefore the lynchpin to most scripting operations in Unity. To explore more about 'Transform' and its effective use in Unity, the [official Unity Transform documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.html) is a great learning material.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.LookAt.documentation: The 'LookAt' method makes the GameObject rotate towards a target. This method is ideal in contexts where the GameObject needs to continually face another, for example, a GameObject camera following a character. For more details, refer to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.LookAt.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.SetParent.documentation: The 'SetParent' method is used to set the parent of the GameObject's transform. It's handy when you need to dynamically create parent-child relationships between GameObjects. For further understanding, refer to the [official Unity Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.SetParent.html).

params.name: p
params.documentation: The target parent Transform.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.SetPositi.documentation: The 'SetPositionAndRotation' method simultaneously changes the position and rotation of the GameObject. This method is more efficient than changing position and rotation separately. For more details, check out the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.SetPositionAndRotation.html).

params.name: position
params.documentation: The new position for the GameObject.

params.name: rotation
params.documentation: The new rotation for the GameObject.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.SetLocalP.documentation: The 'SetLocalPositionAndRotation' method updates the local position and local rotation of the GameObject simultaneously. It's useful when you have colocated GameObjects and need to change their positions and rotations relative to their parent. Visit [Unity's official documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.SetLocalPositionAndRotation.html) for more details.

params.name: localPosition
params.documentation: The new local position for the GameObject.

params.name: localRotation
params.documentation: The new local rotation for the GameObject.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.RotateAro.documentation: The 'RotateAround' method rotates the GameObject around a specific point by a given angle and along a specified axis. This method is quite useful when you want to make a GameObject revolve around a certain point. For better understanding, check the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.RotateAround.html).

params.name: point
params.documentation: The point around which the GameObject will rotate.

params.name: axis
params.documentation: The axis along which the GameObject will rotate.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.Transform.documentation: The 'TransformDirection' method transforms a direction from local space to world space. This method can be useful when you want a locally defined direction to be meaningful in the world space. More information can be found in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.TransformDirection.html).

params.name: direction
params.documentation: The local direction to transform to world direction.

returns.documentation: The direction in world space.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.InverseTr.documentation: The 'InverseTransformDirection' transforms a direction from world space to local space. This often becomes valuable when you want a world direction to be expressed relative to the local space of a GameObject. Check out the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.InverseTransformDirection.html) for more insights.

params.name: direction
params.documentation: The world direction to transform to local direction.

returns.documentation: The direction in local space.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.Transform.documentation: The 'TransformVector' method transforms a local Vector to world Vector. It considers the GameObject's rotation and scale in transforming the vector. For additional context, see the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.TransformVector.html).

params.name: vector
params.documentation: The local Vector3 to transform.

returns.documentation: The transformed Vector3 in world space.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.InverseTr.documentation: The 'InverseTransformVector' does the opposite of 'TransformVector'. It transforms a Vector from world space to local space. This method is primarily useful when you need a globally defined vector to be meaningful in the local space of a GameObject. For more context, refer to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.InverseTransformVector.html).

params.name: vector
params.documentation: The world Vector3 to transform.

returns.documentation: The transformed Vector3 in local space.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.Transform.documentation: The 'TransformPoint' transforms Position from local to world space. It takes into account the GameObject's position, rotation, and scale. More information about how to use this method can be found in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.TransformPoint.html).

params.name: position
params.documentation: The local position to transform.

returns.documentation: The transformed Position in world space.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.InverseTr.documentation: The 'InverseTransformPoint' transforms a position from world to local space. This method is handy when you want a globally defined position to be expressed relative to the local space of a GameObject. Refer to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.InverseTransformPoint.html) to understand more about its functionality.

params.name: position
params.documentation: The world position to transform.

returns.documentation: The transformed Position in local space.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.DetachChi.documentation: The 'DetachChildren' method unparents all the child GameObjects of the GameObject. This means those GameObjects will no longer receive any transformations from their parent. Check out the [official Unity Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.DetachChildren.html) for more context.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.SetAsFirs.documentation: The 'SetAsFirstSibling' method moves the Transform to the beginning of the local transform list. This causes the GameObject to be rendered behind its siblings. Further details can be found in the [Unity Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.SetAsFirstSibling.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.SetAsLast.documentation: The 'SetAsLastSibling' method moves the Transform to the end of the local transform list. It results in the GameObject being rendered in front of its siblings. More information can be found in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.SetAsLastSibling.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.SetSiblin.documentation: The 'SetSiblingIndex' method allows you to alter the sibling index. It changes the sibling order of the GameObject in the hierarchy and impacts the rendering order of GameObjects. You can find more details on the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.SetSiblingIndex.html).

params.name: index
params.documentation: The new index for the GameObject.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.GetSiblin.documentation: The 'GetSiblingIndex' method retrieves the sibling index of the GameObject, helping to understand the order in which GameObjects are displayed. More contextual insights can be found in the [official Unity Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.GetSiblingIndex.html).

returns.documentation: The current index of the GameObject.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.Find.documentation: The 'Find' method allows you to search for a child GameObject by its name. It is particularly useful when you need to access a specific child but do not have a reference to it. Be aware that this method is not optimal for regular use. If the child GameObject needs to be accessed frequently, it's less expensive to get a reference to that GameObject during initialization. Check out the [official Unity Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.Find.html) to learn more.

params.name: n
params.documentation: The name of the child GameObject to find.

returns.documentation: The transform of the found child GameObject.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.IsChildOf.documentation: The 'IsChildOf' method checks if a transform is a child of a particular parent. It's a straightforward and useful way to identify relationships between GameObjects, like whether a specific GameObject is a part of a hierarchy. More details can be found in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.IsChildOf.html).

params.name: parent
params.documentation: The parent Transform to check against.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the Transform is a child of parent, false otherwise.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.GetChild.documentation: The 'GetChild' method retrieves a child Transform by index. It can be tremendously useful when iterating over children in a parent-child hierarchy. Be aware that the Transform's sibling order also represents their order in the hierarchy. For more context, refer to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform.GetChild.html).

params.name: index
params.documentation: The index of the child Transform to retrieve.

returns.documentation: The child Transform retrieved from the index.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.position.documentation: This property represents the position of the GameObject in world space coordinates. It can be used to get or set the current position of your GameObject. For more details, refer to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-position.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.localPosi.documentation: 'localPosition' refers to the position of the GameObject relative to its parent GameObject. This property is useful when you want to arrange GameObjects in a hierarchical nested structure. Additional details can be found in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-localPosition.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.eulerAngl.documentation: The 'eulerAngles' property represents the rotation of the GameObject in degrees around the x, y, and z axes. The angles are measured in a specific order: z, x, and then y. Refer to the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-eulerAngles.html) to learn more.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.localEule.documentation: The 'localEulerAngles' property provides a way to get or set the local rotation (relative to the parent GameObject) of the GameObject in terms of Euler angles. More details can be found in the [official Unity Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-localEulerAngles.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.right.documentation: The 'right' property represents the red axis of the GameObject and points in the direction of increasing x. This gives directions along the x-axis. Additional details in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-right.html) can provide more contextual understanding.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.up.documentation: The 'up' property represents the green axis of the GameObject and it points in the direction of increasing y. In other words, this property provides directions along the y-axis. More information can be found in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-up.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.forward.documentation: The 'forward' property corresponds to the blue axis of the GameObject and points in the direction of increasing z. This gives directions along the z-axis. Additional details can be found in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-forward.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.rotation.documentation: A Quaternion representing the orientation in space of the GameObject. Please note that for setting, it is better to use 'eulerAngles' as this property does not offer a degree of freedom. Further information can be found in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-rotation.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.localRota.documentation: The 'localRotation' represents the rotation of the GameObject relative to the parent GameObject's rotation, as Quaternion. Further details can be found in the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-localRotation.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.localScal.documentation: The 'localScale' property enables you to get or set the scale of a GameObject relative to its parent GameObject. You can manipulate this property to resize GameObjects dynamically. For more information, see the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-localScale.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.parent.documentation: The 'parent' property provides a way to get or set the parent of this GameObject. It's particularly useful for managing GameObject hierarchies. Check out the [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-parent.html) for more information.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.worldToLo.documentation: The 'worldToLocalMatrix' is a matrix that transforms a point from world space into local space (i.e., relative to the GameObject). To understand more about this property, refer to the [Unity Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-worldToLocalMatrix.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.localToWo.documentation: The 'localToWorldMatrix' is the matrix that transforms a point from local space (i.e., relative to the object) into world space. More context can be found in the [Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-localToWorldMatrix.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.root.documentation: The 'root' property gives you the topmost transform in the hierarchy of the GameObject. Essentially, it retrieves the root GameObject that this GameObject is attached to. It's especially useful in large hierarchies. Refer to the [Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-root.html) for more details.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.childCoun.documentation: The 'childCount' provides you with the number of children the Transform has. It can be handy when you are dealing with GameObject hierarchies and need to manage multiple child GameObjects. More details in the [Unity Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-childCount.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.lossyScal.documentation: The 'lossyScale' provides the global scale of the GameObject, which is the product of all parent scales combined with this GameObject’s local scale. It's a read-only value and gives the actual rendered scale of the GameObject. To understand its use, check the [Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-lossyScale.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.hasChange.documentation: The 'hasChanged' property is a flag that indicates whether the transform's position or rotation has changed since the last frame. It’s handy for optimizing code as you can skip processing for static GameObjects. Remember to reset the flag manually after reading it. Check out the [Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-hasChanged.html) for more details.

@highrise/globaltype/Transform.hierarchy.documentation: The 'hierarchyCapacity' property denotes the number of allocated transforms in the hierarchy data structure. Developers can adjust this capacity to optimize memory usage and performance. Visit the [Unity Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-hierarchyCapacity.html) for more details.

The 'hierarchyCount' property provides the current number of Transforms in the Transform's hierarchy data structure. This data may be used alongside 'hierarchyCapacity' to optimize game performance. To understand more, visit the [Unity Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Transform-hierarchyCount.html).

@highrise/globaltype/BoolValue.documentation: BoolValue class stores a single boolean value, extending from Class.Value. It's designed for synchronizing a boolean value across all clients in a networked environment, ensuring consistency of a specific flag or state, such as a game over condition. To effectively utilize BoolValue, familiarity with the base Class.Value documentation is advised.

@highrise/global/BoolValue.documentation: BoolValue class stores a single boolean value, extending from Class.Value. It's designed for synchronizing a boolean value across all clients in a networked environment, ensuring consistency of a specific flag or state, such as a game over condition. To effectively utilize BoolValue, familiarity with the base Class.Value documentation is advised.

@highrise/globaltype/BoolValueType.new.documentation: Creates a new BoolValue instance with a specified name and initial value, used for unique identification and initial state setting across clients.

params.name: name
params.documentation: Unique name for the BoolValue, serving as a key for synchronization.

params.name: initialValue
params.documentation: Initial boolean value of the BoolValue.

returns.documentation: An instance of BoolValue with the provided initial value.

@highrise/globaltype/BoolValue.value.documentation: Represents the synchronized boolean value. Changes trigger notifications across clients via the Value.Changed event.

@highrise/globaltype/PressGesture.documentation: Gesture detect when a single finger is pressed on an element and then removed.

@highrise/global/PressGesture.documentation: Gesture detect when a single finger is pressed on an element and then removed.

@highrise/globaltype/BoxCollider.documentation: BoxCollider is an invisible, box-shaped component that defines the physical boundaries for GameObject interactions, crucial for collision detection and physical simulations. Ideal for simple, axis-aligned shapes like crates or buildings, it can be used with Rigidbody for physics-based interactions or for event triggering areas. It allows for specifying position and dimensions relative to the GameObject it's attached to. For comprehensive understanding, the official Unity BoxCollider documentation is recommended.

@highrise/global/BoxCollider.documentation: BoxCollider is an invisible, box-shaped component that defines the physical boundaries for GameObject interactions, crucial for collision detection and physical simulations. Ideal for simple, axis-aligned shapes like crates or buildings, it can be used with Rigidbody for physics-based interactions or for event triggering areas. It allows for specifying position and dimensions relative to the GameObject it's attached to. For comprehensive understanding, the official Unity BoxCollider documentation is recommended.

@highrise/globaltype/BoxCollider.center.documentation: Specifies the BoxCollider's position relative to the GameObject's local coordinates, enabling offset adjustments.

@highrise/globaltype/BoxCollider.size.documentation: Adjusts the BoxCollider's dimensions within the GameObject's local space, suitable for aligning the collider accurately with the GameObject.

@highrise/globaltype/MeshRenderer.documentation:
In Unity's toolbox, the MeshRenderer is akin to a paintbrush which 'draws' the 3D objects onto the screen. It is a crucial component class within Unity's render system, taking the raw geometry data from the Mesh Filter and using it to render the object onto the game's window.

Working interdependently with the object's Class.Transform component, the MeshRenderer displays the 3D graphics at the precise position, rotation, and scale defined by the Transform. Additionally, it features the capability to tweak a GameObject's Material properties, allowing developers to adjust the visual appearance of their objects.

The partnership between MeshRenderer and Mesh Filter is fundamental to Unity's method of rendering 3D objects. For in-depth insights into how you can wield the MeshRenderer to influence the visual aesthetics of your game, dive into the [official Unity MeshRenderer Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/MeshRenderer.html).

@highrise/global/MeshRenderer.documentation:
In Unity's toolbox, the MeshRenderer is akin to a paintbrush which 'draws' the 3D objects onto the screen. It is a crucial component class within Unity's render system, taking the raw geometry data from the Mesh Filter and using it to render the object onto the game's window.

Working interdependently with the object's Class.Transform component, the MeshRenderer displays the 3D graphics at the precise position, rotation, and scale defined by the Transform. Additionally, it features the capability to tweak a GameObject's Material properties, allowing developers to adjust the visual appearance of their objects.

The partnership between MeshRenderer and Mesh Filter is fundamental to Unity's method of rendering 3D objects. For in-depth insights into how you can wield the MeshRenderer to influence the visual aesthetics of your game, dive into the [official Unity MeshRenderer Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/MeshRenderer.html).

@highrise/globaltype/MeshRenderer.additi.documentation: The additionalVertexStreams property is a Mesh that contains additional vertex data Streams. It is a highly advanced property that should be used with Shader Inputs that are expecting to receive this data. More can be found in [documentation link](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/MeshRenderer-additionalVertexStreams.html).

@highrise/globaltype/MeshRenderer.enligh.documentation: The enlightenVertexStream property provides a Mesh that has the Enlighten data Vertex Stream. Enlighten is the lighting system used in Unity's Render to provide Real-time Global Illumination. For more details, refer to [official Unity documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/MeshRenderer-enlightenVertexStream.html).

@highrise/globaltype/MeshRenderer.subMes.documentation: The subMeshStartIndex of a mesh represents the first index of the submesh within the MeshRenderer. Submeshes are subsets of a mesh, and are often used to apply different materials to different parts of a mesh. Further details can be found [here](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/MeshRenderer-subMeshStartIndex.html).

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4.documentation: Represents a vector or a point in four-dimensional space, commonly used for RGBA values, 4D transforms, or 3D transformations with homogeneous coordinates.

@highrise/global/Vector4.documentation: Represents a vector or a point in four-dimensional space, commonly used for RGBA values, 4D transforms, or 3D transformations with homogeneous coordinates.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4.Set.documentation: Sets the 'x', 'y', 'z', and 'w' components of the Vector4, enhancing code readability and efficiency.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4.Set.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.new(1, 2, 3, 4)
  v1:Set(5, 6, 7, 8)

  print(v1.x, v1.y, v1.z, v1.w)  -- 5, 6, 7, 8

params.name: newX
params.documentation: The new 'x' component.

params.name: newY
params.documentation: The new 'y' component.

params.name: newZ
params.documentation: The new 'z' component.

params.name: newW
params.documentation: The new 'w' component.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4.Scale.documentation: Scales a Vector4 by another Vector4's components, useful for dimension or shape scaling.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4.Scale.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.new(1, 2, 3, 4)
  local v2 = Vector4.new(2, 3, 4, 5)
  v1:Scale(v2)

  print(v1.x, v1.y, v1.z, v1.w)  -- 2, 6, 12, 20

params.name: scale
params.documentation: The Vector4 to scale by.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4.Normalize.documentation: Transforms the Vector4 into a vector of same direction but with length 1, ideal for direction-only uses.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4.SqrMagnitud.documentation: Provides the square of the magnitude of the Vector4, an efficient method for length comparisons.

returns.documentation: Returns the square of the magnitude.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Lerp.documentation: Performs Linear Interpolation between two Vector4's based on a parameter 't', useful for smooth transitions.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Lerp.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.new(1, 2, 3, 4)
  local v2 = Vector4.new(5, 6, 7, 8)
  local v3 = Vector4.Lerp(v1, v2, 0.5)

  print(v3.x, v3.y, v3.z, v3.w)  -- 3, 4, 5, 6

params.name: a
params.documentation: The starting Vector4.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The ending Vector4.

params.name: t
params.documentation: The interpolation factor.

returns.documentation: Returns an interpolated Vector4.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.LerpUnc.documentation: Similar to 'Lerp' but without clamping the 't' parameter, offering more freedom in interpolation.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.LerpUnc.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.new(1, 2, 3, 4)
  local v2 = Vector4.new(5, 6, 7, 8)
  local v3 = Vector4.LerpUnclamped(v1, v2, 2)

  print(v3.x, v3.y, v3.z, v3.w)  -- 9, 10, 11, 12

params.name: a
params.documentation: The start Vector4.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The end Vector4.

params.name: t
params.documentation: The interpolation fraction.

returns.documentation: Returns an unclamped interpolated Vector4.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.MoveTow.documentation: Moves a Vector4 'current' towards 'target', limited by 'maxDistanceDelta', useful for smooth object movement.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.MoveTow.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.new(1, 2, 3, 4)
  local v2 = Vector4.new(5, 6, 7, 8)
  local v3 = Vector4.MoveTowards(v1, v2, 2)

  print(v3.x, v3.y, v3.z, v3.w)  -- 3, 4, 5, 6

params.name: current
params.documentation: The current position.

params.name: target
params.documentation: The target position.

params.name: maxDistanceDelta
params.documentation: The max distance to move.

returns.documentation: Returns a Vector4 closer to the target.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Scale.documentation: Multiplies two Vector4's component-wise, useful for component-wise data manipulation.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Scale.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.new(1, 2, 3, 4)
  local v2 = Vector4.new(2, 3, 4, 5)
  local v3 = Vector4.Scale(v1, v2)

  print(v3.x, v3.y, v3.z, v3.w)  -- 2, 6, 12, 20

params.name: a
params.documentation: The first Vector4.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The second Vector4.

returns.documentation: Returns a new Vector4 from component-wise multiplication.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Normali.documentation: Normalizes a Vector4 and returns a new Vector4 with length 1, ideal for direction-only vectors.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Normali.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.new(1, 2, 3, 4)
  local v2 = Vector4.Normalize(v1)

  print(v2.x, v2.y, v2.z, v2.w)  -- 0.1826, 0.3651, 0.5477, 0.7303

params.name: a
params.documentation: The Vector4 to normalize.

returns.documentation: Returns a normalized Vector4.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Dot.documentation: Computes the dot product of two Vector4's, reflecting their angular relationship.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Dot.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.new(1, 2, 3, 4)
  local v2 = Vector4.new(5, 6, 7, 8)
  local dotProduct = Vector4.Dot(v1, v2)

  print(dotProduct)  -- 70

params.name: a
params.documentation: The first Vector4.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The second Vector4.

returns.documentation: Returns the dot product.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Project.documentation: Projects a Vector4 onto another Vector4, useful for finding the nearest point on a defined line.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Project.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.new(1, 2, 3, 4)
  local v2 = Vector4.new(5, 6, 7, 8)
  local v3 = Vector4.Project(v1, v2)

  print(v3.x, v3.y, v3.z, v3.w)  -- 2.5, 3, 3.5, 4

params.name: a
params.documentation: The Vector4 to project.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The Vector4 to project onto.

returns.documentation: Returns the projection of 'a' onto 'b'.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Distanc.documentation: Computes the distance between two Vector4's, useful for object spacing or collision detection.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Distanc.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.new(1, 2, 3, 4)
  local v2 = Vector4.new(5, 6, 7, 8)
  local distance = Vector4.Distance(v1, v2)

  print(distance)  -- 8.0

params.name: a
params.documentation: The first Vector4.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The second Vector4.

returns.documentation: Returns the distance between the two Vector4's.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Magnitu.documentation: Calculates the length of the Vector4, useful for finding the distance it spans in 4D space.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Magnitu.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.new(1, 2, 3, 4)
  local magnitude = Vector4.Magnitude(v1)

  print(magnitude)  -- 5.4772

params.name: a
params.documentation: The Vector4 to compute the magnitude for.

returns.documentation: Returns the magnitude of the Vector4.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Min.documentation: Returns a Vector4 with the smallest components of two Vector4's, useful for bounding box operations.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Min.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.new(1, 2, 3, 4)
  local v2 = Vector4.new(5, 6, 7, 8)
  local v3 = Vector4.Min(v1, v2)

  print(v3.x, v3.y, v3.z, v3.w)  -- 1, 2, 3, 4

params.name: lhs
params.documentation: The first Vector4.

params.name: rhs
params.documentation: The second Vector4.

returns.documentation: Returns a Vector4 with the smallest components.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Max.documentation: Returns a Vector4 with the largest components of two Vector4's, useful for limiting operations.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.Max.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.new(1, 2, 3, 4)
  local v2 = Vector4.new(5, 6, 7, 8)
  local v3 = Vector4.Max(v1, v2)

  print(v3.x, v3.y, v3.z, v3.w)  -- 5, 6, 7, 8

params.name: lhs
params.documentation: The first Vector4.

params.name: rhs
params.documentation: The second Vector4.

returns.documentation: Returns a Vector4 with the largest components.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.SqrMagn.documentation: Gives the square of the magnitude of a Vector4, an efficient comparison method that avoids square root calculations.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.SqrMagn.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.new(1, 2, 3, 4)
  local sqrMagnitude = Vector4.SqrMagnitude(v1)

  print(sqrMagnitude)  -- 30

params.name: a
params.documentation: The Vector4 to square the magnitude of.

returns.documentation: Returns the square of the Vector4's magnitude.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.new.documentation: Creates a new Vector4 instance with specified 'x', 'y', 'z', and 'w' components, useful for RGBA color representation or spatial coordinates.

params.name: x
params.documentation: The 'x' component of the Vector4.

params.name: y
params.documentation: The 'y' component of the Vector4.

params.name: z
params.documentation: The 'z' component of the Vector4.

params.name: w
params.documentation: The 'w' component of the Vector4.

returns.documentation: Returns a new Vector4 instance.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4.normalized.documentation: Provides a normalized version of the Vector4, with a length of 1, useful for direction-only applications.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4.normalized.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.new(1, 2, 3, 4)
local v2 = v1.normalized

print(v2.x, v2.y, v2.z, v2.w)  -- 0.1826, 0.3651, 0.5477, 0.7303

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4.magnitude.documentation: Provides the length of the Vector4, useful for distance calculations or scaling vectors.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4.sqrMagnitud.documentation: Returns the square of the magnitude of the Vector4, a performance-friendly alternative for length comparisons.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4.x.documentation: Accesses the 'x' component of the Vector4, representing different dimensions or the 'Red' component in RGBA.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4.y.documentation: Accesses the 'y' component of the Vector4, representing different dimensions or the 'Green' component in RGBA.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4.z.documentation: Accesses the 'z' component of the Vector4, representing different dimensions or the 'Blue' component in RGBA.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4.w.documentation: Accesses the 'w' component of the Vector4, representing different dimensions or the 'Alpha' component in RGBA.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.zero.documentation: Represents a Vector4 with all components set to zero.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.zero.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.zero
  print(v1.x, v1.y, v1.z, v1.w)  -- 0, 0, 0, 0

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.one.documentation: Represents a Vector4 with all components set to one, useful for certain mathematical operations.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.one.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.one
  print(v1.x, v1.y, v1.z, v1.w)  -- 1, 1, 1, 1

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.positiv.documentation: Represents a Vector4 with all components set to positive infinity, useful for setting maximum limits.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.positiv.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.positiveInfinity
  print(v1.x, v1.y, v1.z, v1.w)  -- inf, inf, inf, inf

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.negativ.documentation: Represents a Vector4 with all components set to negative infinity, useful for setting minimum limits.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.negativ.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.negativeInfinity
  print(v1.x, v1.y, v1.z, v1.w)  -- -inf, -inf, -inf, -inf

@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.kEpsilo.documentation: Represents a tiny positive number close to zero, used to handle calculations related to precision.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector4Type.kEpsilo.code_sample:
local v1 = Vector4.kEpsilon
  print(v1.x, v1.y, v1.z, v1.w)  -- 1e-05, 1e-05, 1e-05, 1e-05

@highrise/globaltype/Color.documentation:
The Color datatype represents an RGBA (Red Green Blue Alpha) color. Colors are represented with numbers between 0 and 1, where 1 signifies the maximum intensity of a particular color component. RGB components define the color while the Alpha component defines the transparency.

Provides various functions and predefined colors which ranges from common colors like red, green, blue, white, black, to more specific colors such as yellow, cyan, magenta, gray, etc. Further it also provides functionalities such as linear interpolation between two colors, conversion from/to HSV color model, and generating a grayscale color.

@highrise/global/Color.documentation:
The Color datatype represents an RGBA (Red Green Blue Alpha) color. Colors are represented with numbers between 0 and 1, where 1 signifies the maximum intensity of a particular color component. RGB components define the color while the Alpha component defines the transparency.

Provides various functions and predefined colors which ranges from common colors like red, green, blue, white, black, to more specific colors such as yellow, cyan, magenta, gray, etc. Further it also provides functionalities such as linear interpolation between two colors, conversion from/to HSV color model, and generating a grayscale color.

@highrise/globaltype/ColorType.Lerp.documentation: Calculates and returns a color that is a certain percentage (defined by the third parameter) between two other colors. This can be used to smoothly transition between two colors.
@highrise/globaltype/ColorType.Lerp.code_sample:
local colorA = Color.new(1, 0, 0) -- Red color
local colorB = Color.new(0, 1, 0) -- Green color

local transitionColor = Color.Lerp(colorA, colorB, 0.5) -- Transition color between red and green

params.name: a
params.documentation: The color to transition from.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The color to transition into.

params.name: t
params.documentation: The percentage of the transition. 0 represents color 'a' and 1 represents color 'b'.

returns.documentation: Returns the interpolated color.

@highrise/globaltype/ColorType.LerpUncla.documentation: Works similarly to 'Lerp', but without clamping the percentage (third parameter) between 0 and 1. This allows for extrapolation beyond the two original colors.
@highrise/globaltype/ColorType.LerpUncla.code_sample:
local colorA = Color.new(1, 0, 0) -- Red color
local colorB = Color.new(0, 1, 0) -- Green color

local transitionColor = Color.LerpUnclamped(colorA, colorB, 1.5) -- Extrapolated color beyond red and green

params.name: a
params.documentation: The color to transition from.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The color to transition into.

params.name: t
params.documentation: The percentage of the transition.

returns.documentation: Returns the interpolated or extrapolated color.

@highrise/globaltype/ColorType.HSVToRGB.documentation: Convert a color from HSV (Hue, Saturation, Value) color model to RGB (Red, Green, Blue) model. This function can be quite useful whenever you're dealing with HSV colors and need to convert them for use in RGB format.
@highrise/globaltype/ColorType.HSVToRGB.code_sample: local color = Color.HSVToRGB(0.5, 1, 1) -- RGB color from HSV color

params.name: H
params.documentation: The Hue component of the color, ranges between 0 to 1.

params.name: S
params.documentation: The Saturation component of the color, ranges between 0 to 1.

params.name: V
params.documentation: The Value component of the color, ranges between 0 to 1.

returns.documentation: Returns a Color object in RGB color space.

@highrise/globaltype/Color.new.documentation: Creates a new Color object with the provided red, green, blue, and optional alpha values. These values range from 0 to 1, where 0 represents no color and 1 represents full intensity of the color.

params.name: r
params.documentation: The red component of the color.

params.name: g
params.documentation: The green component of the color.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The blue component of the color.

returns.documentation: Returns a new Color object with the specified red, green, and blue components.

@highrise/globaltype/Color.grayscale.documentation: The grayscale value of the color based on the intensities of the red, green, and blue components.
@highrise/globaltype/Color.grayscale.code_sample:
local color = Color.new(1, 0, 0) -- Red color
  print(color.grayscale) -- 0.299

@highrise/globaltype/Color.linear.documentation: The linear (gamma space) equivalent of this color object. Game graphics are usually rendered in a color space known as gamma space, but many computations are done in linear space, thus this property can be useful when such conversions are necessary.
@highrise/globaltype/Color.linear.code_sample:
local color = Color.new(1, 0, 0) -- Red color
print(color.linear) -- 0.2126

@highrise/globaltype/Color.gamma.documentation: The gamma space equivalent of this color object. When the computations are done in linear space, this conversion can be useful to switch back to Gamma space for rendering.
@highrise/globaltype/Color.gamma.code_sample:
local color = Color.new(1, 0, 0) -- Red color
print(color.gamma) -- 0.2126

@highrise/globaltype/Color.maxColorCompo.documentation: The maximum RGB component in the color. It can be useful when you want to identify the dominant color component.
@highrise/globaltype/Color.maxColorCompo.code_sample:
local color = Color.new(1, 0, 0) -- Red color
print(color.maxColorComponent) -- 1

@highrise/globaltype/Color.r.documentation: Access or change the red component value of the color.
@highrise/globaltype/Color.r.code_sample:
local color = Color.new(1, 0, 0) -- Red color
print(color.r) -- 1

@highrise/globaltype/Color.g.documentation: Access or change the green component value of the color.
@highrise/globaltype/Color.g.code_sample:
local color = Color.new(1, 0, 0) -- Red color
print(color.g) -- 0

@highrise/globaltype/Color.b.documentation: Access or change the blue component value of the color.
@highrise/globaltype/Color.b.code_sample:
local color = Color.new(1, 0, 0) -- Red color
print(color.b) -- 0

@highrise/globaltype/Color.a.documentation: Access or change the alpha (transparency) component of the color where '1' is fully opaque and '0' is fully transparent.
@highrise/globaltype/Color.a.code_sample:
local color = Color.new(1, 0, 0) -- Red color
color.a = 0.5

print(color.a) -- 0.5

@highrise/globaltype/Mathf.documentation: Provides a comprehensive set of mathematical functions and constants for game development, including operations like absolute value, square root, and trigonometric calculations, as well as game-specific algorithms like smooth damping and lerp.

@highrise/global/Mathf.documentation: Provides a comprehensive set of mathematical functions and constants for game development, including operations like absolute value, square root, and trigonometric calculations, as well as game-specific algorithms like smooth damping and lerp.

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Abs.documentation: Calculates and returns the absolute value of its input.
@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Abs.code_sample:
local value = -5
local absValue = Mathf.Abs(value)
print("Absolute value: " .. absValue)

params.name: value
params.documentation: A number to find the absolute value of

returns.documentation: The absolute value of the input number.

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Acos.documentation: Returns the angle in radians whose cosine is the specified number, for trigonometric math operations.
@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Acos.code_sample:
local f = 0.5
local angle = Mathf.Acos(f)
print("Angle in radians: " .. angle)

params.name: f
params.documentation: A number representing a cosine, where -1 ≤ f ≤ 1

returns.documentation: Angle in radians, within the range [0, π].

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Approxima.documentation: Compares two floating point values for approximate equality, to handle floating point arithmetic inconsistencies.
@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Approxima.code_sample:
local a = 0.1
local b = 0.2
local equal = Mathf.Approximately(a, b)
print("Approximately equal: " .. tostring(equal))

params.name: a
params.documentation: The first number to compare

params.name: b
params.documentation: The second number to compare

returns.documentation: True if the values are approximately equal, else false.

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Asin.documentation: Returns the angle in radians whose sine is the specified number, useful for trigonometric operations.
@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Asin.code_sample:
local f = 0.5
local angle = Mathf.Asin(f)
print("Angle in radians: " .. angle)

params.name: f
params.documentation: A number representing a sine, where -1 ≤ f ≤ 1

returns.documentation: Angle in radians within the range [-1/2π, 1/2π].

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Atan.documentation: Returns the angle in radians whose tangent is the specified number, for trigonometric operations.
@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Atan.code_sample:
local f = 0.5
local angle = Mathf.Atan(f)
print("Angle in radians: " .. angle)

params.name: f
params.documentation: A number representing a tangent

returns.documentation: Angle in radians within the range [-π/2, π/2].

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Atan2.documentation: Returns the angle in radians whose tan is y/x, useful in game physics calculations.
@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Atan2.code_sample:
local y = 1
local x = 1
local angle = Mathf.Atan2(y, x)
print("Angle in radians: " .. angle)

params.name: y
params.documentation: The y-coordinate of a point

params.name: x
params.documentation: The x-coordinate of a point

returns.documentation: Angle in radians within the range [-π, π].

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Ceil.documentation: Rounds a number up to the closest integer not less than the specified number, useful for setting upper limit values.
@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Ceil.code_sample:
local f = 5.5
local ceilValue = Mathf.Ceil(f)
print("Ceiling value: " .. ceilValue)

params.name: f
params.documentation: The number to round up

returns.documentation: The smallest integer not less than f.

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.CeilToInt.documentation: Rounds a number up to the nearest integer, returning an integer value, useful when working with discrete values.
@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.CeilToInt.code_sample:
local f = 5.5
local ceilValue = Mathf.CeilToInt(f)
print("Ceiling value: " .. ceilValue)

params.name: f
params.documentation: The number to round up

returns.documentation: The smallest integer not less than f.

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Clamp.documentation: Restricts a number to be within a specified range, great for setting limits on variables or return values.
@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Clamp.code_sample:
local value = 5
local min = 0
local max = 10
local clampedValue = Mathf.Clamp(value, min, max)
print("Clamped value: " .. clampedValue)

params.name: value
params.documentation: The number to clamp

params.name: min
params.documentation: The lower boundary of the range

params.name: max
params.documentation: The upper boundary of the range

returns.documentation: The clamped number between min and max.

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Clamp01.documentation: Restricts a number to be within the range [0,1], handy for ensuring proportions or percentages.
@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Clamp01.code_sample:
local value = 5
local clampedValue = Mathf.Clamp01(value)
print("Clamped value: " .. clampedValue)

params.name: value
params.documentation: The number to clamp

returns.documentation: The clamped value between 0 and 1.

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.ClosestPo.documentation: Returns the power of two closest to a provided number, useful in texture resolutions.
@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.ClosestPo.code_sample:
local value = 100
