print("Closest power of two: " .. closestPower)

params.name: value
params.documentation: The number to find the closest power of two for

returns.documentation: The power of two closest to the input value.

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Cos.documentation: Computes and returns the cosine of the specified angle in radians, for trigonometric operations.
@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Cos.code_sample:

params.name: a
params.documentation: An angle, in radians

returns.documentation: The cosine of the angle.

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.DeltaAngl.documentation: Determines and returns the smallest difference between two angles, key to minimal rotation direction.
@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.DeltaAngl.code_sample:

params.name: current
params.documentation: The first angle, in degrees

params.name: target
params.documentation: The second angle, in degrees

returns.documentation: The shortest angle difference, in degrees.

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.PI.documentation: Represents the mathematical constant Pi for circular and trigonometric calculations.

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Infinity.documentation: Represents positive infinity, useful for comparisons.

@highrise/globaltype/MathfType.Deg2Rad.documentation: Conversion factor for degrees to radians.

@highrise/globaltype/Quaternion.documentation: A Quaternion represents rotation and direction in 3D space, consisting of x, y, z, and w components. They are crucial for 3D movement and rotation, offering advantages such as avoiding gimbal lock.

@highrise/global/Quaternion.documentation: A Quaternion represents rotation and direction in 3D space, consisting of x, y, z, and w components. They are crucial for 3D movement and rotation, offering advantages such as avoiding gimbal lock.

@highrise/globaltype/Quaternion.Equals.documentation: Checks if two Quaternions or objects are equal.
@highrise/globaltype/Quaternion.Equals.code_sample:
local a = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 0, 1)

local equal = a:Equals(b)

params.name: other
params.documentation: The Quaternion to compare with.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the Quaternions are equal.

@highrise/globaltype/Quaternion.Set.documentation: Assigns new values to the Quaternion's components.

params.name: newY

params.name: newZ

params.name: newW

local quaternion = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 0, 1)

quaternion:SetFromToRotation(from, to)

params.name: toDirection

@highrise/globaltype/Quaternion.Normaliz.documentation: Modifies the quaternion to a unit length version of itself.

local from = Vector3.new(0, 0, 0)

params.documentation: The vector to rotate from.

params.documentation: The vector to rotate to.

@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.Inve.documentation: Returns the inverse of the Quaternion.

@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.Sler.code_sample:
local a = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 0, 1)

local slerp = Quaternion.Slerp(a, b, t)

params.documentation: The starting rotation.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The end rotation.

params.name: t
params.documentation: The amount to interpolate.

@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.Sler.documentation: Interpolates a Quaternion over an arbitrary range.
@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.Sler.code_sample:
local a = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 0, 1)

local t = 0.5

local slerp = Quaternion.SlerpUnclamped(a, b, t)

params.name: a
params.documentation: The starting rotation.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The end rotation.

params.name: t
params.documentation: The unclamped interpolation amount.

returns.documentation: An interpolated quaternion rotation.

@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.Lerp.code_sample:
local a = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 0, 1)
local b = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 1, 0)
local t = 0.5

local lerp = Quaternion.Lerp(a, b, t)

params.name: a
params.documentation: The starting rotation.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The end rotation.

params.name: t
params.documentation: The amount to interpolate.

returns.documentation: An interpolated quaternion rotation.

@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.Lerp.documentation: The 'LerpUnclamped' method is similar to Lerp, but here the interpolation factor isn't clamped to the range [0, 1].
@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.Lerp.code_sample:
local a = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 0, 1)
local b = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 1, 0)

local lerp = Quaternion.LerpUnclamped(a, b, t)

params.name: a
params.documentation: The starting rotation.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The end rotation.

params.name: t
params.documentation: The unclamped interpolation amount.

returns.documentation: Returns a Quaternion that is interpolated over an arbitrary range.

params.name: axis
params.documentation: The rotation axis.

returns.documentation: A Quaternion around the specified axis with the given angle.

@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.Look.code_sample:
local forward = Vector3.new(0, 0, 1)
local upwards = Vector3.new(0, 1, 0)

params.name: forward
params.documentation: The direction to be faced.

params.name: upwards
params.documentation: The direction to be used as 'upwards'.

returns.documentation: A Quaternion that aligns an object's forward direction towards the specified direction.

@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.Mult.code_sample:
local a = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 0, 1)
local b = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 1, 0)

local multiplied = Quaternion.Multiply(a, b)

params.name: a
params.documentation: The first Quaternion.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The second Quaternion.

returns.documentation: The product of the two Quaternions.

@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.Dot.code_sample:
local a = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 0, 1)
local b = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 1, 0)

params.name: a
params.documentation: The first quaternion.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The second quaternion.

returns.documentation: The dot product of the two quaternions.

@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.Angl.code_sample:
local a = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 0, 1)

params.name: b
params.documentation: The second rotation.

@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.Eule.documentation: Creates a Quaternion rotation from Euler angles.

params.documentation: The angle around the y-axis in degrees.

params.documentation: The angle around the z-axis in degrees.

@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.Rota.documentation: Gradually changes a Quaternion towards a target rotation.
@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.Rota.code_sample:
local from = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 0, 1)
local to = Quaternion.new(0, 0, 1, 0)

params.name: to
params.documentation: The target rotation.

@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.Norm.documentation: Modifies the quaternion to a unit length version of itself.

@highrise/globaltype/Quaternion.new.code_sample:

params.name: y
params.documentation: The y component.

params.name: z
params.documentation: The z component.

params.documentation: The w component.

@highrise/globaltype/Quaternion.eulerAng.code_sample:

@highrise/globaltype/QuaternionType.kEps.documentation: Represents a small number greater than zero for comparison.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2.Set.code_sample:
local position = Vector2.new(1, 2)

params.documentation: First Vector2.

params.name: b
params.documentation: Second Vector2.

params.name: t
params.documentation: Interpolation factor.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2Type.LerpUnc.documentation: Linearly interpolates between two Vector2's without clamping 't'.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector2Type.LerpUnc.code_sample:
local a = Vector2.new(1, 2)
local b = Vector2.new(3, 4)

local result = Vector2.LerpUnclamped(a, b, 2)
print(result.x) -- 5
print(result.y) -- 6

params.name: a
params.documentation: Starting Vector2.

params.name: b
params.documentation: Ending Vector2.

params.name: t
params.documentation: Interpolation factor.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2Type.MoveTow.documentation: Moves a Vector2 towards another Vector2 within a maximum distance.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector2Type.MoveTow.code_sample:
local current = Vector2.new(1, 2)
local target = Vector2.new(3, 4)

local result = Vector2.MoveTowards(current, target, 2)
print(result.x) -- 3
print(result.y) -- 4

params.name: current
params.documentation: Current Vector2.

params.name: target
params.documentation: Target Vector2.

params.name: maxDistanceDelta
params.documentation: Maximum movement distance.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2Type.Scale.code_sample:
local a = Vector2.new(1, 2)
local b = Vector2.new(3, 4)

local result = Vector2.Scale(a, b)
print(result.x) -- 3
print(result.y) -- 8

params.name: a
params.documentation: First Vector2.

params.name: b
params.documentation: Second Vector2.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2Type.Reflect.documentation: Reflects a Vector2 off a surface Vector2.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector2Type.Reflect.code_sample:
local inDirection = Vector2.new(1, 2)
local surfaceNormal = Vector2.new(0, 1)

local result = Vector2.Reflect(inDirection, surfaceNormal)
print(result.x) -- 1
print(result.y) -- -2

params.name: inDirection
params.documentation: Direction of incoming Vector2.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2.new.documentation: Creates a Vector2 with specified x and y components.

params.name: x
params.documentation: The x component.

params.name: y
params.documentation: The y component.

returns.documentation: A new Vector2 instance.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2.normalized.documentation: The normalized version of the Vector2.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector2.normalized.code_sample:
local position = Vector2.new(1, 2)
local normalized = position.normalized

print(normalized.x) -- 0.44721359014511

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2.sqrMagnitud.documentation: The square of the Vector2's magnitude.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2.x.code_sample:
local position = Vector2.new(1, 2)
print(position.x) -- 1

position.x = 3
print(position.x) -- 3

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2.y.code_sample:
local position = Vector2.new(1, 2)
print(position.y) -- 2

position.y = 3
print(position.y) -- 3

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2Type.zero.documentation: A Vector2 with both components set to zero.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2Type.one.documentation: A Vector2 with both components set to one.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2Type.left.documentation: A Vector2 pointing to the left.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2Type.right.documentation: A Vector2 pointing to the right.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2Type.positiv.documentation: A Vector2 with both components at positive infinity.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2Type.negativ.documentation: A Vector2 with both components at negative infinity.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector2Type.kEpsilo.documentation: A very small positive number greater than zero.
A small positive number for Vector2 computations.

@highrise/globaltype/Bounds.documentation: An axis-aligned bounding box. It acts as a simple container for a center position and the extents (further subdivided into size, min, max) of a box that can be used for collision detection, visibility testing, or other similar tasks in your game.

@highrise/global/Bounds.documentation: An axis-aligned bounding box. It acts as a simple container for a center position and the extents (further subdivided into size, min, max) of a box that can be used for collision detection, visibility testing, or other similar tasks in your game.

@highrise/globaltype/Bounds.SetMinMax.documentation: The minimum and maximum corners of the bounding box.

params.name: min
params.documentation: This specifies the smallest value for each coordinate of the bounding box.

params.name: max
params.documentation: This represents the largest value for each coordinate of the bounding box.

@highrise/globaltype/Bounds.Encapsulate.documentation: Grows the Bounds to include a point or bounds. You would typically use this when you have a set of points and you want a bounding box that encloses all these points.

params.name: point
params.documentation: The new point to include within the bounding box.

@highrise/globaltype/Bounds.Expand.documentation: Increases the size of the bounding box by the given amount (in both directions).

params.name: amount
params.documentation: The amount by which the bounding box should be expanded (shrank if negative).

@highrise/globaltype/Bounds.Intersects.documentation: Checks whether the current bounding box intersects with another bounding box. You can use this to determine if two objects are likely to be colliding.

params.name: bounds
params.documentation: The other bounding box to test intersection with.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the bounding boxes intersect, false otherwise.

@highrise/globaltype/Bounds.IntersectRay.documentation: Determines if a specified Ray intersects the bounds. This can prove vital in various game scenarios for interaction detection such as determining if a projectile is in range of an object or if a click or tap in screen space intersects a game object. It evaluates the intersection and returns true if the Ray intersects with the bounds, otherwise it returns false.

params.name: ray
params.documentation: The Ray instance against which the intersection is to be checked.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the Ray intersects with the bounds, otherwise false.

@highrise/globaltype/Bounds.Contains.documentation: Check whether a specific point is within the current bounding box.

params.name: point
params.documentation: This is the point which you want to check.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the point is inside the bounding box, false otherwise.

@highrise/globaltype/Bounds.SqrDistance.documentation: Returns the squared distance from a point to the bounding box. Squared distances can be useful for comparison without needing the computationally expensive square root operation.

params.name: point
params.documentation: The point from which the distance is measured.

returns.documentation: Returns the squared distance from the bounding box to the point.

@highrise/globaltype/Bounds.ClosestPoint.documentation: The closest point on or inside the bounding box to a given point. This can be helpful in figuring out how close an object is to entering a bounding box.

params.name: point
params.documentation: This is the location from which the closest point is determined.

returns.documentation: Returns the closest point within or on the bounding box to the given point.

@highrise/globaltype/Bounds.new.documentation: Creates a new Bounds object by providing a central point and the size of the box.

params.name: center
params.documentation: This specifies the center of the bounding box in three-dimensional space.

params.name: size
params.documentation: This represents the total size of the bounding box along each axis.

returns.documentation: Returns a Bounds object with the provided center and size.

@highrise/globaltype/Bounds.center.documentation: Vector3 value that signifies the central point of the bounding box.

@highrise/globaltype/Bounds.size.documentation: The size of the bounding box for each dimension - how wide, tall, and deep it is.

@highrise/globaltype/Bounds.extents.documentation: Similar to size but it represents half the size of the bounding box in each dimension. This can be used when you need to measure from the center of the bounding box.

@highrise/globaltype/Bounds.min.documentation: The minimum value (lower-left-front corner) of the bounding box coordinates.

@highrise/globaltype/Bounds.max.documentation: The maximal value (upper-right-back corner) of the bounding box coordinates.

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.documentation: The Rect datatype in Unity represents a rectangle defined by its position x, y, and size width, height. It's commonly used in 2D game development to manage areas, positions, and sizes within a game scene.

@highrise/global/Rect.documentation: The Rect datatype in Unity represents a rectangle defined by its position x, y, and size width, height. It's commonly used in 2D game development to manage areas, positions, and sizes within a game scene.

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.Set.documentation: Set the position and size of the Rect. This method assigns the x, y position, width, and height of the Rect.
@highrise/globaltype/Rect.Set.code_sample:
local rect = Rect.new(0, 0, 100, 100)
rect:Set(10, 10, 50, 50)

print(rect.x) -- 10
print(rect.y) -- 10

print(rect.width) -- 50
print(rect.height) -- 50

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.Contains.documentation: Check if a point is within the Rect. This method determines if a point is inside the Rect.
@highrise/globaltype/Rect.Contains.code_sample:
local rect = Rect.new(0, 0, 100, 100)
local point = Vector2.new(50, 50)

print(rect:Contains(point)) -- true

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.Overlaps.documentation: Determine if the Rect overlaps with another Rect. This method checks if the Rect overlaps with another Rect.
@highrise/globaltype/Rect.Overlaps.code_sample:
local rect1 = Rect.new(0, 0, 100, 100)
local rect2 = Rect.new(50, 50, 100, 100)

print(rect1:Overlaps(rect2)) -- true

@highrise/globaltype/RectType.MinMaxRect.documentation: Create a new Rect from minimum and maximum coordinates. This method creates a Rect from the minimum and maximum coordinates.
@highrise/globaltype/RectType.MinMaxRect.code_sample:
local rect = Rect.MinMaxRect(0, 0, 100, 100)

print(rect.x) -- 0
print(rect.y) -- 0

print(rect.width) -- 100
print(rect.height) -- 100

@highrise/globaltype/RectType.Normalized.documentation: Convert normalized coordinates to a point within the Rect. This method converts normalized coordinates to a point within the Rect.
@highrise/globaltype/RectType.Normalized.code_sample:
local rect = Rect.new(0, 0, 100, 100)
local normalized = Vector2.new(0.5, 0.5)

local point = rect:NormalizedToPoint(normalized)
print(point.x) -- 50
print(point.y) -- 50

@highrise/globaltype/RectType.PointToNor.documentation: Convert a point within the Rect to normalized coordinates. This method converts a point within the Rect to normalized coordinates.
@highrise/globaltype/RectType.PointToNor.code_sample:
local rect = Rect.new(0, 0, 100, 100)
local point = Vector2.new(50, 50)

local normalized = rect:PointToNormalized(point)
print(normalized.x) -- 0.5
print(normalized.y) -- 0.5

@highrise/globaltype/RectType.new.documentation: Represents a new instance of Rect with specified x, y position, and width, height size.
@highrise/globaltype/RectType.new.code_sample:
local rect = Rect.new(0, 0, 100, 100)

print(rect.x) -- 0
print(rect.y) -- 0

print(rect.width) -- 100
print(rect.height) -- 100

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.x.documentation: Retrieve or assign the x-coordinate of the Rect. The x-coordinate represents the horizontal position of the Rect.

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.y.documentation: Access or modify the y-coordinate of the Rect. The y-coordinate represents the vertical position of the Rect.

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.position.documentation: Get or set the position of the Rect as a Vector2. The position represents the x, y coordinates of the Rect.
@highrise/globaltype/Rect.position.code_sample:
local rect = Rect.new(0, 0, 100, 100)
rect.position = Vector2.new(10, 10)

print(rect.position.x) -- 10
print(rect.position.y) -- 10

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.center.documentation: Obtain or modify the center position of the Rect. The center represents the midpoint of the Rect.
@highrise/globaltype/Rect.center.code_sample:
local rect = Rect.new(0, 0, 100, 100)
rect.center = Vector2.new(50, 50)

print(rect.center.x) -- 50
print(rect.center.y) -- 50

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.min.documentation: Access the min point of the Rect. The min point represents the bottom-left corner of the Rect.

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.max.documentation: Get the max point of the Rect. The max point represents the top-right corner of the Rect.

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.width.documentation: Access or modify the width of the Rect. The width represents the horizontal size of the Rect.

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.height.documentation: Retrieve or set the height of the Rect. The height represents the vertical size of the Rect.

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.size.documentation: Get or set the size of the Rect as a Vector2. The size represents the width, height dimensions of the Rect.
@highrise/globaltype/Rect.size.code_sample:
local rect = Rect.new(0, 0, 100, 100)
rect.size = Vector2.new(50, 50)

print(rect.size.x) -- 50
print(rect.size.y) -- 50

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.xMin.documentation: Access the minimum x-coordinate of the Rect. The xMin represents the left edge of the Rect.

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.yMin.documentation: Access the minimum y-coordinate of the Rect. The yMin represents the bottom edge of the Rect.

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.xMax.documentation: Get the maximum x-coordinate of the Rect. The xMax represents the right edge of the Rect.

@highrise/globaltype/Rect.yMax.documentation: Access the maximum y-coordinate of the Rect. The yMax represents the top edge of the Rect.

@highrise/globaltype/RectType.zero.documentation: Obtain a Rect instance positioned at the origin (0, 0) with zero width and height. This represents a point at the origin.

@highrise/globaltype/LayerMask.documentation:
Specifies Layers to use in a Physics.Raycast.

A GameObject can use up to 32 LayerMasks supported by the Editor. The first 8 of these Layers are specified by Unity; the following 24 are controllable by the user.

Bitmasks represent the 32 Layers and define them as true or false. Each bitmask describes whether the Layer is used. As an example, bit 5 can be set to 1 (true). This will allow the use of the built-in Water setting.

Edit->Settings->Tags and Layers option shows the use of the 32 bitmasks. Each Layer is shown with a string setting. As an example Built-in Layer 0 is set as Default; Built-in Layer 1 is set as TransparentFX. New named Layers are added above bitmask layer 8. A selected GameObject will show the chosen Layer at top right of the Inspector. The example below has User Layer 13 set to "Wall". This causes the assigned GameObject to be treated as part of a building.

In the following script example, Physics.Raycast sends a ray into the world. Camera.main can be rotated around the y-axis and fire a ray. Three GameObjects represent walls that can be hit by the fired ray. Each GameObject has GameObject.label set to the "Wall" layerMask.

[Unity's LayerMask Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LayerMask.html)

@highrise/global/LayerMask.documentation:
Specifies Layers to use in a Physics.Raycast.

A GameObject can use up to 32 LayerMasks supported by the Editor. The first 8 of these Layers are specified by Unity; the following 24 are controllable by the user.

Bitmasks represent the 32 Layers and define them as true or false. Each bitmask describes whether the Layer is used. As an example, bit 5 can be set to 1 (true). This will allow the use of the built-in Water setting.

Edit->Settings->Tags and Layers option shows the use of the 32 bitmasks. Each Layer is shown with a string setting. As an example Built-in Layer 0 is set as Default; Built-in Layer 1 is set as TransparentFX. New named Layers are added above bitmask layer 8. A selected GameObject will show the chosen Layer at top right of the Inspector. The example below has User Layer 13 set to "Wall". This causes the assigned GameObject to be treated as part of a building.

In the following script example, Physics.Raycast sends a ray into the world. Camera.main can be rotated around the y-axis and fire a ray. Three GameObjects represent walls that can be hit by the fired ray. Each GameObject has GameObject.label set to the "Wall" layerMask.

[Unity's LayerMask Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/LayerMask.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3.documentation: Vector3 represents three-dimensional space as coordinates, physical quantities, or directions, containing three numerical components (x, y, and z). It is used in Unity for physics, animations, and transformations.

@highrise/global/Vector3.documentation: Vector3 represents three-dimensional space as coordinates, physical quantities, or directions, containing three numerical components (x, y, and z). It is used in Unity for physics, animations, and transformations.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3.Set.documentation: Changes the x, y, and z values of an existing Vector3 object, useful for simultaneous updates to all three components.

params.name: newX
params.documentation: The new value for the x-coordinate.

params.name: newY
params.documentation: The new value for the y-coordinate.

params.name: newZ
params.documentation: The new value for the z-coordinate.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3.Scale.documentation: Multiplies each component of the Vector3 by the corresponding components of another Vector3, used to alter the scale without changing its direction.

params.name: scale
params.documentation: A Vector3 by which the instance vector is scaled.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3.Normalize.documentation: Adjusts the Vector3 to a length of one while maintaining its direction, useful for when only the direction is of interest.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Slerp.documentation: Creates a smooth transition between two Vector3 points on a sphere's surface, ideal for smooth transitions in rotations or positions.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Slerp.code_sample:
local start = Vector3.new(1, 0, 0)
local finish = Vector3.new(0, 1, 0)

local slerpVector = Vector3.Slerp(start, finish, 0.5)
print(slerpVector) -- Vector3(0.70710676908493, 0.70710676908493, 0)

params.name: a
params.documentation: The starting Vector3 point.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The ending Vector3 point.

params.name: t
params.documentation: The interpolation factor between 0 and 1.

returns.documentation: A Vector3 point along the shortest path between 'a' and 'b'.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.SlerpUn.documentation: Similar to 'Slerp' but allows the 't' value to exceed the 0 to 1 range, enabling extrapolation beyond the original points.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.SlerpUn.code_sample:
local position = Vector3.new(1, 0, 0)

local a = Vector3.new(0, 1, 0)
local b = Vector3.new(0, 0, 1)

local t = 1.5
local result = Vector3.SlerpUnclamped(a, b, t)

print(result) -- Vector3(0, -0.5, 0.5)

params.name: a
params.documentation: The starting Vector3 point.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The ending Vector3 point.

params.name: t
params.documentation: An extrapolation factor beyond 0 and 1.

returns.documentation: A new Vector3 point potentially extrapolated beyond 'b'.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.RotateT.documentation: Gradually rotates a Vector3 'current' to align with a 'target' Vector3, with specified maximum rotation and magnitude change limits.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.RotateT.code_sample:
local current = Vector3.new(1, 0, 0)
local target = Vector3.new(0, 1, 0)

local maxRadiansDelta = 0.1
local maxMagnitudeDelta = 0.1

local result = Vector3.RotateTowards(current, target, maxRadiansDelta, maxMagnitudeDelta)

print(result) -- Vector3(0.70710676908493, 0.70710676908493, 0)

params.name: current
params.documentation: The current Vector3 from which rotation starts.

params.name: target
params.documentation: The target Vector3 towards which rotation is aimed.

params.name: maxRadiansDelta
params.documentation: Maximum rotation allowed in radians.

params.name: maxMagnitudeDelta
params.documentation: Maximum change in magnitude allowed.

returns.documentation: The Vector3 after rotating towards the target.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Lerp.documentation: Performs linear interpolation between two Vector3s, transitioning from 'a' to 'b' based on the 't' ratio.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Lerp.code_sample:
local start = Vector3.new(1, 0, 0)
local finish = Vector3.new(0, 1, 0)

local lerpVector = Vector3.Lerp(start, finish, 0.5)
print(lerpVector) -- Vector3(0.5, 0.5, 0)

params.name: a
params.documentation: The starting Vector3 point.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The ending Vector3 point.

params.name: t
params.documentation: The interpolation factor, in the range 0 to 1.

returns.documentation: A new Vector3 point interpolated between 'a' and 'b'.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.LerpUnc.documentation: Similar to 'Lerp', this method performs linear interpolation between two points, but allows 't' to exceed the 0 to 1 range, enabling extrapolation.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.LerpUnc.code_sample:
local start = Vector3.new(1, 0, 0)
local finish = Vector3.new(0, 1, 0)

local t = 1.5
local result = Vector3.LerpUnclamped(start, finish, t)

print(result) -- Vector3(-0.5, 0.5, 0)

params.name: a
params.documentation: The starting Vector3 point.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The ending Vector3 point.

params.name: t
params.documentation: The interpolation factor, not limited to between 0 and 1.

returns.documentation: A new Vector3 point interpolated (or extrapolated) between 'a' and 'b'.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.MoveTow.documentation: Moves a Vector3 ('current') incrementally towards a target Vector3 ('target') at a specified 'maxDistanceDelta'.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.MoveTow.code_sample:
local current = Vector3.new(1, 0, 0)
local target = Vector3.new(0, 1, 0)

local maxDistanceDelta = 0.1
local result = Vector3.MoveTowards(current, target, maxDistanceDelta)

print(result) -- Vector3(0.9, 0.1, 0)

params.name: current
params.documentation: The current Vector3 to move.

params.name: target
params.documentation: The target Vector3 to move towards.

params.name: maxDistanceDelta
params.documentation: The maximum distance the Vector3 can move in one call.

returns.documentation: A Vector3 moved towards the target.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Scale.documentation: Creates a new Vector3 from the product of corresponding components of two given Vector3s, affecting the size without changing direction.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Scale.code_sample:
local a = Vector3.new(1, 2, 3)
local b = Vector3.new(4, 5, 6)

local result = Vector3.Scale(a, b)
print(result) -- Vector3(4, 10, 18)

params.name: a
params.documentation: The first Vector3 used for scaling.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The second Vector3 used for scaling.

returns.documentation: The resulting Vector3 after scaling.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Cross.documentation: Calculates the cross product of two Vector3 instances, resulting in a Vector3 perpendicular to both, used for finding normals or rotation axes.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Cross.code_sample:
local lhs = Vector3.new(1, 0, 0)
local rhs = Vector3.new(0, 1, 0)

local crossProduct = Vector3.Cross(lhs, rhs)
print(crossProduct) -- Vector3(0, 0, 1)

params.name: lhs
params.documentation: The first Vector3 to cross.

params.name: rhs
params.documentation: The second Vector3 to cross.

returns.documentation: The cross product of the two Vector3s.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Reflect.documentation: Reflects a Vector3 off a surface with a specified normal, useful for simulating reflections or ricochets.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Reflect.code_sample:
local inDirection = Vector3.new(1, 0, 0)
local inNormal = Vector3.new(0, 1, 0)

local reflectedVector = Vector3.Reflect(inDirection, inNormal)
print(reflectedVector) -- Vector3(1, 0, 0)

params.name: inDirection
params.documentation: The incoming Vector3 to reflect.

params.name: inNormal
params.documentation: The normal Vector3 off which to reflect.

returns.documentation: The reflected Vector3.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Normali.documentation: Normalizes a Vector3, returning a new Vector3 with the same direction but a magnitude of 1, useful for direction without magnitude concern.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Normali.code_sample:
local vector = Vector3.new(1, 2, 3)
local normalizedVector = Vector3.Normalize(vector)

print(normalizedVector) -- Vector3(0.26726123690605, 0.5345224738121, 0.80178368043899)

params.name: value
params.documentation: The Vector3 to normalize.

returns.documentation: A normalized version of the input Vector3.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Dot.documentation: Calculates the Dot Product of two Vector3s, useful for determining directional alignment or the angle between vectors.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Dot.code_sample:
local lhs = Vector3.new(1, 0, 0)
local rhs = Vector3.new(0, 1, 0)

local dotProduct = Vector3.Dot(lhs, rhs)
print(dotProduct) -- 0

params.name: lhs
params.documentation: The first Vector3 for the dot product.

params.name: rhs
params.documentation: The second Vector3 for the dot product.

returns.documentation: The dot product of the two Vector3s.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Project.documentation: Projects a Vector3 onto another, useful for finding the component of one vector in the direction of another.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Project.code_sample:
local vector = Vector3.new(1, 2, 3)
local onNormal = Vector3.new(1, 0, 0)

local projectedVector = Vector3.Project(vector, onNormal)
print(projectedVector) -- Vector3(1, 0, 0)

params.name: vector
params.documentation: The Vector3 being projected.

params.name: onNormal
params.documentation: The Vector3 on which the projection occurs.

returns.documentation: The projection of the first Vector3 onto the second.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Project.documentation: Projects a Vector3 onto a plane defined by a normal orthogonal Vector3, useful for aligning objects to surfaces.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Project.code_sample:
local vector = Vector3.new(1, 2, 3)
local planeNormal = Vector3.new(0, 1, 0)

local projectedVector = Vector3.ProjectOnPlane(vector, planeNormal)
print(projectedVector) -- Vector3(1, 0, 3)

params.name: vector
params.documentation: The Vector3 being projected onto a plane.

params.name: planeNormal
params.documentation: The normal Vector3 of the plane onto which the projection occurs.

returns.documentation: The Vector3 after being projected onto a plane.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Angle.documentation: Calculates the angle in degrees between two Vector3s, useful for determining the required rotation to align one Vector3 with another.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Angle.code_sample:
local from = Vector3.new(1, 0, 0)
local to = Vector3.new(0, 1, 0)

local angle = Vector3.Angle(from, to)
print(angle) -- 90

params.name: from
params.documentation: The origin Vector3 for angle measurement.

params.name: to
params.documentation: The destination Vector3 for angle measurement.

returns.documentation: The angle in degrees between the two Vector3s.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.SignedA.documentation: Calculates the angle between two Vector3s with a sign indicating rotation direction around a given axis.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.SignedA.code_sample:
local from = Vector3.new(1, 0, 0)
local to = Vector3.new(0, 1, 0)

local axis = Vector3.new(0, 0, 1)
local angle = Vector3.SignedAngle(from, to, axis)
print(angle) -- 90

params.name: from
params.documentation: The Vector3 from where the angle measurement starts.

params.name: to
params.documentation: The Vector3 to which the angle measurement is made.

params.name: axis
params.documentation: The axis around which the rotation angle is measured.

returns.documentation: The signed angle in degrees between the two Vector3s.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Distanc.documentation: Calculates the distance between two Vector3 points, typically used to determine how far apart two objects are in 3D space.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Distanc.code_sample:
local a = Vector3.new(1, 0, 0)
local b = Vector3.new(0, 1, 0)

local distance = Vector3.Distance(a, b)
print(distance) -- 1.4142135381699

params.name: a
params.documentation: The first Vector3 point.

params.name: b
params.documentation: The second Vector3 point.

returns.documentation: The distance between the two Vector3 points.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.ClampMa.documentation: Limits the magnitude of a Vector3 to a specified maximum, useful for constraining movement or other vector magnitudes.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.ClampMa.code_sample:
local vector = Vector3.new(1, 2, 3)
local maxLength = 2

local clampedVector = Vector3.ClampMagnitude(vector, maxLength)
print(clampedVector) -- Vector3(0.55470019578934, 1.1094003915787, 1.6641006469727)

params.name: vector
params.documentation: The Vector3 to clamp.

params.name: maxLength
params.documentation: The maximum length to which the Vector3's magnitude is clamped.

returns.documentation: The Vector3 with its magnitude clamped.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Magnitu.documentation: Returns the magnitude (length) of a Vector3, useful for distance calculations from the origin.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Magnitu.code_sample:
local vector = Vector3.new(1, 2, 3)
local magnitude = Vector3.Magnitude(vector)

print(magnitude) -- 3.7416573867739

params.name: vector
params.documentation: The Vector3 of which to calculate the magnitude.

returns.documentation: The magnitude of the Vector3.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.SqrMagn.documentation: Calculates the square of the magnitude of a Vector3, often used for performance reasons in relative length comparisons.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.SqrMagn.code_sample:
local vector = Vector3.new(1, 2, 3)
local sqrMagnitude = Vector3.SqrMagnitude(vector)

print(sqrMagnitude) -- 14

params.name: vector
params.documentation: The Vector3 of which to calculate the square of the magnitude.

returns.documentation: The square of the magnitude of the Vector3.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Min.documentation: Returns a Vector3 composed of the smallest x, y, and z components from two given Vector3s, useful for bounding calculations.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Min.code_sample:
local a = Vector3.new(1, 2, 3)
local b = Vector3.new(3, 2, 1)

local minVector = Vector3.Min(a, b)
print(minVector) -- Vector3(1, 2, 1)

params.name: lhs
params.documentation: The first Vector3 for comparison.

params.name: rhs
params.documentation: The second Vector3 for comparison.

returns.documentation: A Vector3 made up of the smallest components from the two input Vector3s.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Max.documentation: Produces a Vector3 from the largest x, y, and z components of two given Vector3s, useful for defining bounds or extents.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.Max.code_sample:
local a = Vector3.new(1, 2, 3)
local b = Vector3.new(3, 2, 1)

local maxVector = Vector3.Max(a, b)
print(maxVector) -- Vector3(3, 2, 3)

params.name: lhs
params.documentation: The first of two Vector3s to compare.

params.name: rhs
params.documentation: The second of two Vector3s to compare.

returns.documentation: A Vector3 composed of the largest components of the two compared Vector3s.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.new.documentation: Instantiates a new Vector3 object by specifying x, y, and z coordinates, representing a point in the Unity game world's 3D space.

params.name: x
params.documentation: Specifies the x-coordinate value.

params.name: y
params.documentation: Specifies the y-coordinate value.

params.name: z
params.documentation: Specifies the z-coordinate value.

returns.documentation: A Vector3 instance with the specified coordinates.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3.normalized.documentation: Returns a version of this Vector3 with a magnitude of one, maintaining its direction. Useful for unit direction vectors.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3.magnitude.documentation: Provides the length of a Vector3, calculated as the Euclidean distance to (0,0,0), useful for distance calculations in 3D space.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3.sqrMagnitud.documentation: Returns the square of the magnitude, an alternative for performance-sensitive calculations where exact distance is not necessary.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3.x.documentation: Represents the x-coordinate of the Vector3, allowing direct manipulation or reading of its x-component.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3.y.documentation: Corresponds to the y-coordinate of the Vector3, for manipulating or reading the y-component.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3.z.documentation: Represents the z-coordinate of the Vector3, used for direct manipulation or reading of the z-component.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.zero.documentation: Generates a Vector3 with zero values for all coordinates, representing the origin in 3D space or indicating no motion or rotation.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.one.documentation: Generates a Vector3 object with all components set to 1, useful for pointing diagonally in 3D space.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.forward.documentation: Returns a Vector3 pointing towards the positive Z-axis, useful for designating a forward direction.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.back.documentation: Provides a Vector3 pointing towards the negative Z-axis, often used to designate a backward direction.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.up.documentation: Offers a Vector3 pointing upwards along the positive Y-axis, handy for upward movements or orientations.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.down.documentation: Represents a Vector3 pointing downwards along the negative Y-axis, typically used for downward directions.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.left.documentation: Returns a Vector3 pointing in the negative X-axis direction, used to signify left direction in 3D space.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.right.documentation: Provides a Vector3 pointing towards the positive X-axis, recognized as the right direction in 3D space.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.positiv.documentation: Yields a Vector3 with all components set to positive infinity, useful for representing very large values.
@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.positiv.code_sample:
local positiveInfinityVector = Vector3.positiveInfinity
print(positiveInfinityVector) -- Vector3(inf, inf, inf)

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.negativ.documentation: Generates a Vector3 with all components set to negative infinity, representing the smallest possible values in 3D space.

@highrise/globaltype/Vector3Type.kEpsilo.documentation: Provides a very small positive number, used for comparisons to determine if Vector3 components are approximately zero, considering floating-point inaccuracies.
A small positive number used in square root calculations, representing a negligible threshold value for comparing Vector3 magnitudes.

@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.documentation: Stores information returned by a raycast, a technique used to detect objects in a certain path or direction in video games. It contains data such as the hit collider, hit point, surface normal, distance from the ray's origin, etc.

@highrise/global/RaycastHit.documentation: Stores information returned by a raycast, a technique used to detect objects in a certain path or direction in video games. It contains data such as the hit collider, hit point, surface normal, distance from the ray's origin, etc.

@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.collider.documentation: Contains the collider hit by the ray. It can be used to access the collider's properties and methods.
@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.collider.code_sample:
local ray = Ray.new(Vector3.new(0, 0, 0), Vector3.new(0, 0, 1))
local hit = Physics.Raycast(ray)

local collider = hit.collider
print(collider.name) -- Name of the collider hit by the ray

@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.collider.documentation: Holds the unique identifier for the collider hit by the ray. This identifier is unique to each collider in the game.
@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.collider.code_sample:
local ray = Ray.new(Vector3.new(0, 0, 0), Vector3.new(0, 0, 1))
local hit = Physics.Raycast(ray)

local colliderInstanceID = hit.colliderInstanceID
print(colliderInstanceID) -- Unique identifier of the collider hit by the ray

@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.point.documentation: The point in world space where the raycast hit the collider. It represents the position of the hit point.
@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.point.code_sample:
local ray = Ray.new(Vector3.new(0, 0, 0), Vector3.new(0, 0, 1))
local hit = Physics.Raycast(ray)

local point = hit.point
print(point) -- Position of the hit point

@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.normal.documentation: Gives the normal of the surface hit by the ray. The normal is a vector perpendicular to the surface at the hit point.
@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.normal.code_sample:
local ray = Ray.new(Vector3.new(0, 0, 0), Vector3.new(0, 0, 1))
local hit = Physics.Raycast(ray)

local normal = hit.normal
print(normal) -- Normal of the surface hit by the ray

@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.barycent.documentation: Provides the barycentric coordinates of the hit point on the mesh. Barycentric coordinates are used to represent a point on a triangle.
@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.barycent.code_sample:
local ray = Ray.new(Vector3.new(0, 0, 0), Vector3.new(0, 0, 1))
local hit = Physics.Raycast(ray)

local barycentricCoordinate = hit.barycentricCoordinate
print(barycentricCoordinate) -- Barycentric coordinates of the hit point

@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.distance.documentation: Refers to the distance from the ray's origin to the hit point. It represents the length of the ray from the origin to the hit point.
@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.distance.code_sample:
local ray = Ray.new(Vector3.new(0, 0, 0), Vector3.new(0, 0, 1))
local hit = Physics.Raycast(ray)

local distance = hit.distance
print(distance) -- Distance from the ray's origin to the hit point

@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.triangle.documentation: Holds the index of the triangle hit by the ray. The triangle index is used to identify the triangle hit by the ray.
@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.triangle.code_sample:
local ray = Ray.new(Vector3.new(0, 0, 0), Vector3.new(0, 0, 1))
local hit = Physics.Raycast(ray)

local triangleIndex = hit.triangleIndex
print(triangleIndex) -- Index of the triangle hit by the ray

@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.textureC.documentation: Provides the coordinates of the texture hit by the ray. The texture coordinates are used to map textures to 3D models.
@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.textureC.code_sample:
local ray = Ray.new(Vector3.new(0, 0, 0), Vector3.new(0, 0, 1))
local hit = Physics.Raycast(ray)

local textureCoord = hit.textureCoord
print(textureCoord) -- Coordinates of the texture hit by the ray

@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.textureC.documentation: Provides the coordinates of the second texture hit by the ray. The second texture coordinates are used to map textures to 3D models.
@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.textureC.code_sample:
local ray = Ray.new(Vector3.new(0, 0, 0), Vector3.new(0, 0, 1))
local hit = Physics.Raycast(ray)

local textureCoord2 = hit.textureCoord2
print(textureCoord2) -- Coordinates of the second texture hit by the ray

@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.transfor.documentation: Provides the Transform of the object that was hit. The Transform represents the position, rotation, and scale of the object.
@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.transfor.code_sample:
local ray = Ray.new(Vector3.new(0, 0, 0), Vector3.new(0, 0, 1))
local hit = Physics.Raycast(ray)

local transform = hit.transform
print(transform.name) -- Name of the object hit by the ray

@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.rigidbod.documentation: Offers access to the Rigidbody of the hit object, if it has one. The Rigidbody is used to simulate physics on an object.
@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.rigidbod.code_sample:
local ray = Ray.new(Vector3.new(0, 0, 0), Vector3.new(0, 0, 1))
local hit = Physics.Raycast(ray)

local rigidbody = hit.rigidbody
print(rigidbody.name) -- Name of the Rigidbody of the hit object

@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.lightmap.documentation: Provides the coordinates of the lightmap hit by the ray. The lightmap coordinates are used to map lightmaps to 3D models.
@highrise/globaltype/RaycastHit.lightmap.code_sample:
local ray = Ray.new(Vector3.new(0, 0, 0), Vector3.new(0, 0, 1))
local hit = Physics.Raycast(ray)

local lightmapCoord = hit.lightmapCoord
print(lightmapCoord) -- Coordinates of the lightmap hit by the ray

@highrise/globaltype/Ray.documentation: Represents a line in 3D space extending indefinitely from a source point (origin) in a specified direction. It is utilized extensively for ray casting and collision detection.

@highrise/global/Ray.documentation: Represents a line in 3D space extending indefinitely from a source point (origin) in a specified direction. It is utilized extensively for ray casting and collision detection.

@highrise/globaltype/Ray.GetPoint.documentation: Retrieves a point along the ray at a specified distance from the origin. The distance is measured in the direction of the ray.
@highrise/globaltype/Ray.GetPoint.code_sample:
local origin = Vector3.new(0, 0, 0)
local direction = Vector3.new(0, 0, 1)

local ray = Ray.new(origin, direction)
local point = ray:GetPoint(5)

print(point) -- (0, 0, 5)

params.name: distance
params.documentation: The distance along the ray from the origin point.

returns.documentation: Returns the point at the given distance along the ray.

@highrise/globaltype/Ray.new.documentation: Creates a new Ray instance with specified origin and direction vectors. If the direction vector's magnitude is not 1, it's normalized. The origin and direction vectors are stored in the Ray instance.
@highrise/globaltype/Ray.new.code_sample:
local origin = Vector3.new(0, 0, 0)
local direction = Vector3.new(0, 0, 1)

local ray = Ray.new(origin, direction)

params.name: origin
params.documentation: The starting point of the ray in 3D space.

params.name: direction
params.documentation: The direction of the ray in 3D space.

returns.documentation: Returns a new Ray instance with specified origin and direction.

@highrise/globaltype/Ray.origin.documentation: Represents the starting point of the ray in 3D space.
@highrise/globaltype/Ray.origin.code_sample:
local origin = Vector3.new(0, 0, 0)
local direction = Vector3.new(0, 0, 1)

local ray = Ray.new(origin, direction)
print(ray.origin) -- (0, 0, 0)

@highrise/globaltype/Ray.direction.documentation: Depicts the path along which the ray extends in 3D space. The direction vector is normalized to have a magnitude of 1.
@highrise/globaltype/Ray.direction.code_sample:
local origin = Vector3.new(0, 0, 0)
local direction = Vector3.new(0, 0, 1)

local ray = Ray.new(origin, direction)
print(ray.direction) -- (0, 0, 1)

@highrise/globaltype/LocalizedString.documentation: Represents a localized string within a LocalizedDatabase.

@highrise/global/LocalizedString.documentation: Represents a localized string within a LocalizedDatabase.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.documentation:
Operates as the cornerstone in modeling transformations in 3D space, holding critical data about translations, rotations, and scaling. Think of it as the mathematical blueprint that instructs your 3D objects on how to transform from one state to another – a fundamental tool in creating dynamic and interactive 3D environments. Like a guiding chart for your 3D objects, impacting how they move, turn, and resize in the 3D realm.

[Matrix4x4 section from the official Unity Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Matrix4x4.html)

@highrise/global/Matrix4x4.documentation:
Operates as the cornerstone in modeling transformations in 3D space, holding critical data about translations, rotations, and scaling. Think of it as the mathematical blueprint that instructs your 3D objects on how to transform from one state to another – a fundamental tool in creating dynamic and interactive 3D environments. Like a guiding chart for your 3D objects, impacting how they move, turn, and resize in the 3D realm.

[Matrix4x4 section from the official Unity Documentation](https://docs.unity3d.com/2022.3/Documentation/ScriptReference/Matrix4x4.html)

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.ValidTRS.documentation: Checks if a matrix is a valid transformation matrix. It returns a boolean indicating whether the matrix holds valid translation, rotation, and scale values.

returns.documentation: Returns true if the matrix is a valid transformation matrix, otherwise false.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.SetTRS.documentation: Sets the matrix to a transformation matrix, given a Vector3 for position, a Quaternion for rotation, and a Vector3 for scale. It's quick and convenient when you want to set up a transform from position, rotation and scale values.

params.name: pos
params.documentation: The position to set in the transformation matrix.

params.name: q
params.documentation: The rotation to set in the transformation matrix.

params.name: s
params.documentation: The scale to set in the transformation matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.GetColumn.documentation: Vector4 representing a specified column of the matrix. This can be helpful when you need to extract specific column information from a matrix.

params.name: index
params.documentation: The index of the column to retrieve.

returns.documentation: Returns a Vector4 representing the specified column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.GetRow.documentation: Vector4 representing a specified row of the matrix. This can be useful when you need to extract certain row information from a matrix.

params.name: index
params.documentation: The index of the row to retrieve.

returns.documentation: Returns a Vector4 representing the specified row of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.GetPositi.documentation: Vector3 representing the position stored in the transformation matrix. This is particularly useful when wanting to extract the position component from a transformation matrix.

returns.documentation: Returns a Vector3 representing the position stored in the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.SetColumn.documentation: Vector4 to a specified column of the matrix. This method comes in handy when you want to replace a specific column of a matrix.

params.name: index
params.documentation: The index of the column to set.

params.name: column
params.documentation: The vector to set in the specified column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.SetRow.documentation: Vector4 to a specified row of the matrix. You can use this method to replace a certain row of a matrix.

params.name: index
params.documentation: The index of the row to set.

params.name: row
params.documentation: The vector to set in the specified row of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.MultiplyP.documentation: Multiplies a Matrix4x4 and a Vector3 together. It treats the input Vector3 as a point in 3D space - this means it also considers the translation stored in the matrix.

params.name: point
params.documentation: The vector to be multiplied with the matrix.

returns.documentation: Returns a Vector3 as a result of the multiplication.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.MultiplyP.documentation: Multiplies a Matrix4x4 and a Vector3 together. It treats the matrix as if it's a 3x4 matrix, and thus the result will not have perspective projection applied.

params.name: point
params.documentation: The vector to be multiplied with the matrix.

returns.documentation: Returns a Vector3 as a result of the multiplication without perspective projection.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.MultiplyV.documentation: Multiplies a Matrix4x4 and a Vector3 together. It treats the input Vector3 as a direction rather than a point, meaning it will not consider the translation part of the matrix.

params.name: vector
params.documentation: The vector to be multiplied with the matrix.

returns.documentation: Returns a Vector3 as a result of the multiplication.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4Type.Deter.documentation: Determinant of a given Matrix4x4. The determinant of a matrix is a special scalar value that can be computed from its elements and can provide useful information about the matrix.

params.name: m
params.documentation: The matrix whose determinant is to be calculated.

returns.documentation: Returns the determinant of the given matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4Type.TRS.documentation: Creates a transformation matrix from translation, rotation, and scale. The 'TRS' stands for 'Translate, Rotate, Scale'. It returns a Matrix4x4 built from the given Vector3 of position, Quaternion of rotation and another Vector3 of scale.

params.name: pos
params.documentation: The position to be included in the transformation matrix.

params.name: q
params.documentation: The rotation to be included in the transformation matrix.

params.name: s
params.documentation: The scale to be included in the transformation matrix.

returns.documentation: Returns a Matrix4x4 transformation matrix created from a position, rotation, and scale.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4Type.Inver.documentation: Computes the inverse of a given Matrix4x4. The inverse of a matrix is a matrix that, when multiplied with the original matrix, yields the identity matrix.

params.name: m
params.documentation: The matrix to be inversed.

returns.documentation: Returns the inverse of the given matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4Type.Trans.documentation: Creates the transpose of a given Matrix4x4. The transpose of a matrix is a new matrix whose rows are the columns of the original matrix and whose columns are the original's rows.

params.name: m
params.documentation: The matrix to be transposed.

returns.documentation: Returns the transpose of the given matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4Type.Ortho.documentation: Creates an orthogonal projection matrix. The resulting matrix can be used to transform coordinates in 3D into a 2D projection. This is particularly useful in things like 2D games or interfaces.

params.name: left
params.documentation: The value for the left vertical clipping plane.

params.name: right
params.documentation: The value for the right vertical clipping plane.

params.name: bottom
params.documentation: The value for the bottom horizontal clipping plane.

params.name: top
params.documentation: The value for the top horizontal clipping plane.

params.name: zNear
params.documentation: The value for the near depth clipping plane.

params.name: zFar
params.documentation: The value for the far depth clipping plane.

returns.documentation: Returns an orthogonal projection matrix created from the specified parameters.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4Type.Persp.documentation: Creates a perspective projection matrix from field of view, aspect ratio, and near and far clipping planes. The resulting matrix can be used to transform 3D coordinates into a 2D perspective.

params.name: fov
params.documentation: The field of view in the y direction, measured in degrees.

params.name: aspect
params.documentation: The aspect ratio, defined as width divided by height.

params.name: zNear
params.documentation: The value for the near depth clipping plane.

params.name: zFar
params.documentation: The value for the far depth clipping plane.

returns.documentation: Returns a perspective projection matrix created from the specified parameters.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4Type.LookA.documentation: Creates a viewing matrix aimed at a target with a defined up direction. This method can be useful in a variety of situations, like setting the view matrix of a camera.

params.name: from
params.documentation: The position the result matrix will transform from.

params.name: to
params.documentation: The target point the result matrix will face towards.

params.name: up
params.documentation: The up direction. It must not be parallel to the direction vector pointing from 'from' to 'to'.

returns.documentation: Returns a viewing matrix aimed at the target from a set position and up direction.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4Type.Frust.documentation: Creates a perspective projection matrix that represents a view frustum. A frustum is a kind of pyramid with its top cut off. It is typically what a camera in 3D space sees with certain field of view and near and far clipping planes.

params.name: left
params.documentation: The value for the left vertical clipping plane.

params.name: right
params.documentation: The value for the right vertical clipping plane.

params.name: bottom
params.documentation: The value for the bottom horizontal clipping plane.

params.name: top
params.documentation: The value for the top horizontal clipping plane.

params.name: zNear
params.documentation: The value for the near depth clipping plane.

params.name: zFar
params.documentation: The value for the far depth clipping plane.

returns.documentation: Returns a perspective projection matrix that represents the specified view frustum.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4Type.Scale.documentation: Creates a scaling matrix from a given Vector3. The resulting matrix can be used to scale an object in 3D space by the specified vector.

params.name: vector
params.documentation: The vector by which to scale.

returns.documentation: Returns a scaling matrix created from the specified vector.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4Type.Trans.documentation: Creates a translation matrix from a given Vector3. It can be used to move an object in 3D space by a specified vector.

params.name: vector
params.documentation: The vector by which to translate.

returns.documentation: Returns a translation matrix created from the specified vector.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4Type.Rotat.documentation: Creates a rotation matrix from a Quaternion. The resulting matrix can be used to rotate an object in 3D space by the specified Quaternion.

params.name: q
params.documentation: The quaternion by which to rotate.

returns.documentation: Returns a rotation matrix created from the specified quaternion.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.new.documentation: Creates a new Matrix4x4 instance given four Vector4 inputs for each column of the matrix. It constructs a 4x4 matrix using four 4-dimensional vectors.

params.name: column0
params.documentation: This is the first column vector of the 4x4 matrix.

params.name: column1
params.documentation: This is the second column vector of the 4x4 matrix.

params.name: column2
params.documentation: This is the third column vector of the 4x4 matrix.

params.name: column3
params.documentation: This is the fourth column vector of the 4x4 matrix.

returns.documentation: Returns a new Matrix4x4 instance.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.rotation.documentation: Quaternion that represents the rotation part of this matrix. Accessing this property can be particularly useful if you want to extract the rotation information of a Matrix4x4 instance.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.lossyScal.documentation: Vector3 representing the scale of the matrix. If the matrix has a uniform scale (the same scale along all axes), 'lossyScale' will correctly report it. If the matrix has a non-uniform scale (different scales along different axes), 'lossyScale' will not accurately reflect it.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.isIdentit.documentation: Boolean indicating whether the matrix is the identity matrix. The identity matrix is a special type of matrix that doesn't change any vector when we multiply that vector with it.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.determina.documentation: Determinant of the matrix. The determinant is a special number that encapsulates some properties of the matrix. It is used for solving systems of equations, in calculus, and more.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.inverse.documentation: Inverse of the matrix, assuming it exists. An inverse matrix is a matrix that, when multiplied by the original matrix, yields the identity matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.transpose.documentation: Transpose of the matrix. The transpose of a matrix is obtained by swapping its rows with columns and vice versa.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m00.documentation: Element at the first row and first column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m10.documentation: Element at the second row and first column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m20.documentation: Element in the third row and first column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m30.documentation: Element at the fourth row and first column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m01.documentation: Element in the first row and second column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m11.documentation: Element at the second row and second column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m21.documentation: Element at the third row and second column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m31.documentation: Element in the fourth row and second column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m02.documentation: Element at the first row and third column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m12.documentation: Element in the second row and third column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m22.documentation: Element in the third row and third column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m32.documentation: Element at the fourth row and third column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m03.documentation: Element in the first row and fourth column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m13.documentation: Element at the second row and fourth column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m23.documentation: Element in the third row and fourth column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4.m33.documentation: Element at the fourth row and fourth column of the matrix.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4Type.zero.documentation: Matrix4x4 where all elements are set to zero. This essentially signifies a "null" transformation, meaning no change will take place on applying this matrix to a vector or a point.

@highrise/globaltype/Matrix4x4Type.ident.documentation: Identity Matrix4x4. An identity matrix, when used to transform a point or a vector, leaves it unaltered, just like the number '1' in multiplication. It plays a crucial role in matrix operations and can be very useful for resetting transformations.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.documentation: Tween object for creating smooth animations and transitions. Tween objects are used to create smooth animations and transitions between values. They can be used to animate properties of objects, such as position, scale, rotation, and color. Tweens can be played, paused, stopped, and updated. They can also be delayed, looped, and ping-ponged. Easing functions can be applied to tweens to create different effects, such as acceleration and deceleration. Tweens can be created using the Tween.new method.

@highrise/global/Tween.documentation: Tween object for creating smooth animations and transitions. Tween objects are used to create smooth animations and transitions between values. They can be used to animate properties of objects, such as position, scale, rotation, and color. Tweens can be played, paused, stopped, and updated. They can also be delayed, looped, and ping-ponged. Easing functions can be applied to tweens to create different effects, such as acceleration and deceleration. Tweens can be created using the Tween.new method.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.Play.documentation: Plays the tween animation. If the tween is already playing, it will restart from the beginning.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.Stop.documentation: Stops the tween animation. If the tween is set to destroy, deactivate, or disable on stop, it will be removed from the tween manager.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.Pause.documentation: Pauses the tween animation. The tween can be resumed by calling the Play method.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.Update.documentation: Updates the tween animation for the given delta time. Returns true if the tween is still playing, and false if it has finished.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.Priority.documentation: Sets the priority of the tween. Higher priority tweens will be played before lower priority tweens.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.Delay.documentation: Delays the start of the tween animation. The tween will not start until the delay time has passed.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.AddDelay.documentation: Adds additional delay to the tween animation. The tween will not start until the delay time has passed.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.Duration.documentation: Sets the duration of the tween animation. The tween will take this amount of time to complete.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.Id.documentation: Sets the ID of the tween. The ID can be used to identify the tween in the tween manager.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.DestroyOnStop.documentation: Sets whether the tween should be destroyed when stopped. If true, the tween will be removed from the tween manager when stopped.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.DeactivateOnS.documentation: Sets whether the tween should be deactivated when stopped. If true, the tween will be deactivated when stopped.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.DisableOnStop.documentation: Sets whether the tween should be disabled when stopped. If true, the tween will be disabled when stopped.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.AutoStop.documentation: Sets whether the tween should automatically stop when finished. If true, the tween will stop automatically when it reaches the end of its duration.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.PingPong.documentation: Creates a ping-pong effect for the tween animation. The tween will play forward and then backward.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.From.documentation: Starts the tween animation from a specified point. The tween will start from the current value of the tween target.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.Loop.documentation: Loops the tween animation a specified number of times. If the count is set to -1, the tween will loop indefinitely.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.UnscaledTime.documentation: Sets whether the tween should use unscaled time for its animation. If true, the tween will not be affected by time scale.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.Element.documentation: Sets the element associated with the tween animation. The tween will animate the properties of the specified element.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInQuadrat.documentation: Applies an ease-in quadratic easing function to the tween. This function accelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseOutQuadra.documentation: Applies an ease-out quadratic easing function to the tween. This function decelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInOutQuad.documentation: Applies an ease-in-out quadratic easing function to the tween. This function accelerates and decelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInCubic.documentation: Applies an ease-in cubic easing function to the tween. This function accelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseOutCubic.documentation: Applies an ease-out cubic easing function to the tween. This function decelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInOutCubi.documentation: Applies an ease-in-out cubic easing function to the tween. This function accelerates and decelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInBack.documentation: Applies an ease-in back easing function to the tween. This function overshoots the target value before settling into place.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseOutBack.documentation: Applies an ease-out back easing function to the tween. This function overshoots the target value before settling into place.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInOutBack.documentation: Applies an ease-in-out back easing function to the tween. This function overshoots the target value before settling into place.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInElastic.documentation: Applies an ease-in elastic easing function to the tween. This function creates a spring-like effect.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseOutElasti.documentation: Applies an ease-out elastic easing function to the tween. This function creates a spring-like effect.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInOutElas.documentation: Applies an ease-in-out elastic easing function to the tween. This function creates a spring-like effect.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInBounce.documentation: Applies an ease-in bounce easing function to the tween. This function creates a bouncing effect.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseOutBounce.documentation: Applies an ease-out bounce easing function to the tween. This function creates a bouncing effect.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInOutBoun.documentation: Applies an ease-in-out bounce easing function to the tween. This function creates a bouncing effect.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInSine.documentation: Applies an ease-in sine easing function to the tween. This function accelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseOutSine.documentation: Applies an ease-out sine easing function to the tween. This function decelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInOutSine.documentation: Applies an ease-in-out sine easing function to the tween. This function accelerates and decelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInCircle.documentation: Applies an ease-in circular easing function to the tween. This function accelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseOutCircle.documentation: Applies an ease-out circular easing function to the tween. This function decelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInOutCirc.documentation: Applies an ease-in-out circular easing function to the tween. This function accelerates and decelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInExponen.documentation: Applies an ease-in exponential easing function to the tween. This function accelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseOutExpone.documentation: Applies an ease-out exponential easing function to the tween. This function decelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInOutExpo.documentation: Applies an ease-in-out exponential easing function to the tween. This function accelerates and decelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInCubicBe.documentation: Applies an ease-in cubic Bezier easing function to the tween. This function accelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseOutCubicB.documentation: Applies an ease-out cubic Bezier easing function to the tween. This function decelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.EaseInOutCubi.documentation: Applies an ease-in-out cubic Bezier easing function to the tween. This function accelerates and decelerates the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/TweenType.Reset.documentation: Resets all tweens. This will stop all tweens and remove them from the tween manager.

@highrise/globaltype/TweenType.StopAll.documentation: Stops all tweens. This will stop all tweens and remove them from the tween manager.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.isPlaying.documentation: Indicates if the tween is currently playing. If the tween is playing, it is animating its properties.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.isPaused.documentation: Indicates if the tween is currently paused. If the tween is paused, it can be resumed by calling the Play method.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.isValid.documentation: Indicates if the tween is valid and can be used. If the tween is not valid, it has been stopped or removed from the tween manager.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.normalizedTim.documentation: Current time of the tween normalized to the range [0, 1]. This value represents the progress of the tween animation.

@highrise/globaltype/Tween.duration.documentation: Total duration of the tween. The tween will take this amount of time to complete.

@highrise/globaltype/TweenType.IsAnyTwee.documentation: Checks if any tween is currently animating. Returns true if any tween is playing, and false if no tweens are playing.

@highrise/globaltype/Time.documentation: Provides controls over time-related aspects in your game Universe. It regulates the flow of time and pace of game actions, orchestrating object movements and animations.

@highrise/global/Time.documentation: Provides controls over time-related aspects in your game Universe. It regulates the flow of time and pace of game actions, orchestrating object movements and animations.

@highrise/globaltype/Time.deltaTime.documentation: 'deltaTime' represents the time in seconds it took to complete the last frame. It's useful for smooth object motion or time-related calculations, reflecting real-world time more than game time.

@highrise/globaltype/Time.fixedDeltaTime.documentation: 'fixedDeltaTime' signifies the time in seconds between physics updates (FixedUpdate calls). It's consistent between frames, crucial for physics calculations requiring stable performance.

@highrise/globaltype/Inventory.documentation: The Inventory API provides functionality for handling owned items and currencies.  Inventories can be stored per player, but also supports non-player ids to allow for features such as storage boxes for either a single player or group of players.  Changes to the inventory are handled through InventoryTransactions which contains actions that are either all processed when a operation succeeds or are all skipped if the operation fails.  This means you will never have cases such as a player buying an item from a shop within the world, losing their currency, but not getting the item, or cases such as two players trading items and the items end up duplicated or permanently lost.  The Inventory API is only available on the server.  See InventoryError for a list of errors that can be returned from Inventory functions.  There is a limit of how often Inventory functions can be called before functions will start returning InventoryError.RequestThrottled.  See the documentation for InventoryError.RequestThrottled for details.

@highrise/global/Inventory.documentation: The Inventory API provides functionality for handling owned items and currencies.  Inventories can be stored per player, but also supports non-player ids to allow for features such as storage boxes for either a single player or group of players.  Changes to the inventory are handled through InventoryTransactions which contains actions that are either all processed when a operation succeeds or are all skipped if the operation fails.  This means you will never have cases such as a player buying an item from a shop within the world, losing their currency, but not getting the item, or cases such as two players trading items and the items end up duplicated or permanently lost.  The Inventory API is only available on the server.  See InventoryError for a list of errors that can be returned from Inventory functions.  There is a limit of how often Inventory functions can be called before functions will start returning InventoryError.RequestThrottled.  See the documentation for InventoryError.RequestThrottled for details.

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryType.GetIt.documentation: Returns the data for a particular item owned by the holder.  The callback parameters are an InventoryItem containing the item data and the error code.  The item will be nil and the error code will be InventoryError.None if the holder does not own the item.  The item will be nil and the error code will be a value other than InventoryError.None if an error occurred.

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryType.GetPl.documentation: This is the equivalent of calling GetItem(player.user.id, callback).
@highrise/globaltype/InventoryType.GetPl.code_sample:
function PrintItem(player: Player, itemId: string)
    Inventory.GetPlayerItem(player, itemId, function(item)
      if(item == nil) then
        print(`Player {player.name} does not have {itemId}`)
      else
        print(`Player {player.name} has {item.amount} of {item.id}`)
      end
    end)
  end

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryType.GetIt.documentation: Returns up to the given limit number of items the holder owns.  To get the first group of items, pass in nil for the cursorId.
