The callback includes a cursorId that can be passed to GetItems to retrieve the next group of items.  If the cursor ID is nil, then there are no more items.  The callback parameters are an array of InventoryItem, the cursor ID, and the error code.  The array will be empty and the error code will be InventoryError.None if the holder owns no items.  The array will be nil and the error code will be a value other than InventoryError.None if an error occurred.
@highrise/globaltype/InventoryType.GetIt.code_sample:
function GetItems(holder: string, limit: number, cursorId: string)
    Inventory.GetItems(holder, limit, cursorId, function(items, newCursorId, errorCode)
      if(items == nil) then
        print(`Got error {InventoryError[errorCode]} while getting items`)
        return
      end
              
      for index, item in items do
        print(`{item.id} : {item.amount}`)
      end
      
      if(newCursorId ~= nil) then
        GetItems(holder, limit, newCursorId)
      else
        print("done")
      end
    end)
  end
  GetItems("SharedStorage", 15)

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryType.GetPl.documentation: This is the equivalent of calling GetItems(player.user.id, limit, cursorId, callback).

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryType.Commi.documentation: CommitTransaction will perform all the actions contained in the transaction if the returned error code is InventoryError.None or none of the actions if the returned error code is a value other than InventoryError.None.  The callback parameters are the transaction ID and error code.  The returned transaction ID can be used to call RollbackTransaction if the actions need to be undone.

@highrise/globaltype/InventoryType.Rollb.documentation: Undos the actions of a committed transaction by passing in the transaction ID that was returned in the callback of CommitTransaction.  The callback parameter is the error code.

@highrise/global/defer.documentation: Defers the execution of a function to the next frame. This is useful for when you want to run a function after the current frame has finished.

params.name: callback
params.documentation: The function to run in the next frame.

@luau/global/require.documentation:
Gets a 'Module' typed script by name as a singleton behaviour, giving access to the hierarchy it is within.

Using the require method to retrieve a module will automatically load the singleton instance of the behaviour. This is equivalent to using Find and GetComponent to retrieve the behaviour.

params.name: path
params.documentation: The script name of the module to load.

returns.documentation: The module that was loaded.

@luau/global/typeof.documentation: Gets the string representation of the type of the object. This is useful for debugging and logging as well as learning about what types are being returned by complex methods.
@luau/global/typeof.code_sample:
local v = Vector3.new(1, 2, 3)
  print(typeof(v)) -- prints "Vector3" instead of "userdata" or "(1, 2, 3)"

returns.documentation: The Type of the object. In question.

@luau/global/tostring.documentation: Gets the string representation of the object if one has defined one. This is useful for debugging and logging.
@luau/global/tostring.code_sample:
local v = Vector3.new(1, 2, 3)
  print(tostring(v)) -- prints "(1, 2, 3)" instead of "userdata" or "Vector3"

@highrise/global/self.documentation: The 'self' property is used to access the current script's instance. This is always the owning script of the object as a Class.LuaBehaviour. This is the primary way to get many of the core Unity MonoBehaviour methods and properties like `self.gameObject`, `self:Update` and `self:OnTriggerEnter`. It is highly recommended to familiarize yourself with the Class.LuaBehaviour documentation to understand how to use the 'self' property.
@highrise/global/self.code_sample:
local objectName = self.gameObject.name
  print("My name is: " .. objectName)

@highrise/global/client.documentation: The 'client' property is used to access the current client instance. This is useful for when you want to access the client's information like the `client.localPlayer` property or `client.PlayerConnected` event. Read the Class.GameClient documentation to learn more.
@highrise/global/client.code_sample:
local localPlayer = client.localPlayer
  print("My name is: " .. localPlayer.name)

@highrise/global/server.documentation: The 'server' property is used to access the current server instance. This is useful for when you want to access the server' information like the `server.PlayerConnected` event. Read the Class.GameServer documentation to learn more.

@highrise/global/scene.documentation: The 'scene' property is used to access the currently active scene.

@highrise/hotcomment/SerializeField.name: SerializeField
@highrise/hotcomment/SerializeField.documentation: This attribute allows you serialize a variable in your lua script, exposing it as one of the script properties in the inspector window in the Unity Editor
@highrise/hotcomment/SerializeField.code_sample:
--!SerializeField
local obstaclePrefab: GameObject = nil
...
local obstacle = Object.Instantiate(obstaclePrefab)

@highrise/hotcomment/Header.name: Header
@highrise/hotcomment/Header.documentation: This attributes adds a header above some fields in the inspector window
@highrise/hotcomment/Header.code_sample:
--!Header("Health Settings")
local health: number = 0
local maxHealth: number = 0

@highrise/hotcomment/Tooltip.name: Tooltip
@highrise/hotcomment/Tooltip.documentation: This attribute specifies a tooltip for a field in the inspector window
@highrise/hotcomment/Tooltip.code_sample:
--!Tooltip("Health value between 0 and 100")
--!SerializeField
local health: number = 0

@highrise/hotcomment/Range.name: Range
@highrise/hotcomment/Range.documentation: This attribute makes a number variable in a script be restricted to a specific range

@highrise/hotcomment/Space.name: Space
@highrise/hotcomment/Space.documentation: This attribute adds some spacing in the inspector window
@highrise/hotcomment/Space.code_sample:
--!SerializeField
local health: number = 0
--!SerializeField
local maxHealth: number = 0

--!Space(10)

--!SerializeField
local mana: number = 0
--!SerializeField
local maxMana: number = 0

@highrise/hotcomment/AddComponentMenu.name: AddComponentMenu
@highrise/hotcomment/AddComponentMenu.documentation: This attribute allows you to place a script anywhere in the Component menu, instead of just the Component->Scripts menu

@highrise/hotcomment/DisallowMultipleCom.name: DisallowMultipleComponent
@highrise/hotcomment/DisallowMultipleCom.documentation: This attribute prevents the script from being added more than once to a GameObject

@highrise/hotcomment/RequireComponent.name: RequireComponent
@highrise/hotcomment/RequireComponent.documentation: This attribute automatically adds required components as dependencies

@highrise/hotcomment/Bind.name: Bind
@highrise/hotcomment/Bind.documentation: This attribute binds UXML properties to its variable

@highrise/hotcomment/Type(UI).name: Type(UI)
@highrise/hotcomment/Type(UI).documentation: This attribute forces the script type to be 'UI'. With this type it can be used to define your UI

@highrise/hotcomment/Type(ClientAndServe.name: Type(ClientAndServer)
@highrise/hotcomment/Type(ClientAndServe.documentation: This attribute forces the script type to be 'Client And Server'. With this type it will be executed both on client and server

@highrise/hotcomment/Type(Client).name: Type(Client)
@highrise/hotcomment/Type(Client).documentation: This attribute forces the script type to be 'Client'. With this type it will be executed only on the client

@highrise/hotcomment/Type(Server).name: Type(Server)
@highrise/hotcomment/Type(Server).documentation: This attribute forces the script type to be 'Server'. With this type it will be executed only on the server

@highrise/hotcomment/Type(Module).name: Type(Module)
@highrise/hotcomment/Type(Module).documentation: This attribute forces the script type to be 'Module'. With this type it can be referenced by other scripts with the require method and used for common functionalities
